original_text: The immune system is a system of many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease. To function properly, an immune system must detect a wide variety of agents, known as pathogens, from viruses to parasitic worms, and distinguish them from the organism's own healthy tissue. In many species, the immune system can be classified into subsystems, such as the innate immune system versus the adaptive immune system, or humoral immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans, the blood-brain barrier, blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier, and similar fluid-brain barriers separate the peripheral immune system from the neuroimmune system which protects the brain.

original_text: Luther was a prolific hymn-writer, authoring hymns such as "Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott" A Mighty Fortress Is Our God, based on Psalm 46, and "Vom Himmel hoch, da komm ich her" From Heaven Above to Earth I Come, based on Luke 2:11-12. Luther connected high art and folk music, also all classes, clergy and laity, men, women and children. His tool of choice for this connection was the singing of German hymns in connection with worship, school, home, and the public arena. He often accompanied the sung hymns with a lute, later recreated as the waldzither that became a national instrument of Germany in the 20th century.

original_text: The shortcomings of Aristotelian physics would not be fully corrected until the 17th century work of Galileo Galilei, who was influenced by the late Medieval idea that objects in forced motion carried an innate force of impetus. Galileo constructed an experiment in which stones and cannonballs were both rolled down an incline to disprove the Aristotelian theory of motion early in the 17th century. He showed that the bodies were accelerated by gravity to an extent that was independent of their mass and argued that objects retain their velocity unless acted on by a force, for example friction.

original_text: An apoplectic stroke deprived him of his speech, and he died shortly afterwards at 2:45 a.m. on 18 February 1546, aged 62, in Eisleben, the city of his birth. He was buried in the Castle Church in Wittenberg, beneath the pulpit. The funeral was held by his friends Johannes Bugenhagen and Philipp Melanchthon. A year later, troops of Luther's adversary Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor entered the town, but were ordered by Charles not to disturb the grave.

original_text: Luther next set about reversing or modifying the new church practices. By working alongside the authorities to restore public order, he signalled his reinvention as a conservative force within the church. Instead of taking a stand against the most abusive of practices, as he had before, he now launched a broadside against them all. His 'Disputation against Scholastic Theology' in 1517 was a frontal attack on the church's attempts to transform the poorly educated clergy into theologians. The next year he issued a programme of reform that was a careful compromise with existing arrangements: he promised to eliminate the sale of indulgences, but he also defended the idea of them, along with a variety of other practices. It was the church, he said, that would decide which practices to continue. The Disputation against the Scholastic Theology (1517) has been translated into English, as has the outline of a reform programme that Luther published the following year. In 1519 Luther was recalled to Wittenberg from the Augustinian house in Wittenberg, where he had been living since 1512, to lecture on the Bible to the university's students. There he was called upon to review a new Bible translation, the New Testament of which was translated from Greek into German by the humanist Desiderius Erasmus. As a devout Augustinian monk and committed teacher of the Bible, Luther was convinced that the Bible was the supreme authority for Christian faith and life. On this basis, he criticized the new translation for its inaccuracy, lack of clarity, and failure to address the spiritual needs of the reader. In response, Luther began translating the Bible into German, a project that he completed in 1534. In 1520, the papal authorities, who had been investigating Luther's teachings since 1518, responded to his challenge. They demanded that he recant and threatened to excommunicate him if he refused. Luther was summoned to appear before the Holy Roman Emperor, Charles V, at the imperial diet in the German city of Worms. There, in April 1521, he refused to retract his writings and was subsequently excommunicated by the pope. To his friends and supporters, Luther had become a hero, but to his opponents he was a heretic who must be punished. Luther's supporters sheltered him in Wartburg castle, where he lived under the alias of a knight named George. There he completed his translation of the Bible and in 1522 began to write devotional texts, catechisms, and hymns, which he hoped would help the common people understand the new ideas that he had introduced. Back in Wittenberg in 1522, Luther promoted the Reformation by helping to develop a new form of church order. Together with the German humanist and statesman Philip Melanchthon, he wrote a new liturgy and a series of catechisms that introduced the new teachings to laypeople. He also helped to reform the university in Wittenberg, and in 1524 he began to write his great commentaries on the books of the Bible. In the same year he married Katharina von Bora, a former nun, and established a family with her. Throughout the 1520s Luther worked to strengthen his position in the church and society. He promoted the translation of the Bible into German, and he also wrote a number of works to explain his theological views. He also supported the development of new forms of religious life, and he helped to lead the Protestant movement in Wittenberg. In 1525, the German princes and the Holy Roman Emperor signed the Peace of Augsburg, which recognized the principle that each German prince could choose either Lutheranism or Catholicism as the official religion of his territory. The Peace of Augsburg settled the religious issue in Germany, but it did not end religious tensions in Europe. In 1529 the pope excommunicated Luther, and in 1530 he published 'On the Babylonian Captivity of the Church', a powerful polemic against the church's sacramental practices. In this period Luther also confronted the threat of a radical party that wanted to do away with the church altogether. In 'Against the Robbing and Murdering Hordes of Peasants' (1525) and the 'Sermon on Good Works' (1528), Luther defended the authority of the state, thereby opposing the radicals and strengthening his position as a leader in German society.

original_text: The Broncos defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers in the divisional round, 23-16, by scoring 11 points in the final three minutes of the game. They then beat the defending Super Bowl champion Seattle Seahawks in the AFC Championship, 20-18, in overtime. Brady has been suspended for the first four games of the 2015 regular season for his alleged role in deflating footballs used in the AFC title game. The NFL claims the quarterback knew footballs provided by the Patriots were intentionally deflated below the league-mandated minimum of 12.5 PSI, and that he was "generally aware" of the actions of other Patriots personnel involved in the scandal. New England's regular-season home opener is scheduled for Sept. 27 against the Dallas Cowboys, but Brady will be eligible to return to action on Oct. 11 against the Indianapolis Colts. Brady has led the Patriots to six Super Bowl appearances, winning four, and has been named Super Bowl MVP twice. He has also won two NFL MVP awards and 11 AFC East titles. He is currently a three-time NFL MVP, a two-time Super Bowl MVP and a 10-time Pro Bowler. For a list of all Patriots' Super Bowl appearances, click here. original_text: One of the more unusual collections is that of Eadweard Muybridge's photographs of Animal Locomotion of 1887, this consists of 781 plates. These sequences of photographs taken a fraction of a second apart capture images of different animals and humans performimg various actions. There are several of John Thomson's 1876-7 images of Street Life in London in the collection. The museum also holds James Lafayette's society portraits, a collection of more than 600 photographs dating from the late 19th to early 20th centuries and portraying a wide range of society figures of the period, including bishops, generals, society ladies, Indian maharajas, Ethiopian rulers and other foreign leaders, actresses, people posing in their motor cars and a sequence of photographs recording the guests at the famous fancy-dress ball held at Devonshire House in 1897 to celebrate Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee.

original_text: The third assessment report (TAR) prominently featured a graph labeled "Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction" based on a 1999 paper by Michael E. Mann, Raymond S. Bradley and Malcolm K. Hughes, later referred to as "MBH98" for short, and its 1999 updates. The graph appeared to show a sharp rise in the 20th century, much steeper than the apparent variations in earlier centuries. The graph was featured in the Summary for Policymakers of the Third Assessment Report (TAR), and gained the popular name "hockey stick graph" because of its shape, which some commentators have noted is similar to that of an ice hockey stick. Mann, Bradley and Hughes used statistical techniques to combine a set of proxy measurements, or indicators of past temperatures, taken from historical records and other sources such as tree rings, ice cores, coral and lake sediments. They created a graph of the northern hemisphere mean temperature over the last 600 years, and reported that their graph showed a sharp rise in the late 20th century, in comparison to the earlier centuries. A strong divergence between the proxy data and instrumental data was apparent after about 1970. The proxy data and instrumental data were both plotted on the same graph, and both were smoothed by a Gaussian filter. The graph quickly became a central icon of the global warming controversy. Soon after publication of the MBH98 papers, two scientists from the United States, Stephen McIntyre and Ross McKitrick, began a critical examination of the MBH98 methodology. In October 2003, they published a paper in Energy Environment (McIntyre and McKitrick 2003) which argued that the statistical methods used by MBH98 had been flawed and had resulted in a graph which showed a spurious 20th century trend. Mann, Bradley and Hughes published a paper in 2004, (MBH98: Corrigendum, Mann et al., 2004) which contained corrections to the original paper, and a revised graph which showed a strong 20th century upturn, but not as steep as in the original MBH98 graph. The corrections concerned the calculation of principal components, the use of a different normalization of proxies, the use of a slightly different data set, and the use of a different algorithm to calculate the principal components. In 2005, McIntyre and McKitrick published a paper in Geophysical Research Letters (McIntyre and McKitrick 2005), which concluded that the MBH98 reconstruction had overestimated the significance of the 20th century upturn in the Northern Hemisphere temperature record, and that this had resulted from the improper use of principal component analysis. This paper was criticized by Wahl and Ammann (2007), who argued that the criticisms of McIntyre and McKitrick did not apply to the MBH98 methodology. Wahl and Ammann also demonstrated that the omission of certain proxy data sets (the "no-dendro" data) and other corrections to the Mann et al. (1998) methodology did not change the qualitative nature of the reconstruction. In 2007, an expert panel was set up by the National Academy of Sciences to review the criticisms of McIntyre and McKitrick. The panel concluded that the criticisms were unfounded. In 2008, McIntyre and McKitrick published a paper in Geophysical Research Letters (McIntyre and McKitrick 2008), which concluded that the use of principal components analysis was inappropriate for this type of data, and that the MBH98 reconstruction had underestimated the uncertainties in the reconstruction. This paper was criticized by Wahl and Ammann (2008), who argued that the criticisms of McIntyre and McKitrick did not apply to the MBH98 methodology. In 2010, the National Research Council released a report which concluded that the Mann et al. reconstruction was spurious, and that the 20th century upturn was not unprecedented. In 2009, a paper by Kaufman et al. was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, which claimed to show that the 20th century upturn was un

original_text: In 1781 James Watt patented a steam engine that produced continuous rotary motion. Watt's ten-horsepower engines enabled a wide range of manufacturing machinery to be powered. The engines could be sited anywhere that water and coal or wood fuel could be obtained. Watt's fundamental breakthrough was to separate the steam condenser from the cylinder. This greatly improved the efficiency of the engine by reducing fuel consumption. Watt also developed a double-acting engine where the cylinder was closed at one end. When steam was fed into the other end of the cylinder the piston was driven one way, and when steam was fed into the first end the piston was driven the other way. Watt's engine was commercially successful, as it was four times as efficient as the Newcomen engine.
text: The Newcomen engine was the world's first diesel engine, but it wasn't the first to use steam as a fuel - it was the British inventor James Watt's engine.

original_text: Firstly, certain costs are difficult to avoid and are shared by everyone, such as the costs of housing, pensions, education and health care. If the state does not provide these services, then for those on lower incomes, the costs must be borrowed and often those on lower incomes are those who are worse equipped to manage their finances. Secondly, aspirational consumption describes the process of middle income earners aspiring to achieve the standards of living enjoyed by their wealthier counterparts and one method of achieving this aspiration is by taking on debt. The result leads to even greater inequality and potential economic instability.

Secondly, aspirational consumption describes the process of middle income earners aspiring to achieve the standards of living enjoyed by their wealthier counterparts and one method of achieving this aspiration is by taking on debt. The result leads to even greater inequality and potential economic instability.

original_text: Dynamic equilibrium was first described by Galileo who noticed that certain assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by observations and logic. Galileo realized that simple velocity addition demands that the resultant motion of the centre of mass of two bodies after a collision is independent of their relative velocities. This is not the case if the bodies stick together; thus, he was able to show that the only way both principles could be valid was if the bodies recoiled and separated to a large distance after impact. Galileo's realization was counterintuitive. He believed that bodies seeking their natural place would be drawn to one another if left to themselves, and he was not aware of the third law of Newton. Galileo's proposed solution is called "the principle of rebound": bodies rebounding from impact obey a principle of "least constraint" in choosing their post-impact motions. This was a mathematical statement of a body's inertia, which was later to become one of the defining characteristics of classical mechanics. Despite the mathematical formulation of inertia, the principle of rebound did not become widely accepted until late in the 17th century, when it was restated by Isaac Newton as the third law of motion. The third law was controversial, and was generally accepted by Continental European physicists only about 1800. Halliday, David; Robert Resnick (2001). Physics. New York: John Wiley Sons. p. 480. ISBN 0-471-32057-9. 2.0 2.1 2.2 Thomson, W. (1983), "Dynamics," in Hawkins, T.L., The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 153-54, ISBN 0-521-23850-8 .

original_text: While in-house production had ceased, the BBC hoped to find an independent production company to relaunch the show. Philip Segal, a British expatriate who worked for Columbia Pictures' television arm in the US, proposed the idea of relaunching the series to the BBC, and eventually the Corporation asked him to oversee the project. Segal's initial proposal envisaged the use of American writers and a predominantly US cast with a British producer. Freedman was unwilling to allow the series to be made outside the UK, and insisted on a predominantly British cast and production team. Segal's next idea was to form a co-production between Columbia Pictures Television, Universal Studios, 20th Century Fox and BBC Worldwide, a commercial arm of the BBC. This did not come to pass, and Segal was approached by BBC Enterprises who agreed to independently finance the production if the rights could be obtained. Segal acquired the rights from the BBC in exchange for a guarantee that a Doctor Who television movie would be produced within three years. Segal approached a number of American television networks to take the project. Fox, NBC, ABC, and UPN all expressed interest, but concerns over the violence and sexual content that had been present in the original series led to them passing on the project. Segal's pitch to CBS was more successful; the network's head of drama, David Rosenthal, was a fan of the original series. The movie was co-produced by BBC Worldwide, Universal Television, 20th Century Fox Television and CBS Entertainment. McCoy was approached to appear in the movie, but declined as he felt his role would be "too short." Davison was also considered for a reprisal of the role, but he also declined. Segal's first choice for the part was Patrick Stewart, who had previously played Captain Jean-Luc Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation, but Stewart turned down the role. Segal next approached Paul McGann, who had previously appeared in Withnail and I and the ITV series The Monocled Mutineer, and he accepted the role. A number of British actors were considered for the part of the Master, including Peter Wyngarde, who had been offered the part of the Master in 1979, and Peter Capaldi, who later played the Twelfth Doctor. Eric Roberts, who had previously appeared in The Cannonball Run and The Dark Knight, was cast in the part. The casting of Daphne Ashbrook, who had appeared in the short-lived series Catwalk, as Grace Holloway was controversial with some fans, who were upset that an American was being cast in the role of the Doctor's companion. Filming of the television movie began on 22 September 1996 in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, lasting until 31 October. The movie was directed by Geoffrey Sax, produced by Philip David Segal, and written by Matthew Jacobs. The movie was intended to be fast-paced, with several special effects-laden action sequences, and would have a length of two hours. As the movie had a relatively large budget, there were a number of high-profile special effects; the TARDIS interior set was completely redesigned, with a swimming pool-like console room. The Master was given a new look; his face was covered in bandages to hide the fact that Eric Roberts was American, rather than British. This was later changed to the Master removing his own face, which he keeps in a jar. The Eye of Harmony was given a new look, with the special effects team creating a three-dimensional representation of a black hole. The television movie was originally intended to have a full-orchestral score, but this was changed to an electronic score by John Debney. The movie was originally intended to be given a prime-time broadcast slot in the US, but was moved to May when it was realised that the movie would clash with coverage of the 1996 Olympics. The special was broadcast on the Fox Network in the United States on 12 May 1996, and by the BBC in the United Kingdom on 27 May 1996. It received high ratings in both countries; 8.3 million viewers in the UK (a 34.2 share of the total audience) and 7.6 million viewers in the US. However, the movie did not fare well with critics, with many feeling that it was too "Americanised." A planned sequel to the television movie, which would have featured the Ice Warriors, was scrapped. Following the broadcast of the television movie, BBC Worldwide received a number of enquiries from production
text: While in-house production had ceased, the BBC hoped to find an independent production company to relaunch the show. Philip Segal, a British expatriate who worked for Columbia Pictures' television arm in the US, proposed the idea of relaunching the series to the BBC, and eventually the Corporation asked him to oversee the project. Segal's initial proposal envisaged the use of American writers and a predominantly US cast with a British producer. Freedman was unwilling to allow the series to be made outside the UK, and insisted on a predominantly British cast and production team. Segal's next idea was to form a co-production between Columbia Pictures Television, Universal Studios, 20th Century Fox and BBC Worldwide, a commercial arm of the BBC. This did not come to pass, and Segal was approached by BBC Enterprises who agreed to independently finance the production if the rights could be obtained. Segal acquired the rights from the BBC in exchange for a guarantee that a Doctor Who television movie would be produced within three years. Segal approached a number of American television networks to take the project. Fox, NBC, ABC, and UPN all expressed interest, but concerns over the violence and sexual content that had been present in the original series led to them passing on the project. Segal's pitch to CBS was more successful; the network's head of drama, David Rosenthal, was a fan of the original series. The movie was co-produced by BBC Worldwide, Universal Television, 20th Century Fox Television and CBS Entertainment. McCoy was approached to appear in the movie, but declined as he felt his role would be "too short." Davison was also considered for a reprisal of the role, but he also declined. Segal's first choice for the part was Patrick Stewart, who had previously played Captain Jean-Luc Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation, but Stewart turned down the role. Segal next approached Paul McGann, who had previously appeared in Withnail and I and the ITV series The Monocled Mutineer, and he accepted the role. A number of British actors were considered for the part of the Master, including Peter Wyngarde, who had been offered the part of the Master in 1979, and Peter Capaldi, who later played the Twelfth Doctor. Eric Roberts, who had previously appeared in The Cannonball Run and The Dark Knight, was cast in the part. The casting of Daphne Ashbrook, who had appeared in the short-lived series Catwalk, as Grace Holloway was controversial with some fans, who were upset that an American was being cast in the role of the Doctor's companion. Filming of the television movie began on 22 September 1996 in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, lasting until 31 October. original_text: In the early years, many Huguenots also settled in the area of present-day Charleston, South Carolina. In 1685, Rev. Elie Prioleau from the town of Pons in France, was among the first to settle there. He became pastor of the first Huguenot church in North America in that city. After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian nobility and descent, including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, Jean Postell of Dieppe France, Alexander Pepin, Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France, and Jacques de Bordeaux of Grenoble, immigrated to the Charleston Orange district. They were very successful at marriage and property speculation. After petitioning the British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies, they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger. Some of their descendants moved into the Deep South and Texas, where they developed new plantations.

original_text: It is possible to use a mechanism based on a pistonless rotary engine such as the Wankel engine in place of the cylinders and valve gear of a conventional reciprocating steam engine. Many such engines have been designed, from the time of James Watt to the present day, but relatively few were actually built and even fewer went into quantity production; see link at bottom of article for more details. The major problem is the difficulty of sealing the rotors to make them steam-tight in the face of wear and thermal expansion; the resulting leakage made them very inefficient. Lack of expansive working, or any means of control of the cutoff is also a serious problem with many such designs.[citation needed]

original_text: As a result, by 1206 Temujin had managed to unite or subdue the Merkits, Naimans, Mongols, Keraites, Tatars, Uyghurs, and other disparate smaller tribes under his rule. It was a monumental feat for the "Mongols" (as they became known collectively). At a Khuruldai, a council of Mongol chiefs, Temujin was acknowledged as "Khan" of the consolidated tribes and took the new title "Genghis Khan." The title Khagan was not conferred on Genghis until after his death, when his son and successor, Ogedei, took the title for himself and extended it posthumously to his father (as he was also to be posthumously declared the founder of the Yuan dynasty). This unification of all confederations by Genghis Khan established peace between previously warring tribes and a single political and military force under Genghis Khan.

original_text: Some of the oldest schools in South Africa are private church schools that were established by missionaries in the early nineteenth century. The private sector has grown ever since. After the Second World War, the African National Congress (ANC) saw private schooling as one of the ways in which white South Africans continued to control the education system and perpetuate the apartheid regime, and it called for the abolition of private schooling. This did not happen, and the number of private schools increased from 1990. Today, private education in South Africa is dominated by independent schools, which are overwhelmingly fee-charging schools that cater for the higher income bracket. They are funded by parents and are governed by school governing bodies. The total number of schools in the independent sector is estimated at 1,126, of which 19.7 are primary schools, 38.7 are combined schools, 30.7 are secondary schools and 10.9 are tertiary schools. Independent schools are far more popular among white South Africans than among black South Africans, and their student population is almost three times more affluent than the national average. The next largest group of private schools is the 'group of schools', which is a type of school that has its own governing body and consists of a number of schools which are operated by the same management group and have the same vision and mission. They are also funded by parents and are responsible for their own budgets. The number of schools in the group of schools sector is estimated at 863, of which 21.3 are primary schools, 40.5 are combined schools, 35.1 are secondary schools and 3.1 are tertiary schools. A smaller group of private schools is the religious-based schools, of which there are 138. Of these, 32.4 are primary schools, 41.5 are combined schools, 17.3 are secondary schools and 8.8 are tertiary schools. These schools are run by a variety of denominations and religious institutions. The number of private schools is unknown, because private education is not regulated by the South African government. There is no state registration of independent schools, but it is estimated that there are 3,300 private schools, of which 1,500 are independent schools. There are also around 700 private creches and nurseries, 2,500 private pre-primary schools and 1,500 private primary schools. The proportion of the student population attending private schools is low by international standards. About 3 of all school students are enrolled in private schools. Private school enrolment is higher among South Africa's white population than its black population, and is also higher among the affluent. The Independent Schools Association of Southern Africa (ISASA) is the largest and oldest association of independent schools in South Africa. It was established in 1929 to advance education and protect the interests of its members. It has more than 800 member schools. The South African Institute of Professional Accountants (SAIPA) is the largest professional accountancy body in South Africa, representing more than 11,000 accountants in the country.

original_text: Since its founding, the EU has operated among an increasing plurality of national and globalising legal systems. This has meant both the European Court of Justice and the highest national courts in EU member states often have to deal with foreign laws. This book explores the cross-border legal problems that this generates. It shows that the way in which different legal orders relate to one another, and the ways in which courts handle these relationships, are central to the transnational legal order. The book provides an exploration of the cross-border legal issues involved in EU and European human rights law. It argues that the European legal order has a fragmented structure, not a single, unitary structure. It shows that the most important factors in understanding the cross-border legal order are the rules of private international law and the specific features of the different areas of law. It also argues that the current structure of the European legal order is neither legally necessary nor desirable, and that it could be replaced by a more integrated structure.

original_text: Later in life, Tesla made claims concerning a "teleforce" weapon after studying the Van de Graaff generator. The press variably referred to it as a "peace ray" or death ray. Tesla described the weapon as being able to be used against ground based infantry or for anti-aircraft purposes. Tesla gave no explanations as to how the directed-energy weapon would operate, though it has been suggested that the he meant to use a stream of tachyons (hypothetical particles that move faster than light). In 1937, Tesla wrote about it to Tryntje (Katherine) Rogers, a woman from The Netherlands who ran a spiritual center and was a follower of his. In 1940, Tesla composed a treatise entitled "The Art of Projecting Concentrated Non-dispersive Energy through the Natural Media." Tesla tried to explain that there was "a difference between the apparatus I have described as the ray of death and the invention I have described as the peace ray. The ray of death is not a new invention but a development of an apparatus I constructed many years ago. It is a beautiful apparatus, but a terrible weapon. Before the present war began, I approached the United States Government, suggesting that this apparatus be used against the invading army of Germany. The suggestion fell on deaf ears, though I gave the matter thorough consideration. The [peace ray] apparatus requires much power, and I have devised a means of developing great power. The apparatus is so constructed that it is at once an offensive and defensive weapon, enabling nation to destroy any country approaching it with hostile intent by simply directing the ray to the enemy's capital, thereby rendering him impotent before invading his territory. This is not a dream. It is a simple feat of scientific electrical engineering, only expensive blind, faint-hearted, doubting world. Humanity is not yet sufficiently advanced to be willingly led by the discoverer's keen searching sense. But who knows? Perhaps it is better in this present world of ours that a revolutionary idea or invention instead of being helped and patted, be hampered and ill-treated in its adolescence by want of means, by selfish interest, pedantry, stupidity and ignorance; that it be attacked and stifled; that it pass through bitter trials and tribulations, through the strife of commercial existence. So the idea matures. It is thus that all great discoveries are made, by trials, error, perseverance. When you look at the power and potential of Tesla's invention, it is easy to see why governments would want to keep it under wraps. Tesla's "Teleforce" weapon was based on a channeling of radiant energy which Tesla said could be used for either good or evil purposes. Tesla claimed he had developed a weapon of tremendous destructive power that could be used against aircraft or ground forces. He later changed his description of the weapon to a more peaceful one. But one of the many mysteries surrounding Tesla and his ideas, is what did Tesla mean when he said he had discovered a new energy source that was of tremendous power? Tesla said he was a "blasted by cosmic rays" and from this he had developed a new form of energy. Tesla discovered that when he was exposed to these cosmic rays he was able to develop what he called "a new kind of matter." Tesla's notes indicate that this new form of matter could be used to produce "free energy" or energy that could be used to "destroy the earth." Tesla believed he had tapped into a new and unknown energy source. One that was not only revolutionary in its ability to provide free and clean energy, but also in its power to destroy. Tesla's idea that he had discovered a new source of energy was met with ridicule and scepticism. Many scientists and theorists have tried to unravel Tesla's mysterious claims. While Tesla's secrets died with him, some theorists believe that Tesla had discovered a new way to harness the energy of the sun. If Tesla had discovered a way to harness the energy of the sun, it would explain the comments that he had "obtained new principles of power and motion" and that he had discovered a new and "more powerful" source of energy. Tesla claimed his greatest contribution was in the discovery of a new source of energy. He called this free energy.
text: The Van de Graaff generator was a directed-energy device developed in the 1930s by German-born, American-born scientist, inventor, and futurist, Nikola Tesla.

original_text: As in the House of Commons, a number of qualifications apply to being an MSP. Such qualifications were introduced under the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Act 1981. Specifically, members must be over the age of 18 and must be a citizen of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, one of the countries in the Commonwealth of Nations, a citizen of a British overseas territory, or a European Union citizen resident in the UK. Members of the police and the armed forces are disqualified from sitting in the Scottish Parliament as elected MSPs, and similarly, civil servants and members of foreign legislatures are disqualified. An individual may not sit in the Scottish Parliament if he or she is judged to be insane under the terms of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003.

original_text: Some chloroplasts contain a structure called the chloroplast peripheral reticulum. It is often found in the chloroplasts of C4 plants, though it has also been found in some C3 angiosperms, and even some gymnosperms. The chloroplast peripheral reticulum consists of a maze of membranous tubes and vesicles continuous with the inner chloroplast membrane that extends into the internal stromal fluid of the chloroplast. Its purpose is thought to be to increase the chloroplast's surface area for cross-membrane transport between its stroma and the cell cytoplasm. The small vesicles sometimes observed may serve as transport vesicles to shuttle stuff between the thylakoids and intermembrane space.

original_text: The VA Theatre Performance galleries, formerly the Theatre Museum, opened in March 2009. The collections are stored by the VA, and are available for research, exhibitions and other shows. They hold the UK's biggest national collection of material about live performance in the UK since Shakespeare's day, covering drama, dance, musical theatre, circus, music hall, rock and pop, and most other forms of live entertainment. Types of items displayed include costumes, set models, wigs, prompt books, and posters.

They hold the UK's biggest national collection of material about live performance in the UK since Shakespeare's day, covering drama, dance, musical theatre, circus, music hall, rock and pop, and most other forms of live entertainment. Types of items displayed include costumes, set models, wigs, prompt books, and posters.

original_text: Some theories of civil disobedience hold that civil disobedience is only justified against governmental entities. Brownlee argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of non-governmental agencies such as trade unions and religious organizations is also justified if the organization's decision would be unjust. While I'm sympathetic to her general line of reasoning, I find that Brownlee's argument is not wholly persuasive. The central question that motivates Brownlee's argument is: Is it ever justified to disobey a decision that has been made by a group one belongs to? That is, if I belong to a group that has made a decision, is it ever justified for me to disobey the decision? According to Brownlee, there are three possible answers to this question: (1) All disobedience in this context is justified, (2) no disobedience is justified, or (3) some disobedience is justified. Brownlee argues that the third answer is the correct one and that it has important implications for theories of civil disobedience. To make her case, Brownlee presents two puzzles. The first puzzle is what she calls the "Group Obedience Puzzle." In this puzzle, a group, G, makes a decision, D, which an individual, I, thinks is unjust. In order to resolve the puzzle, we must determine whether I ought to obey the decision that the group made. According to Brownlee, the intuitive answer to this puzzle is that I ought to disobey D. This is because, according to Brownlee, we think that it is morally permissible to disobey decisions made by groups of which we are a member. Yet, Brownlee claims, this intuitive answer leads to the problem that I would also have to disobey D1, a decision made by the group that has the same content as D but is made by a different group, G1. This is problematic because it leads to a contradiction: If I ought to obey D1, then I ought to obey D because it has the same content as D1. But if I ought to obey D1, then I ought to obey D. And, since I ought not to obey D, the contradiction leads us to conclude that I ought to obey D1. However, this is also problematic, since the intuitive answer to the puzzle was that I ought to disobey D. The second puzzle is what she calls the "Individual Obedience Puzzle." In this puzzle, a group, G, makes a decision, D, which an individual, I, thinks is unjust. However, in this puzzle, it is not the case that I is a member of G. According to Brownlee, the intuitive answer to this puzzle is that I ought not to disobey D. However, this answer leads to the problem that I would also have to obey D1, a decision made by the group that has the same content as D but is made by a different group, G1. This is problematic because it leads to a contradiction: If I ought to obey D, then I ought to obey D1. But if I ought to obey D, then I ought not to obey D1. And, since I ought to obey D1, the contradiction leads us to conclude that I ought not to obey D. However, this is also problematic, since the intuitive answer to the puzzle was that I ought not to disobey D. Brownlee argues that, in order to resolve these puzzles, we must either reject the intuition that it is morally permissible to disobey a decision made by a group of which we are a member, or we must reject the intuition that it is morally impermissible to disobey a decision made by a group of which we are not a member. Brownlee argues that the former view is too restrictive, so she adopts the latter. According to Brownlee, it is justified to disobey a decision made by a group of which one is a member if the decision is unjust. However, it is not justified to disobey a decision made by a group of which one is not a member. On this view, both the Group Obedience Puzzle and the Individual Obedience Puzzle have a solution. Brownlee has an interesting argument to justify her conclusion about the Individual Obedience Puzzle. In the Individual Obedience Puzzle, Brownlee claims, there is no reason to treat the individual any different than the group. Therefore, Brownlee claims, it is justified for the group to disobey the decision.
text: In our series of letters from African-American journalists, film-maker and columnist Tavis Smiley looks at a new theory of civil disobedience that argues that disobedience in opposition to government decisions is justified.

original_text: QuickBooks sponsored a "Small Business Big Game" contest, in which Death Wish Coffee had a 30-second commercial aired free of charge courtesy of QuickBooks. Death Wish Coffee beat out nine other finalists, including a food truck and a mobile gym. For the past four years, the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) has been conducting a survey of small business owners. This year's survey, conducted in November, asked 831 small business owners to identify the single most important issue facing them. The survey did not ask about a laundry list of issues, only the single most important issue. Given the ongoing partisan politics surrounding the Affordable Care Act (ACA), one might have expected that a healthy majority of small business owners would have pointed to the healthcare law as their most pressing issue. That was not the case. "The Affordable Care Act ranked as the most important issue for only 10 percent of the small business owners surveyed," said NFIB President Dan Danner. "That was the lowest percentage in the past four years, and the percentage continues to decrease." In fact, the top most important issue identified in the survey was the need for more qualified workers. Twenty-eight percent of small business owners surveyed pointed to this as the most pressing issue. "It is the highest percentage for this issue in the history of the survey," said Danner. "For the past 30 years, the NFIB has been surveying small business owners, and this was the first time that the need for qualified workers ranked as the number one most important issue. It's also notable that the need for qualified workers was the top issue among all age groups of small business owners." The second-most important issue identified was the economy and jobs. Nineteen percent of small business owners selected this as their top issue. Other issues were immigration (4 percent), taxes (10 percent), government regulations (10 percent), healthcare (10 percent), and high taxes (8 percent). "When asked about what specific policies they would like to see implemented by Congress, small business owners overwhelmingly said they want Congress to pass legislation that would spur economic growth," said Danner. "Specifically, they pointed to tax reform and regulatory relief as the best ways to help the economy grow." Danner also noted that 63 percent of small business owners surveyed believe the economy is on the wrong track. "Without question, small business owners are very concerned about the future of the economy," he said. "Their concerns are not simply about their own business. They're concerned about the overall health of the economy and the impact that will have on their employees, their communities, and their nation. Small business owners are very thoughtful about the future and are making plans for how to keep their businesses viable for years to come. They're concerned about the future of their employees, their communities, and the nation." Bill Brunelle, an owner of Old Town Canoe in Old Town, Maine, says he is concerned about the future of the economy and the impact that will have on his employees, his community, and the nation. "I'm worried about the economy and I don't think Washington is doing anything to address that," he said. "I think they're out of touch. I'm worried about people's jobs. When the economy is bad, we have fewer customers, which means we have less money to put back into the community." Brunelle says he also has concerns about the Affordable Care Act. "The Affordable Care Act is causing us to offer fewer benefits, which is causing us to lose good people. We can't keep them because we can't afford to provide the benefits they want." Bill Berkheimer, owner of Bills Bike and Run in Roanoke, Virginia, says he is also worried about the economy. "The economy is not good right now," he says. "The Affordable Care Act is affecting me as well. The cost of healthcare is rising, which affects me because I have to pay for it. I'm also seeing a big jump in payroll taxes, which is also affecting me." However, Berkheimer says that, despite the economy and the Affordable Care Act, his business is doing well. original_text: During the mass high school education movement from , there was an increase in skilled workers, which led to a decrease in the price of skilled labor. High school education during the period was designed to equip students with necessary skill sets to be able to perform at work. In fact, it differs from the present high school education, which is regarded as a stepping-stone to acquire college and advanced degrees. This decrease in wages caused a period of compression and decreased inequality between skilled and unskilled workers. Education is very important for the growth of the economy, however educational inequality in gender also influence towards the economy. Lagerlof and Galor stated that gender inequality in education can result to low economic growth, and continued gender inequality in education, thus creating a poverty trap. It is suggested that a large gap in male and female education may indicate backwardness and so may be associated with lower economic growth, which can explain why there is economic inequality between countries.

original_text: Another of the Egyptian groups which employed violence in their struggle for Islamic order was al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya (Islamic Group). Victims of their campaign against the Egyptian state in the 1990s included the head of the counter-terrorism police (Major General Raouf Khayrat), a parliamentary speaker (Rifaat al-Mahgoub), dozens of European tourists and Egyptian bystanders, and over 100 Egyptian police. Ultimately the campaign to overthrow the government was unsuccessful, and the major jihadi group, Jamaa Islamiya (or al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya), renounced violence in 2003. Other lesser known groups include the Islamic Liberation Party, Salvation from Hell and Takfir wal-Hijra, and these groups have variously been involved in activities such as attempted assassinations of political figures, arson of video shops and attempted takeovers of government buildings.

original_text: The 2010 United States Census reported that Fresno had a population of 494,665. The population density was 4,404.5 people per square mile (1,700.6km2). The racial makeup of Fresno was 245,306 (49.6) White, 40,960 (8.3) African American, 8,525 (1.7) Native American, 63,403 (12.8) Asian (3.6 Hmong, 2.7 Filipino, 2.1 Laotian, 1.2 Asian Indian, 1.2 Chinese, 1.2 Cambodian, 1.0 Vietnamese, 1.0 Korean, 0.7 Thai, 0.4 Pakistani, 0.4 Japanese, 0.2 Burmese), 8,276 (1.7) Pacific Islander, 93,557 (18.9) from other races, and 27,218 (5.5) from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 190,554 persons (38.5). 29.0 of Fresno's population is of Mexican origin; 0.7 Salvadoran, 0.5 Guatemalan, 0.5 Honduran, 0.4 Puerto Rican, 0.2 Nicaraguan, and 0.2 Cuban. Non-Hispanic Whites were 32.8 of the population in 2010, down from 72.6 in 1970. The census reported that 480,930 people (97.3 of the population) lived in households, 3,216 (0.6) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 10,520 (2.1) were institutionalized. The population was spread out with 140,081 people (28.4) under the age of 18, 64,798 people (13.1) aged 18 to 24, 140,230 people (28.5) aged 25 to 44, 104,968 people (21.2) aged 45 to 64, and 44,688 people (9.0) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30.4 years. For every 100 females there were 96.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.6 males. There were 168,807 housing units at an average density of 1,546.8 per square mile (597.2km), of which 86,272 (46.3) were owner-occupied, and 98,982 (53.7) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 3.2; the rental vacancy rate was 8.2. 264,554 people (53.4 of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 216,376 people (43.9) lived in rental housing units.

original_text: Many types of Turing machines are used to define complexity classes, such as deterministic Turing machines, probabilistic Turing machines, non-deterministic Turing machines, quantum Turing machines, symmetric Turing machines and alternating Turing machines. Turing machines are a mathematical model of computation that defines an abstract machine which manipulates symbols on a strip of tape according to a table of rules. Despite the model's simplicity, given any computer algorithm, a Turing machine capable of simulating that algorithm's logic can be constructed. The machine operates on an infinite memory tape divided into discrete cells. The machine positions its readwrite head over a particular cell of the tape and "reads" (scans) the symbol in that cell, then, based on the symbol and its internal state, the machine performs an action: either erasing the symbol and writing a new one, or moving the tape one cell to the left or right. The new state is thus calculated by a table of rules, or by a function (q, a), where q is the machine's state and a is the symbol being observed. The Turing machine is said to "accept" or "reject" the "input" (the entire tape contents at the start of the computation) when it halts. The Turing machine is a general purpose model of a CPU. A Turing machine is an abstract machine similar to a computer. A Turing machine can do anything that a real computer can do and is the basis for the Church-Turing thesis, which says that this is true of anything capable of computation. A Turing machine consists of a head, which can read and write symbols on a tape. A Turing machine has a state, and the state is changed after it reads a symbol and it does some computation based on the symbol and its current state. During each computation cycle, the machine is in a particular state and can move in a particular direction. The machine reads a symbol from the tape. The machine then performs an action determined by its state and the symbol. The machine then writes a new symbol and moves left or right. The machine starts in a certain state, called the start state. If the machine reaches an accept state, it is said to accept the input, and the computation halts. Otherwise, the computation never halts. The Turing machine accepts the input if it ever halts in an accept state. A Turing machine can be constructed from any set of rules. These rules are like a computer program. The rules are applied to the current state and symbol to compute the next state. The machine starts in a start state and halts when it reaches an accept state. The input is said to be accepted if the machine ever halts in an accept state. original_text: In 1939 Chinese Nationalist soldiers took the mausoleum from its position at the'Lord's Enclosure' (Mongolian: Edsen Khoroo) in Mongolia to protect it from Japanese troops. It was taken through Communist-held territory in the Soviet Union to Xinjiang in western China where it was kept in a temple in Kulja (now Yining) for thirteen years. After the Communist takeover of China in 1949, the mausoleum was moved to Beijing. In 1954, after the 14th Dalai Lama had arrived in Beijing, a joint committee of Chinese and Mongolian officials decided that the body would be reburied in the city of Xilin Hot in Inner Mongolia, where it was interred in 1955. In 1956, the tomb was opened, the coffin was photographed, and the mummy was examined by a Chinese medical team who proclaimed that Genghis Khan had died of a wound to the head. The body was reburied with a monument raised over it. In 1960, a granite memorial was erected over the mausoleum. In 1976, the memorial was transformed into a museum. In 1982, the corpse was taken to Ulaanbaatar, where it was examined by North Korean forensic specialists, who confirmed that Genghis Khan's cause of death was head trauma. Afterwards, the body was returned to the mausoleum. In 1995, the mausoleum was renovated and the museum was reopened. In 2004, the mausoleum was moved to Ordos City, where it was reopened to the public on 18 August 2005.
text: The mausoleum of Genghis Khan is one of the most important sites in China, and is the resting place of some of the country's most famous people, including Mao Zedong.

original_text: The Harvard Crimson competes in 42 intercollegiate sports in the NCAA Division I Ivy League. Harvard has an intense athletic rivalry with Yale University culminating in The Game, although the Harvard-Yale Regatta predates the football game. This rivalry is put aside every two years when the Harvard and Yale Track and Field teams come together to compete against a combined Oxford University and Cambridge University team, a competition that is the oldest continuous international amateur competition in the world. Harvard's athletic rivalry with Yale is strongest in football. The two compete annually in The Game, while Harvard also plays Yale in the first rugby varsity match of the season. This rivalry extends to the two universities' athletic supporters. Alumni of both Harvard and Yale came together to found the first college alumni organization in the United States. The Harvard Crimson men's ice hockey team won the school's first NCAA Championship in any sport in 1989. Harvard was also the first Ivy League institution to win a NCAA championship title in a women's sport when its women's lacrosse team won the NCAA Championship in 1990. Harvard Undergraduate Television has footage from historical games and athletic events including the 2005 pep-rally before the Harvard-Yale Game.

original_text: The IPCC process on climate change and its efficiency and success has been compared with dealings with other environmental challenges (compare Ozone depletion and global warming). In case of the Ozone depletion global regulation based on the Montreal Protocol has been successful, in case of Climate Change, the Kyoto Protocol failed. The Ozone case was used to assess the efficiency of the IPCC process. The lockstep situation of the IPCC is having built a broad science consensus while states and governments still follow different, if not opposing goals. The underlying linear model of policy-making of more knowledge we have, the better the political response will be is being doubted.

original_text: The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. While an MSP is allowed a free vote on matters of conscience, such as abortion, most issues are not considered matters of conscience. Votes on the Scottish Government's budget are normally subject to a party whip. The Presiding Officer has no vote, but may exercise a casting vote. He or she uses this power only to ensure that, if a vote is tied, further debate on the subject takes place. Find out how MSPs vote How do I find out how MSPs voted? All votes taken by the Scottish Parliament are recorded in the Official Report. These records are available from the Scottish Parliament's website. Who do I contact if I want to find out more about how MSPs vote? You can contact the Scottish Parliament Information Centre (SPICe) for more information about how MSPs vote. Telephone: (local rate call) Email: SPICe Website:
text: MSPs vote in the Scottish Parliament on a range of issues, from the budget to the Queen's Speech, and on matters of conscience.

original_text: The main response of the immune system to tumors is to destroy the abnormal cells using killer T cells, sometimes with the assistance of helper T cells. Tumor antigens are molecules on the surface of tumor cells, such as proteins, that are recognized by the immune system. The problem is that tumors have ways to escape the immune system: Tumor cells can shut off expression of their antigens. Tumor cells can express proteins that prevent them from being recognized by the immune system. Tumor cells can turn off receptors that are required for the tumor cells to be recognized and killed by the immune system. Tumor cells can produce proteins that block the action of the immune system. Tumor cells can change their location to avoid the immune system. Tumor cells can send out chemical signals that prevent the immune system from getting to the tumor. Tumor cells can make substances that turn off the immune system. Tumor cells can spread to areas of the body where the immune system cannot get to them. Tumor cells can be present in small numbers and are not recognized by the immune system. Tumor cells can stimulate the immune system to kill healthy cells. Understanding how tumors are able to escape the immune system has led to the development of ways to make the immune system recognize tumors. This is known as immunotherapy. There are several different types of immunotherapy: Immunostimulants: These drugs stimulate the immune system so that it can recognize and destroy cancer cells. Immune modulators: These drugs change the way the immune system functions so that it can recognize and destroy cancer cells. Adoptive immunotherapy: The body's own immune system is trained to recognize and kill cancer cells. Cancer vaccines: These are substances that stimulate the immune system to destroy cancer cells. Immune checkpoint inhibitors: These drugs interfere with the abnormal ways that tumors turn off the immune system. Monoclonal antibodies: These drugs are proteins that recognize and bind to cancer cells. Once the antibody binds to the cancer cell, it can be destroyed by other parts of the immune system. Following treatment with immunotherapy, patients are followed closely for side effects of the therapy. Many of these drugs can cause a variety of side effects, including: Severe skin problems Inflammation of the brain, spinal cord, nerves, muscles, and joints Kidney problems including kidney failure The immune system may also attack healthy tissue, leading to a variety of other problems, including: Inflammation in the lungs, skin, joints, and intestinal tract Abnormal hormone production It is important to know that immunotherapy can cause severe side effects, including death. Patients with cancer who are being treated with immunotherapy are encouraged to contact their healthcare provider if they develop any side effects that they do not think are normal.

original_text: Deke Slayton, the grounded Mercury astronaut who became Director of Flight Crew Operations for the Gemini and Apollo programs, selected the first Apollo crew in January 1966, with Grissom as commander, Chaffee as senior pilot and White as pilot. They were known as the prime crew. The backup crew was selected in March 1966. They were veteran astronauts McDivitt, Scott and Schweickart. Slayton and NASA's Head of Flight Operations, Chris Kraft, named a support crew to provide assistance to the prime and backup crews. They were veteran astronauts Young and Cunningham, with rookie astronaut Schirra. The prime crew's first assignment was to test the Apollo command module's systems in Earth orbit to ensure they were suitable for a moon mission. The backup crew's first assignment was to test Apollo's lunar module systems in Earth orbit to ensure they were suitable for a moon mission. The support crew's first assignment was to test Apollo's service module systems in Earth orbit to ensure they were suitable for a moon mission. On 27 January 1967, Grissom, White and Chaffee climbed aboard Apollo 1 for a routine test at the Cape. The crew were suited up and seated in the command module. The hatch was shut and locked and the test began. At 6.31pm, the test was suddenly terminated. Grissom reported a fire inside the spacecraft. A minute later, there was an explosion. Grissom, White and Chaffee were unable to get out. The astronauts were asphyxiated by the flames. They died of heart attacks, but their death certificates all read: "Major Charles A. L. Grissom, Lieutenant Colonel Edward H. White, and Lieutenant Commander Roger B. Chaffee died as a result of asphyxiation, due to fire." The fire was caused by a faulty electrical wire in the Apollo command module. Apollo 1 was the first of NASA's manned spaceflight programs to suffer a fatal accident. The astronauts' deaths were a major setback for NASA. The Apollo program was delayed by more than a year. Apollo 1 was redesigned and renamed Apollo 204. Apollo 204 was also used as a test flight. Apollo 204 was a success, but the crew was killed when they were flying back to base. NASA launched Apollo 7 on 11 October 1968. Apollo 7 was the first manned Apollo mission. It flew in Earth orbit for eleven days. Apollo 7 was the first time astronauts flew the command module in space. Slayton and NASA's Head of Flight Operations, Chris Kraft, named a support crew to provide assistance to the prime and backup crews. They were veteran astronauts Young and Cunningham, with rookie astronaut Schirra. The prime crew's first assignment was to test the Apollo command module's systems in Earth orbit to ensure they were suitable for a moon mission. The backup crew's first assignment was to test Apollo's lunar module systems in Earth orbit to ensure they were suitable for a moon mission. The hatch was shut and locked and the test began. At 6.31pm, the test was suddenly terminated. Grissom reported a fire inside the spacecraft. A minute later, there was an explosion. Grissom, White and Chaffee were unable to get out. The astronauts were asphyxiated by the flames. They died of heart attacks, but their death certificates all read: "Major Charles A. L. Grissom, Lieutenant Colonel Edward H. White, and Lieutenant Commander Roger B. Chaffee died as a result of asphyxiation, due to fire." The fire was caused by a faulty electrical wire in the Apollo command module. Apollo 1 was the first of NASA's manned spaceflight programs to suffer a fatal accident. original_text: The game's media day, which was typically held on the Tuesday afternoon prior to the game, was moved to the Monday evening and re-branded as Super Bowl Opening Night. The changes were made to allow players to spend more time with family before the game, while increasing media availability for the week leading up to the game. The Patriots are the only franchise in the NFL with six Super Bowl appearances since 2001, winning four of them. The Falcons, meanwhile, had only made two Super Bowl appearances in their history, with the most recent coming in 1999. After the Patriots and Falcons won their respective conference championships, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that some Falcons players were not interested in the traditional media day for the Super Bowl due to the "media circus" that accompanies it. NFL spokesman Brian McCarthy dismissed the idea, saying "We are not considering any changes to the media day format or venue." However, the NFL later announced that the event would be held in Houston, Texas, at the George R. Brown Convention Center the day after the conference championship games. The event was rebranded as "Super Bowl Opening Night," and was moved from the traditional Monday evening to the evening of the previous day. The Patriots became the first team in NFL history to win a Super Bowl after overcoming a deficit of at least 16 points in the third quarter (they were down 28-3 with 2:06 left in the third quarter), and the first team to overcome more than a 10-point deficit in the third quarter. The comeback was the largest comeback in the Super Bowl, and the third largest deficit overcome in the history of the NFL playoffs, after the 1950 NFL Championship Game and the 1993 AFC Wild Card Game. The Patriots are the first team since the 1980 Raiders to win a Super Bowl without having any players elected to the Associated Press All-Pro Team. The Patriots were the first team to overcome a deficit of 17 points to win the Super Bowl, and the first team to win the Super Bowl after trailing at halftime since the 1992 Dallas Cowboys. The Patriots and the Falcons made this the first Super Bowl to feature two teams that had never met in a regular season game. This was the first Super Bowl since Super Bowl X to not have a player named as MVP from the losing team. This was the first Super Bowl since Super Bowl XXXIX in which neither starting quarterback was named MVP. Patriots head coach Bill Belichick became the first coach to win five Super Bowls. He also tied Tom Landry and Curly Lambeau for the most NFL championships won by a coach with six. Belichick also tied Chuck Noll for the most Super Bowl wins by a head coach with five. This was the first Super Bowl to be a rematch of a previous Super Bowl (XI, XIII, XVII, XXVII, and XLVII). This was the first Super Bowl in which both teams entered the game undefeated since Super Bowl XXXV in 2001. Atlanta became the second city to host the Super Bowl at two different stadiums, after the Los Angeles metropolitan area. Atlanta became the fourth city to host the Super Bowl at two different stadiums, after the New York metropolitan area, the Los Angeles metropolitan area, and the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area. The Super Bowl is traditionally held the first Sunday in February. However, in 2017, Super Bowl LI was played on February 5, because February 1 and 2 fell on a Sunday and Monday respectively. In addition, Super Bowl LII was moved to February 4, 2018, due to the 2018 Winter Olympics being held in Pyeongchang, South Korea, from February 9 to 25, 2018. Super Bowl LIII was then moved to February 3, 2019, in order to ensure a full week between the game and the opening ceremonies of the 2019 Winter Olympics, which will take place on February 8, 2019. The NFL also chose to move Super Bowl LIV to February 2, 2020, in order to ensure a full week between the game and the opening ceremonies of the 2020 Summer Olympics, which will take place on July 24, 2020. As this was the 51st Super Bowl, the Roman numerals "LI
text: The New England Patriots beat the Atlanta Falcons 34-28 in Super Bowl LI on Sunday night, winning the NFL's biggest game for the sixth time in their history.

original_text: An early important political response to the opening of hostilities was the convening of the Albany Congress in June and July, 1754. The goal of the congress was to formalize a unified front in trade and negotiations with various Indians, since allegiance of the various tribes and nations was seen to be pivotal in the success in the war that was unfolding. The plan that the delegates agreed to was never ratified by the colonial legislatures nor approved of by the crown. Nevertheless, the format of the congress and many specifics of the plan became the prototype for confederation during the War of Independence.

original_text: The original logo used for the First Doctor (and briefly for the Second Doctor) was reused in a slightly modified format for the 50th anniversary special "The Day of the Doctor" during the Eleventh Doctor's run. The logo used in the television movie featuring the Eighth Doctor was an updated version of the logo used for the Third Doctor. The logo from 1973-80 was used for the Third Doctor's final season and for the majority of the Fourth Doctor's tenure. The following logo, while most associated with the Fifth Doctor, was also used for the Fourth Doctor's final season. The logo used for the Ninth Doctor was slightly edited for the Tenth Doctor, but it retained the same general appearance. The logo used for the Eleventh Doctor had the "DW" TARDIS insignia placed to the right in 2012, but the same font remained, albeit with a slight edit to the texture every episode, with the texture relating to some aspect of the story. The logo for the Twelfth Doctor had the "DW" TARDIS insignia removed and the font was subtly altered, as well as made slightly larger. As of 2014, the logo used for the Third and Eighth Doctors is the primary logo used on all media and merchandise relating to past Doctors, and the current Doctor Who logo is used for all merchandise relating to the current Doctor.

original_text: The Soulages collection of Italian and French Renaissance objects was acquired between 1859 and 1865, and includes several cassone. The John Jones Collection of French 18th-century art and furnishings was donated to the Museum in 1986. In the late 1860s and early 1870s, Charles Lang Freer assembled his collection of Italian Renaissance painting, Renaissance maiolica, and Asian ceramics. The Henry Walters Collection of paintings, sculpture, and decorative arts, including major holdings in Renaissance and Baroque bronzes, Renaissance maiolica, and Renaissance ceramics, was given to the Museum in 1931. The Museum's collection of prints and drawings was begun in 1937 with gifts and purchases from Edward Perry Warren. In the 1950s, the Museum acquired the Ferdinand and Imogene Burg Collection of Renaissance enamels. In 1966, the Museum acquired the Robert and Betsy Feinberg Collection of prints, drawings, and decorative arts, including a collection of Renaissance maiolica and a complete set of Jacques de Gheyn II prints. In 2007, the Museum acquired the outstanding collection of Renaissance maiolica by Robert and Renee Hicks. This collection is one of the finest and most comprehensive outside of Italy. The gift of more than 300 pieces includes outstanding examples of maiolica from Deruta, Florence, Gubbio, Orvieto, Faenza, and Urbino. The acquisition was made possible by the generosity of Robert and Renee Hicks. The Museum's collections of Renaissance decorative arts are displayed in the galleries of Renaissance and Baroque art, as well as the galleries of European decorative arts.

original_text: Temujin began his ascent to power by offering himself as an ally (or, according to other sources, a vassal) to his father's anda (sworn brother or blood brother) Toghrul, who was Khan of the Keraites, and is better known by the Chinese title "Wang Khan," which the Jurchen Jin dynasty granted him in 1197. This relationship was first reinforced when Borte was captured by the Merkits. Temujin turned to Toghrul for support, and in response, Toghrul offered his vassal 20,000 of his Keraite warriors and suggested that he also involve his childhood friend Jamukha, who had himself become Khan (ruler) of his own tribe, the Jadaran.

original_text: The addition of new rock units, both depositionally and intrusively, often occurs during deformation. Faulting and other deformational processes result in the creation of topographic gradients, causing material on the crest of a surface to migrate up-slope, while material on the toe of a slope moves down-slope. Deformational processes which have been active within the last 100 years are known as active deformation, while processes which have been active for thousands of years are known as passive deformation. These two types of deformation may occur simultaneously in the same area of the Earth's crust. Active deformation is driven by plate tectonics. Examples of active deformation in the modern day include faulting and folding of the crust (as occurs in the Himalayas), subduction of oceanic lithosphere (as occurs at the Japan Trench), and rifting (as occurs in the East African Rift Valley). Passive deformation is driven by the weakening of the lithosphere by erosion, and isostatic uplift. The process of erosion effectively removes mass from the Earth's crust and facilitates upward movement of a particular lithospheric block, while isostatic uplift occurs when a block of the crust cools to form a rigid lithosphere. Passive deformation is a long-term process and often takes place over hundreds of millions of years. This movement occurs through the process of plate tectonics. The crust and upper mantle are collectively known as the lithosphere, and together with the asthenosphere, form the lithosphere-asthenosphere system (LAS). Plate tectonics is driven by the motion of the lithosphere in response to convection currents in the asthenosphere. The lithosphere is a strong, rigid outer layer of the Earth, and is divided into the seven major and many minor plates. These plates move relative to each other, with a maximum speed of 15 cmyr at the Mid-Atlantic ridge. Movement of the plates is driven by convection currents in the asthenosphere, which can be compared to a boiling pot of water. The rigid lithosphere is pushed along by the convection currents in the asthenosphere, which is a weaker part of the upper mantle. Convection currents occur within the asthenosphere when temperature differentials within the asthenosphere cause hot material to move upwards towards the surface, and colder material to sink downwards towards the Earth's core. The boundaries between the plates are known as plate margins, and along these margins, the relative movement of the plates results in deformation. In general, a plate margin may be classified as convergent, divergent, or transform. Convergent margins occur when two plates are pushed towards each other. text: Deformation is the movement of material from one part of the Earth's crust to another, either by itself or as a result of movement of tectonic plates.

Luther wrote these hymns for use in the worship services of the new church. He thought of hymns as a way to teach the laity the faith and to encourage their participation in the liturgy. His hymns were direct, simple and accessible to the people. Luther insisted that the hymns be written in the vernacular and set to simple tunes that would be easy to sing. original_text: The Saturn IB was an upgraded version of the Saturn I. The S-IB first stage increased the thrust to 1,600,000 pounds-force (7,120 kN), and the second stage replaced the S-IV with the S-IVB, with a single J-2 engine. Development of the Saturn IB began in January 1962, and the first flight took place on February 26, 1966. The Saturn IB was used for three types of missions: Earth orbital missions, such as launching the Skylab space station; Lunar orbit missions, such as launching Apollo astronauts; and Lunar landing missions, such as launching Apollo astronauts, and landing them on the Moon. The Saturn IB was also planned to be used for the canceled Apollo Applications Program.
text: The Saturn IB was the second American spaceplane to be launched after the Mercury and Apollo spacecraft of the 1950s and 1960s. TheSaturn IB was used for three types of missions, such as launching the Skylab space station, Lunar orbit missions, including launching Apollo astronauts, and landing them on the Moon.

original_text: In World War II, Charles de Gaulle and the Free French used the overseas colonies as bases from which they fought to liberate France. However after 1945 anti-colonial movements began to challenge the Empire. France fought and lost a bitter war in Vietnam in the 1950s. Whereas they won the war in Algeria, the French leader at the time, Charles de Gaulle, decided to grant Algeria independence anyway in 1962. Its settlers and many local supporters relocated to France. Nearly all of France's colonies gained independence by 1960, but France retained great financial and diplomatic influence. It has repeatedly sent troops to assist its former colonies in Africa in suppressing insurrections and coups d'etat.

original_text: The English name "Normans" comes from the French words NormansNormanz, plural of Normant, modern French normand, which is itself borrowed from Old Low Franconian Nortmann "Northman" or directly from Old Norse Nordmadr, Latinized variously as Nortmannus, Normannus, or Nordmannus (recorded in Medieval Latin, 9th century) to mean "Norseman, Viking."
