original_text: In July 1968, ABC Radio launched a special programming project for its FM stations, which was spearheaded by Allen Shaw, a former program manager at WCFL in Chicago who was the consultant for ABC Radio. The project, called 'Stars of the Future', would allow ABC's FM stations to discover and play new, local artists in hopes that their records would become hits and break nationally. The project also allowed stations to showcase their own talents as music directors and program managers. The project was scheduled to last two months and the ABC network promised to pick a hit out of the program for nationwide play. The first week of the project had the ABC FM stations focus on the work of a single artist. The second week would feature work of two artists. The third week would feature an artist from each of the ABC FM stations, and the fourth week would include artists from the first three weeks. The fourth week in August featured the work of John B. Sebastian, 'King Bee' by the Doors, 'Walking the Dog' by Rufus Thomas, and 'The Way You Do the Things You Do' by the Temptations. In September, ABC-FM began using the project to determine which of the newly discovered artists would be featured in a monthly series of albums. The albums would be distributed by ABC-Dunhill Records. Artists who were featured in the album series included: Sweetwater, Rare Earth, Ted Nugent and the Amboy Dukes, and Pure Food Drug Act. In October, ABC announced that 'Stars of the Future' was one of the most successful and profitable promotion campaigns in the company's history. ABC's FM stations began playing cuts from the 'Stars of the Future' album series and they became the first FM station to use a computer to rate records. The success of 'Stars of the Future' led to a number of follow-up projects, including the 'Superstars of the Future' album series and 'Stars of the Future II' project. The 'Superstars of the Future' album series featured artists who were already stars on the ABC-FM stations and were expected to be hits nationally. Artists included: Eric Clapton, Janis Joplin, the Moody Blues, and Cream. The 'Stars of the Future II' project in 1970 focused on new artists, and included artists such as: Stevie Wonder, the Carpenters, the Isley Brothers, and B.B. King. The 'Stars of the Future' project did not have much of an impact on the national Top 40 charts, but it did have an influence on the Billboard Easy Listening chart. In the mid-1970s, the Easy Listening chart was being heavily influenced by easy rock artists like Bread, America, and Seals Crofts. When many of these artists started to crossover into the Top 40 and Hot 100 charts, many radio stations dropped their Easy Listening formats. In 1977, the Billboard Easy Listening chart was expanded to include pop and rock artists as well as easy listening artists. In 1978, the Easy Listening chart was renamed 'Adult Contemporary' and it was expanded to include any record that received spins on the AC chart. By the 1980s, the AC chart became one of the most successful charts at Billboard and it continues to have a major impact on the music industry.
text: Fifty years ago this month, ABC-FM listeners in the Quad-Cities were treated to the first of a series of albums by some of the most popular artists of the time.

original_text: The objective is typically a course of study, lesson plan, or a practical skill. A teacher may follow standardized curricula as determined by the relevant authority. The teacher may interact with students of different ages, from infants to adults, students with different abilities and students with learning disabilities. A teacher may also work with students from the general publiccommunity or inmates. A teacher may teach in a traditional setting, like a classroom with whiteboards and textbooks, or may teach in an online setting. An online teacher may conduct classes over the internet using a webcam, microphone, and educational software. Teachers work in public and private schools, religious and secular schools, as well as institutions of higher learning, such as colleges and universities. They may also work in other settings, such as museums, libraries, and hospitals. Elementary school teachers typically work during school hours when students are present and for professional development sessions, parent meetings, and other requirements. This may require working a half day on Saturdays or on short-term assignments during the summer. The median annual wage for postsecondary teachers was 72,470 in May 2015. In 2015, 50 of postsecondary teachers worked part-time. Teachers in general and postsecondary teachers in particular generally work during school hours. However, they may also work evenings and weekends grading papers and preparing lessons. Postsecondary teachers who work for 4-year colleges and universities typically need a doctoral degree in their field. Some schools may hire those with a master's degree. Some fields offer alternative certifications or licensing programs for people with degrees in the liberal arts or sciences who do not have training in education. These programs typically cover teaching methods and child development. Communication skills. Teachers must collaborate with other teachers and special education teachers. In addition, they need to discuss students' needs with parents and administrators. Patience. Working with students of different abilities and backgrounds can be difficult. Teachers must be patient when students struggle with material. Resourcefulness. Teachers need to be able to come up with different ways to present information and to adapt lessons to each student's learning style.
text: A teacher is a person who teaches a subject to a group of students in a school, college, university, or other educational setting for a set period of time or a set amount of time.

original_text: In Afghanistan, the mujahideen's victory against the Soviet Union in the 1980s did not lead to justice and prosperity, due to a vicious and destructive civil war between political and militant factions. More than 60,000 people were killed in Kabul alone, and 25,000 houses destroyed. In the chaos, many people joined the Taliban, a radical religious movement which took power in the mid-1990s. The Taliban claimed to bring peace to the country, but many Afghans - especially women - suffered under the extreme interpretation of Islam enforced by the Taliban, who banned women from working or going to school and subjected people to severe punishments for minor crimes. Following the 11 September attacks on the US in 2001, the US and its allies invaded Afghanistan. The Taliban were toppled in less than two months, but the US-led forces then became mired in a protracted conflict with the Taliban and other armed groups. A US-led military coalition overthrew the Taliban in 2001 for harbouring al-Qaeda leader Osama Bin Laden, blamed for the attacks on New York and Washington. Some 2,300 US soldiers have been killed since the start of the Afghan operation. Since 2001, at least 21,000 civilians have been killed and 40,000 injured, mainly by insurgents, according to the UN. In 2014, Afghanistan elected a new president, Ashraf Ghani, to succeed Hamid Karzai, but the new president's authority beyond Kabul is unclear. Much of the country remains unsafe and large parts are controlled by the Taliban. The US and UK formally ended their combat operations in 2014, but thousands of troops remain in training and counter-terrorism roles. original_text: It was only the orbit of the planet Mercury that Newton's Law of Gravitation seemed not to fully explain. Some astrophysicists predicted the existence of another planet (Vulcan) that would explain the discrepancies; however, despite some early indications, no such planet could be found. When Albert Einstein formulated his theory of general relativity (GR) he turned his attention to the problem of Mercury's orbit and found that his theory added a correction, which could account for the discrepancy. This was the first time that Newton's Theory of Gravity had been shown to be less correct than an alternative.

original_text: The energy crisis led to greater interest in renewable energy, nuclear power and domestic fossil fuels. There is criticism that American energy policies since the crisis have been dominated by crisis-mentality thinking, promoting expensive quick fixes and single-shot solutions that ignore market and technology realities. Instead of providing stable rules that support basic research while leaving plenty of scope for entrepreneurship and innovation, congresses and presidents have repeatedly backed policies which promise solutions that are politically expedient, but whose prospects are doubtful.

original_text: The election produced a majority SNP government, making this the first time in the Scottish Parliament where a party has commanded a parliamentary majority. The SNP took 16 seats from Labour, with many of their key figures not returned to parliament, although Labour leader Iain Gray retained East Lothian by 151 votes. The SNP took a further eight seats from the Liberal Democrats and one seat from the Conservatives. The SNP overall majority meant that there was sufficient support in the Scottish Parliament to hold a referendum on Scottish independence.

original_text: The chloroplasts of plant and algal cells can orient themselves to best suit the available light. In low-light conditions, they will spread out in a sheet - maximizing the surface area to absorb light. Under intense light, they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on. This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage. This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones. Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated stimulus-response systems that can be found in plants. Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move.

original_text: BSkyB utilises the VideoGuard pay-TV scrambling system owned by NDS, a Cisco Systems company. There are tight controls over use of VideoGuard decoders; they are not available as stand-alone DVB CAMs (conditional-access modules). BSkyB has design authority over all digital satellite receivers capable of receiving their service. The receivers, though designed and built by different manufacturers, must conform to the same user interface look-and-feel as all the others. This extends to the Personal video recorder (PVR) offering (branded Sky).

original_text: The physicians of the Yuan court came from diverse cultures. Healers were divided into non-Mongol physicians called otachi and traditional Mongol shamans. The Mongols characterized otachi doctors by their use of herbs and medicines, and shamans as those who used supernatural powers. The Yuan court recruited physicians from the West, the Middle East, India and Korea. The Chinese practiced healing methods of traditional Chinese medicine. Chinese doctors found employment as healers and advisors at the Yuan court, including Zhu Danxi, a court doctor from Nanjing. The Chinese physicians were considered to be otachi. The Mongols characterized the non-Mongol physicians as otachi, although the Mongols themselves used traditional Chinese medicine. Otachi physicians came from diverse cultures and included Muslims, Christians, and Buddhists. In 1309, the Yuan court accepted an invitation from the Persian leader Oljaitu to send an embassy to Persia to learn more about Islamic medicine. The leader of the embassy was a Muslim and an otachi physician.

original_text: Some theories of civil disobedience hold that civil disobedience is only justified against governmental entities. Brownlee argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of non-governmental agencies such as trade unions, banks, and private universities can be justified if it reflects "a larger challenge to the legal system that permits those decisions to be taken." The same principle, she argues, applies to breaches of law in protest against international organizations and foreign governments.

The same principle, she argues, applies to breaches of law in protest against international organizations and foreign governments.

original_text: In the early 1990s the memory of Genghis Khan with the Mongolian national identity has had a powerful revival partly because of his perception during the Mongolian People's Republic period. Genghis Khan became one of the central figures of the national identity. He is looked upon positively by Mongolians for his role in uniting warring tribes. For example, it is not uncommon for Mongolians to refer to their country as "Genghis Khan's Mongolia," to themselves as "Genghis Khan's children," and to Genghis Khan as the "father of the Mongols" especially among the younger generation. However, there is a chasm in the perception of his brutality. Mongolians maintain that the historical records written by non-Mongolians are unfairly biased against Genghis Khan and that his butchery is exaggerated, while his positive role is underrated.

original_text: The judicial branch of the EU has played an important role in the development of EU law, by assuming the task of interpreting the treaties, and accelerating economic and political integration. Today the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) is the main judicial body, within which there is a higher European Court of Justice (commonly abbreviated as ECJ) that deals with cases that contain more public importance, and a General Court that deals with issues of detail but without general importance. There is also a Civil Service Tribunal to deal with EU staff issues, and then a separate Court of Auditors. Under the Treaty on European Union article 19 (2) there is one judge from each member state, 28 at present, who are supposed to "possess the qualifications required for appointment to the highest judicial offices" (or for the General Court, the "ability required for appointment to high judicial office. A president is elected by the judges for three years. Under TEU article 19 (3) is to be the ultimate court to interpret questions of EU law. In fact, most EU law is applied by member state courts (the English Court of Appeal, the German Bundesgerichtshof, the Belgian Cour du travail, etc.) but they can refer questions to the EU court for a preliminary ruling. The CJEU's duty is to "ensure that in the interpretation and application of the Treaties the law is observed," although realistically it has the ability to expand and develop the law according to the principles it deems to be appropriate. Arguably this has been done through both seminal and controversial judgments, including Van Gend en Loos, Mangold v Helm, and Kadi v Commission.

original_text: One of the great treasures in the library is the Codex Forster, some of Leonardo da Vinci's note books. The Codex consists of three parchment-bound manuscripts, Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III, quite small in size, dated between 1490 and 1505. Their contents include a large collection of sketches and references to the equestrian sculpture commissioned by the Duke of Milan Ludovico Sforza to commemorate his father Francesco Sforza. These were bequeathed with over 18,000 books to the museum in 1876 by John Forster. The Reverend Alexander Dyce was another benefactor of the library, leaving over 14,000 books to the museum in 1869. Amongst the books he collected are early editions in Greek and Latin of the poets and playwrights Aeschylus, Aristotle, Homer, Livy, Ovid, Pindar, Sophocles and Virgil. More recent authors include Giovanni Boccaccio, Dante, Racine, Rabelais and Moliere.

original_text: The energy crisis led to greater interest in renewable energy, nuclear power and domestic fossil fuels. There is criticism that American energy policies since the crisis have been dominated by gas and oil companies. Crisis in the Middle East led to an oil embargo by OPEC in 1973. Gasoline rationing, even-odd rationing, long lines at gas stations, and a 55 mph (89 kmh) speed limit were enacted, while prices skyrocketed. Inflation in 1974 ran at 11.3, the highest since 1946. Unemployment reached 4.9 in May 1975, the highest since 1941. The value of the U.S. dollar declined significantly. During the 1970s, a combination of economic stagnation, growing inflation, and a growing dependence on foreign oil accompanied by the 1973 Oil Crisis and the 1979 energy crisis to cause a recession in 1974, and a longer lasting energy crisis in the late 1970s. The oil crisis of 1973 was a period when the price of oil rapidly increased in the United States. The crisis began in October 1973, when the members of OPEC refused to ship petroleum to the United States and other nations that had supported Israel in the Yom Kippur War. The embargo caused the price of oil to soar from 3 per barrel to 12 per barrel. Gasoline was in short supply and stations limited how much gas they would sell to each customer. Even though the embargo lasted only a few months, gasoline rationing remained in place until August 1974. The embargo had a significant impact on the United States and other nations. The period marked the end of economic growth that had continued since the end of World War II. The Arab-Israeli conflict has been a major obstacle to a comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace. Although peace was made between the Israelis and Egyptians, as well as Israelis and Jordanians, decades of violence between the Israelis and Palestinians continue to be a major obstacle to a comprehensive peace. There were a series of wars and conflicts, both between Israel and the Arab countries and internally within the Palestinian territories. The impact of the Arab-Israeli conflict on the Middle East region as a whole has been described as "devastating" and by some, such as Fouad Ajami as a "disaster for the Arabs." The Arab-Israeli conflict has become the world's "greatest intractable conflict." The Vietnam War was a Cold War-era proxy war that occurred in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia from December 1956 to the fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975. This war followed the First Indochina War (1946-54) and was fought between North Vietnam - supported by the Soviet Union, China and other communist allies - and the government of South Vietnam - supported by the United States and other anti-communist allies. The Viet Cong (also known as the National Liberation Front, or NLF), a lightly armed South Vietnamese communist common front directed by the North, largely fought a guerrilla war against anti-communist forces in the region. The Vietnam People's Army (North Vietnamese Army) engaged in a more conventional war, at times committing large units into battle. U.S. and South Vietnamese forces relied on air superiority and overwhelming firepower to conduct search and destroy operations, involving ground forces, artillery, and airstrikes. The Vietnam War had a lasting impact on American politics. It was the only foreign war of the United States that attracted broad social opposition during wartime. It saw widespread civil unrest, including draft card burning and massive protests in addition to the killings that were carried out by a number of groups on all sides. One of the most influential anti-war and counterculture books in American history was written by an Army veteran Ron Kovic, titled "Born on the Fourth of July." Numerous films have dramatized the Vietnam War, including "The Green Berets" (1968), "Go Tell the Spartans" (1978), "The Deer Hunter" (1978), "Platoon" (1986), "Born on the Fourth of July" (1989
text: The oil crisis of 1973 was a period when the price of oil rapidly increased in the United States, leading to rationing at gas stations, inflation, and a recession in 1974.

original_text: To help reduce consumption, in 1974 a national maximum speed limit of 55 mph (about 88 kmh) was imposed through the Emergency Highway Energy Conservation Act. Development of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was initiated in 1977 to reduce the impact of an oil embargo by maintaining oil supplies during periods of disruption. In 1979, a second oil crisis, caused by the Iranian Revolution, disrupted oil supplies further. These events, along with the realization that the US was becoming a net importer of petroleum, motivated the search for alternative energy sources. In the early 1970s, the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) began researching nuclear power as an alternative energy source. During the 1973 oil embargo, President Nixon authorized the development of a National Energy Plan. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) was created by the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974. The purpose of the NRC was to reduce the concentration of responsibility for regulation of nuclear energy, and to create a more independent federal agency to enforce reactor safety. The Energy Research and Development Administration (ERDA) was created at the same time to promote the development of alternative energy sources. In 1977, the Department of Energy was created to consolidate the energy-related work of these agencies. US nuclear plants, as of 2016, provide about 10 of the electricity generated in the US. The largest producer of nuclear power is Exelon Corporation, which operates 19 reactors at 13 plants, and produces about 20 of US nuclear electricity. Other large nuclear power producers are Duke Energy, Southern Company, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, and Entergy Nuclear. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 provided economic incentives for the nuclear power industry through production tax credits, price-anderson reactor insurance, risk insurance for new plants, and loan guarantees for financing new plants. The Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008 expanded the production tax credit for nuclear power to include uranium mining and enrichment facilities. As of 2016, there are 104 nuclear reactors operating at 60 plants in the US. These plants have a total capacity of 99 GW. In 2015, 805 terrawatt-hours (TWh) of electricity were generated by nuclear power plants, about 20 of total US electricity generation. The average capacity factor (ratio of actual output to maximum possible output) in 2015 was 90. A few plants have been built recently, and many older plants have been retrofitted. Nuclear power has several advantages, but also has significant environmental, safety, and political disadvantages. Provides a dependable source of power. The fuel is abundant, and the waste can be recycled or stored. Nuclear power is a non-carbon fuel, so it does not contribute to climate change or air pollution. Electricity produced by nuclear power plants is cheaper than electricity produced by solar or wind power plants. Mining and enrichment of uranium releases radioactive material into the environment. Nuclear waste must be isolated from the environment for 10000 years. Accidental release of radioactive material could pose a significant risk to public health. Nuclear power plants have a high capital cost, which is a barrier for new nuclear power plants. A nuclear reactor is a nuclear reactor is a device that contains and controls the fission chain reaction in which fissionable materials are bombarded by neutrons to release energy. The fuel used in a nuclear reactor is uranium. Uranium is a naturally occurring element. It is a relatively rare element, but a large supply of uranium has been discovered in Canada and Australia. The fission of uranium produces fission products. The decay of fission products produces heat energy. Heat from the decay of fission products is used to produce steam. Steam is used to drive turbines that produce electricity. The fission of uranium produces fission products. The decay of fission products produces heat energy. Heat from the decay of fission products is used to produce steam. Steam is used to drive turbines that produce electricity. original_text: In World War II, it was recognised that the Rhine would present a formidable natural obstacle to the invasion of Germany, by the Western Allies. The Rhine bridge at Arnhem, immortalized in the book, A Bridge Too Far and the film, was a central focus of the battle for Arnhem, during the failed Operation Market Garden of September 1944. The bridges at Nijmegen, over the Waal distributary of the Rhine, were also an objective of Operation Market Garden. In a separate operation, the Ludendorff Bridge, crossing the Rhine at Remagen, became famous, when U.S. forces were able to capture it intact - much to their own surprise - after the Germans failed to demolish it. This also became the subject of a film, The Bridge at Remagen. Seven Days to the River Rhine was a Warsaw Pact war plan for an invasion of Western Europe during the Cold War.

original_text: Harvard operates several arts, cultural, and scientific museums. The Harvard Art Museums comprises three museums. The Arthur M. Sackler Museum includes collections of ancient, Asian, Islamic and later Indian art, the Busch-Reisinger Museum, formerly the Germanic Museum, covers central and northern European art, and the Fogg Museum of Art, covers Western art from the Middle Ages to the present emphasizing Italian early Renaissance, British pre-Raphaelite, and 19th-century French art. The Harvard Museum of Natural History includes the Harvard Mineralogical Museum, Harvard University Herbaria featuring the Blaschka Glass Flowers exhibit, and the Museum of Comparative Zoology. Other museums include the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts, designed by Le Corbusier, housing the film archive, the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, specializing in the cultural history and civilizations of the Western Hemisphere, and the Semitic Museum featuring artifacts from excavations in the Middle East.

The Harvard Museum of Natural History includes the Harvard Mineralogical Museum, Harvard University Herbaria featuring the Blaschka Glass Flowers exhibit, and the Museum of Comparative Zoology. Other museums include the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts, designed by Le Corbusier, housing the film archive, the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, specializing in the cultural history and civilizations of the Western Hemisphere, and the Semitic Museum featuring artifacts from excavations in the Middle East.

original_text: The University of Chicago Library system encompasses six libraries that contain a total of 9.8 million volumes, the 11th most among library systems in the United States. The university's main library is the Regenstein Library, which contains one of the largest collections of print volumes in the United States. The Joe and Rika Mansueto Library, built in 2011, houses a large study space and an automatic book storage and retrieval system. The John Crerar Library contains more than 1.3 million volumes in the biological, medical and physical sciences and collections in general science and the philosophy and history of science, medicine, and technology. The university also operates a number of special libraries, including the D'Angelo Law Library, the Social Service Administration Library, and the Eckhart Library for mathematics and computer science, which closed temporarily for renovation on July 8, 2013. Harper Memorial Library no longer contains any volumes; however it is, in addition to the Regenstein Library, a 24-hour study space on campus.

original_text: Some priests and former religious had already married, including Andreas Karlstadt and Justus Jonas, but Luther's wedding set the seal of approval on clerical marriage. He had long condemned vows of celibacy, seeing them as an example of works-based salvation, but had argued that priests who had already made such vows should not marry. The Elector was delighted to have arranged this for Luther, and the marriage was a cause for great celebrations. Luther preached a sermon in which he referred to marriage as 'the best and noblest estate of all', before taking his place in the procession, in which he was preceded by two children carrying lighted tapers. Catherine was twenty-six, and was said to have been a nun for a while, but this is almost certainly an embellishment of the story. She was of lower social status than Luther, and may have been brought to Wittenberg to work in the Black Cloister. She was intelligent, with a good sense of humour and an attractive personality, and was an excellent housekeeper. Within the marriage, Luther was the dominant partner, and this continued to be the case, but he clearly respected his wife's views and took her advice seriously. They had six children, and she managed the household brilliantly. She was also a writer, whose hymns are still sung. The marriage was exceptionally happy, but was not without its difficulties. Luther's condemnation of the Mass in 1522 was directed against the idea of the Mass as a sacrifice, but also took issue with the idea of the Real Presence. This meant that he was attacking the doctrine of transubstantiation, the teaching that during the Mass the bread and wine really become the body and blood of Christ. This was one of the beliefs that most offended Luther's sense of logic, and one that his opponents thought was at the heart of Protestant heresy. They were angered that he could so easily deny such a central part of the teaching of the Church, and criticised him for not providing a clear definition of what was meant by 'This is my body'. Luther's comment that he could believe what he liked so long as his reason was not offended was interpreted as a piece of arrogant self-assertion. In this, as in many other respects, Luther was way ahead of his opponents, but it would take some time before they caught up with him. He was also aware that there would be problems within his own camp, and he was right. In 1524, Andreas Bodenstein von Karlstadt, a professor of theology at the university, took issue with Luther over the doctrine of transubstantiation. This was partly because Karlstadt found it difficult to accept the idea that the bread and wine were transformed in the course of the Mass, but was also because he wanted to attack the Mass as a sacrifice, and saw this as the place to do it. He claimed that the bread and wine remained unchanged, and said that as Christ was present everywhere, the sacrament should be administered by a layman. He also said that the Mass should not be celebrated in Latin, but in German. Luther argued against this, but Karlstadt pressed his claims in a series of pamphlets, and was backed up by a group of radicals at the university and in Wittenberg itself. Karlstadt's views were condemned by Luther, and the issue was referred to the Elector for a decision. Luther believed that the Mass should be celebrated in Latin, because that was what had been prescribed by the Church, and it was still the language of theology. He also said that the Mass should be celebrated by a priest, and that the elements should be treated with reverence, and he said that the bread and wine were the body and blood of Christ. Karlstadt was dismissed from his post at the university, and Luther preached a series of sermons denouncing his views. Karlstadt's supporters were banned from Wittenberg, and he himself fled to Switzerland. There he continued to develop his ideas, and in 1525 published a work entitled On the Ban , which attacked the worship of images and the practice of fasting. His views were more radical than Luther's, and he had the support of some of the Swiss reformers, notably Ulrich Zwingli. Luther was alarmed by Karlstadt's teaching, and wrote a series of pamphlets attacking it. Luther's views were shared by the other reformers at Wittenberg, and the Mass was celebrated in Latin and in the traditional way, with the priest facing east towards the altar. Some of Luther's supporters

original_text: The project must adhere to zoning and building code requirements. Constructing a project that fails to adhere to codes does not benefit the owner. Some legal requirements come from malum in se considerations, or the desire to prevent acts that are universally seen as socially unacceptable, harmful, or dangerous. Building codes and other regulations exist to provide minimum standards for safety to protect present and future persons from unreasonable harm or danger. Relevant codes include universal design, fire codes, and local building authority rules. Universal design, or universal access, refers to designing spaces that are accessible to all persons regardless of their age, race, size, or ability. There are many standards for universal design, including the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). It is important to have an understanding of the various codes and standards, and to work with an architect who is well versed in universal design. Many of the considerations for universal design are also features that enhance the usability of a project for all users, such as accessible and level pathways and the use of durable, low-maintenance materials. Fire codes help prevent fires and ensure the safety of occupants in case of fire. Fire codes are the basis for the design of fire protection systems. These codes are usually enforced by the local or state building authority. In the United States, NFPA 101 is the national model fire code that localities adopt. These codes govern building design, construction, and use. Local building authorities such as local planning departments or building inspection departments are responsible for enforcing building codes and for issuing permits to begin construction. Working with a local building official early in the design process helps to ensure that the proposed design is in compliance with applicable codes. Before beginning construction of the project, a building permit must be obtained. In the United States, the International Building Code (IBC) is the most widely adopted building code. IBC is a model code, which means that it serves as a template for the local building code, which is usually adopted by reference in local ordinances. The building code is enforced by the local building authority, such as the local building inspection department. A building permit is required for any construction, including a new home, an addition to an existing home, remodeling, or demolition. A building permit application must be submitted to the local building department, and the application must include drawings, calculations, and other documentation that describe the work to be done. A building permit application may require the seal of a registered design professional such as an architect, engineer, or building official. If a registered design professional seals the permit application, the professional is responsible for ensuring that the design meets the requirements of applicable codes. The professional may consult with other engineers or specialists who have expertise in certain areas. To ensure the safety of the occupants and the public, building code enforcement is critical. A well-designed building is not safe if the building is not constructed in compliance with the building code. One reason that a building permit is required is to ensure that the design is built as intended, and that construction is monitored by a qualified building official to ensure compliance with the building code. Another reason for building code enforcement is to ensure that building officials understand the building and the systems within it, and to ensure that the building is prepared for emergency situations, such as fires and natural disasters. As a registered design professional, it is my responsibility to design a project in compliance with the building code and to ensure that the project is constructed in compliance with the building code. This is a responsibility that I take very seriously, and one that I take pride in. I do not take shortcuts, and I strive to ensure that every detail of a project is carefully considered. I am a responsible design professional.
text: Building codes and regulations set minimum standards for the design and construction of a building or other structure, such as a shopping mall, office building, or residential home.

original_text: The Upper Rhine region was changed significantly by a Rhine straightening program in the 19th Century. The rate of flow was increased and the ground water level fell significantly. Dead branches and trunks were transported further downstream. The reduction of water retention areas and water plants led to a rise in water temperature. The meanders were straightened and the course of the Rhine became shorter. 40,000 ha of wetlands were lost and many fish species disappeared. The Upper Rhine was ecologically dead. With the Rhine's straightening, the migration routes of the fish were interrupted. Furthermore, the water quality deteriorated and led to a drastic reduction in the number of species of fish. The ecological balance was disturbed. The straightening of the Upper Rhine led to a decline in the numbers of the fish species that were important for the ecosystem. The Upper Rhine was in danger of becoming ecologically dead. In the 1970s, the EU launched a rescue program. The international waterway was being made into a "Rhine with a thousand faces." The first fish passages were built. Water plants were reintroduced. The river banks were renaturalized. These measures created habitats for numerous animals, especially fish. Since 1975, the European Union has been investing in the ecological restoration of the Rhine. The Upper Rhine was among the first restoration projects. As a result, the ecological balance has been restored. Fish are once again migrating from the sea into the heart of Europe. The populations of many fish species have grown significantly. The number of fish species has risen from 40 in the 1970s to 76 today. The Rhine now has a high diversity of species. The Rhine is now navigable again for the fish. A total of 11 fish passages were built in the Upper Rhine. They help the fish overcome the barriers and continue their journey. Many fish species have found new habitats in the Upper Rhine. This is good for the ecological balance of the river. The number of species has risen from 40 in the 1970s to 76 today. Many fish species that were on the verge of extinction have recovered their populations. The Upper Rhine is now a hotspot for fish. The ecological restoration of the Upper Rhine is one of the most successful projects in Europe. The fishing areas have been expanded significantly. The Upper Rhine is once again a valuable recreational area. The improvement in the water quality has also increased the attractiveness of the Upper Rhine for recreation. The banks of the Upper Rhine are now a popular recreational area. Many residents of the Upper Rhine region like to go fishing here. As part of the ecological restoration of the Upper Rhine, the banks have been renaturalized. The Upper Rhine is a popular area for sports fishing, recreational fishing and fishing from a boat. The Upper Rhine is a popular destination for day-trippers and excursions. For a long time, the Upper Rhine was regarded as ecologically dead. It has now become a hotspot for fish. The Upper Rhine is an important recreational area for the residents of the region. The banks of the Upper Rhine are now a popular destination for excursions. The Upper Rhine was for a long time regarded as ecologically dead. It has now become a hotspot for fish. The fishing areas have been expanded significantly. Since the ecological restoration, the Upper Rhine is once again a popular area for day-trippers. The Upper Rhine has once again become an ecological hotspot. The Upper Rhine is now a popular destination for day-trippers and excursions.
text: The Rhine is one of the world's most important rivers and a major source of drinking water for millions of people in Europe and North America, but it was once ecologically dead.

original_text: Salaries for primary teachers in Ireland depend mainly on seniority (i.e. holding the position of principal, deputy principal or assistant principal), experience and qualifications. Extra pay is also given for teaching through the Irish language, in a Gaeltacht area or on an island. The basic pay for a starting teacher is EUR27,814 p.a., rising incrementally to EUR53,423 for a teacher with 25 years service. A principal of a large school with many years experience and several qualifications (M.A., H.Dip., etc.) could earn over EUR90,000.

Extra pay is also given for teaching through the Irish language, in a Gaeltacht area or on an island. A principal of a large school with many years experience and several qualifications (M.A., H.Dip., etc.) could earn over EUR90,000.

original_text: There are a set of beautiful inlaid doors, dated 1580 from Antwerp City Hall, attributed to Hans Vredeman de Vries. One of the finest pieces of continental furniture in the collection is the Rococo Augustus Rex Bureau Cabinet dated c1750 from Germany, with especially fine marquetry and ormolu mounts. One of the grandest pieces of 19th-century furniture is the highly elaborate French Cabinet dated made by M. Fourdinois, made from ebony inlaid with box, lime, holly, pear, walnut and mahogany woods as well as marble with gilded carvings. Furniture designed by Ernest Gimson, Edward William Godwin, Charles Voysey, Adolf Loos and Otto Wagner are among the late 19th-century and early 20th-century examples in the collection. The work of modernists in the collection include Le Corbusier, Marcel Breuer, Charles and Ray Eames, and Gio Ponti.

original_text: Despite being relatively unaffected by the embargo, the UK nonetheless faced an oil crisis of its own - a series of strikes by coal miners and railroad workers over the winter of 1973-4 caused widespread power cuts and eventually brought down the Conservative government. The crisis also exposed deep fault lines in the British economy. British industry had been in decline since the 1960s, and Britain had become a net importer of food and manufactured goods. In the face of the oil crisis, the British government tried to reduce the country's dependence on oil by cutting its use of petroleum products. But this only exacerbated the problems for the British economy. Britain's coal mines were inefficient, and mechanisation was largely restricted to the pits' surface facilities. Coal miners were organised in powerful unions, which effectively resisted government attempts to cut coal subsidies. But with oil prices rising, the government decided to impose a three-day week in 1974, in order to conserve power. A state of emergency was declared, electricity supplies were restricted, and the police were given emergency powers. The three-day week was finally lifted in January 1975, but even then the problem was far from over. A series of strikes by coal miners throughout the winter of 1974-5 led to widespread power cuts, and forced the government to use troops to help move coal supplies around the country. The crisis caused the government to fall, and on February 4th 1974 the UK faced its first ever national election in February. When the election results came in, the Conservative Party was ousted from office and the Labour Party, under Harold Wilson, returned to power. Unfortunately for the British, the Labour Party's policies were no more effective than the Conservatives. After being re-elected, Wilson embarked on a series of nationalisations and higher taxes, which ultimately did little to revive the British economy. Britain's economic woes were mirrored in the rest of Europe. Inflation had sky-rocketed, and the value of the pound and other European currencies had fallen to record lows. The oil shock had also exposed deep economic fault lines throughout Europe, especially in Germany. German industry was still reeling from the impact of the oil crisis, and the country faced high unemployment and serious economic problems. As a result, the German government re-imposed controls on wages and prices in order to keep inflation under control. This, however, exacerbated the country's problems - inflation and unemployment continued to rise, and the German economy sank into a deep recession. In the early 1970s, the British and German economies had been growing steadily. But by 1974, the recession had spread throughout Europe. As the oil shocks continued throughout 1975, the economy in Europe continued to slide. The Italian lira, the Spanish peseta and the Irish pound all fell dramatically, while the value of the pound plunged to an all-time low of 1.57 - a level it has never regained. But the biggest problem for Europe was inflation. By the end of 1974, inflation throughout Europe had risen to 10 - higher than at any time since the Second World War. European countries tried to counter the rise in prices by printing more money - but this only increased inflation. By 1975, inflation in Europe had reached 12, and the value of European currencies was falling. The end of the 1970s saw a wave of devaluations throughout Europe. The French franc was devalued in 1976, the Italian lira in 1976, and the Spanish peseta in 1978. In Britain, the situation was even worse. The pound fell to a record low of 1.60, and the country faced unprecedented levels of inflation and unemployment. When James Callaghan became Prime Minister in 1976, he inherited a nation in crisis. He introduced a series of measures, including wage restraints, tax increases and a cut in public spending. But the measures were largely unsuccessful, and by 1977, Britain faced its second oil crisis. The Middle East peace accords between Israel and Egypt were signed in 1978,
text: Despite being relatively unaffected by the embargo, the UK nonetheless faced an oil crisis of its own - a series of strikes by coal miners and railroad workers over the winter of 1973-4 caused widespread power cuts and eventually brought down the Conservative government. The crisis also exposed deep fault lines in the British economy. British industry had been in decline since the 1960s, and Britain had become a net importer of food and manufactured goods. In the face of the oil crisis, the British government tried to reduce the country's dependence on oil by cutting its use of petroleum products. But this only exacerbated the problems for the British economy. Britain's coal mines were inefficient, and mechanisation was largely restricted to the pits' surface facilities. Coal miners were organised in powerful unions, which effectively resisted government attempts to cut coal subsidies. But with oil prices rising, the government decided to impose a three-day week in 1974, in order to conserve power. A state of emergency was declared, electricity supplies were restricted, and the police were given emergency powers. The three-day week was finally lifted in January 1975, but even then the problem was far from over. After being re-elected, Wilson embarked on a series of nationalisations and higher taxes, which ultimately did little to revive the British economy. The oil shock had also exposed deep economic fault lines throughout Europe, especially in Germany. German industry was still reeling from the impact of the oil crisis, and the country faced high unemployment and serious economic problems. As a result, the German government re-imposed controls on wages and prices in order to keep inflation under control. original_text: The Normans (Norman: Nourmands; French: Normands; Latin: Normanni) were the people who in the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name to Normandy, a region in France. They were descended from Norse Vikings who were granted feudal overlordship of areas in northern France - a duchy of Normandy - in the 10th century. The Norman dynasty had a major political, cultural and military impact on medieval Europe and even the Near East. Norman may also refer to: 2.1 Places in England 2.2 Places in France 2.3 Places in the United States 3 Culture and science 5.1 People with the surname Norman 6.1 Places named Norman The Normans (musical group), a 1960s band featuring Zal Yanovsky Norman (album), a 2013 album by Sorrows The Normals, an American rock band from the 1990s The Normals, a British indie band The Normals (album), a 2001 album by the band Norman (opera), a 1984 opera by Philip Glass Norman!, a 1976 album by Norman Connors Norman (given name) Norman (surname) Norman baronets, two baronetcies created for persons with the surname Norman Norman!, a 2010 film Norman (film), a 2017 film The Norman Conquests, a 1973 trilogy of plays by Alan Ayckbourn This page contains text from Wikipedia, the Free Encyclopedia - Norman was an Anglo-Norman nobleman who served as the Justiciar of Ireland and founded the St Leger family. Norman was the son of Richard le Gros, a royal clerk under Henry II of England. His family were established in Hertfordshire before entering the civil service of the Norman kings of England. Norman's younger brother, Ralph le Gros, also had a long career in the civil service. Norman was appointed justiciar of Ireland by Prince John, the Lord of Ireland, in 1189, a post he held until 1194. Norman was also the founder of the St Leger family. While Justiciar of Ireland he founded the settlement of St Leger in County Donegal. He was appointed Chief Justiciar of England in 1199 and died in 1203. Norman married Alice de Courcy. Together they had two sons, Robert and Ralph. Ralph le Gros was also a royal clerk and later became Bishop of Chichester. text: The surname Norman is given to people in England, France, and the United States, as well as to those in Spain, Italy, Germany, and Canada.

original_text: Teachers that exhibit enthusiasm can lead to students who are more likely to be engaged, interested, energetic, and curious about learning the subject matter. Recent research has found a correlation between teacher enthusiasm and students' intrinsic motivation to learn and vitality in the classroom. Controlled, experimental studies exploring intrinsic motivation of college students has shown that nonverbal expressions of enthusiasm, such as demonstrative gesturing, dramatic movements which are varied, and emotional facial expressions, result in college students reporting higher levels of intrinsic motivation to learn. Students who experienced a very enthusiastic teacher were more likely to read lecture material outside of the classroom.

original_text: Immigrants arrived from all over the world to search for gold, especially from Ireland and China. Many Chinese miners worked in Victoria, and their legacy is particularly strong in Bendigo, where they made up around 20 per cent of the mining population in the mid-1800s. These goldfields attracted the attention of the Chinese Empire, which sent a diplomat to Britain in 1866 to negotiate the rights of Chinese subjects in Victoria. In the Victorian goldfields, there were many Chinese stores, restaurants and lodging houses. The Chinese were known for their resourcefulness and industry. They often worked in teams, and their financial and business skills meant they were soon running highly successful businesses. The Australian gold rushes were also known as the 'new chum rushes' because new arrivals from England, Ireland and Europe came in large numbers to the Victorian goldfields. They brought with them a new culture of entrepreneurialism and the gold rushes were a catalyst for Australian-born innovation.
text: The Victorian goldfields were one of Australia's most important economic centres, and were home to some of the country's best known and most successful entrepreneurs.

original_text: One of the later ruptures between Toghrul and Temujin was Toghrul's refusal to give his daughter in marriage to Jochi, the eldest son of Temujin, a sign of disrespect in the Mongolian culture. This act led to the split between both factions and was a prelude to war. Toghrul allied himself with Jamukha, who already opposed Temujin's forces; however, the internal dispute between Toghrul and Jamukha, plus the desertion of a number of their allies to Temujin, led to Toghrul's defeat. Jamukha escaped during the conflict. This defeat was a catalyst for the fall and eventual dissolution of the Keraite tribe.

original_text: Most species are hermaphrodites - a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm, meaning it can fertilize its own egg, not needing a mate. Some are simultaneous hermaphrodites, which are both sexes at the same time; some are sequential hermaphrodites, which start out as one sex and then change to the other. Some have both male and female organs, but they are not fully functional as both sexes. When a hermaphrodite and a male mate, their offspring can be either male or female, depending on the genetics of the parents. In some species, all the offspring are female. These females reproduce by cloning, since they don't need a mate. Some animals are parthenogenic - females can reproduce without mating. The eggs can have genetic mutations, so that each female may have slightly different offspring. Some species have sex determination, where the sex of the offspring is determined by environmental factors (e.g., temperature, available food). Some animals can change their sex, depending on the needs of the group. Some species have "gynodioecy" - a hermaphrodite and a male will mate, but the male's sperm will fertilize only the female's eggs, not her own. Some species can change sex during their lifespan. Some animals reproduce by asexual budding, which does not involve sexual reproduction. Some species are all male or all female. Some organisms reproduce without sex. Some species have haplodiploid sex determination - the males are haploid (one set of chromosomes), the females are diploid (two sets of chromosomes). Some animals can change their sex over their lifespan, or under certain conditions. Some animals have homosexual sex. Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of two gametes (sex cells) to form a zygote (fertilized egg). The zygote divides by mitosis into a multicellular individual. The fusion of the gametes usually takes place in a specialized structure within one of the individuals, such as the flower of the angiosperms, or within the body cavities of animals. The sex cells are produced in multicellular structures called gonads. When the sex cells are produced, they undergo a special form of cell division called meiosis, which reduces the number of chromosomes by half, so that the resulting cells are haploid. In sexual reproduction, the male gametes are called sperm, and the female gametes are called eggs or ova. In most sexually-reproducing organisms, each individual has two sexes, which are called male and female. In some species, some individuals can function as one sex, and others can function as the other sex. In some species, a single individual functions as both sexes. In some species, the male and female functions are not clearly defined. Most animals (including humans) have two different sexes (male and female). Some animals have a single sex. Some animals have both sexes at the same time. Some animals change sex. Some animals can have any sex, depending on the needs of the group. Some animals can have sex with the same sex. In some species, a single organism can change its sex over its lifetime. Most animals have two sexes (male and female). Some animals have a single sex (hermaphrodite). Some animals have both sexes at the same time. Some animals can change their sex, depending on the needs of the group. Some animals can have sex with the same sex. Some organisms have both sexes at the same time (hermaphrodite). Some organisms have one sex when they are young, and the other sex when they are adults. Some organisms can change their sex under certain conditions. Some organisms can have sex with the same sex. Many of the terms used to describe gender and sex are outdated. Some people may identify themselves as transgender. Some people may not identify as either male or female. Some animals have both male and female organs, but they are not fully functional as both sexes. Some animals are parthenogenic - females can reproduce without mating. Some species have gynodioecy - a hermaphrodite and a male will mate, but the male's sperm will fertilize only the female's eggs, not her own. text: A hermaphrodite is an animal with two ovaries, one male and one female, which can produce both male and female offspring, depending on the genetics of the parents.

original_text: A regulation of the Rhine was called for, with an upper canal near Diepoldsau and a lower canal at Fussach, in order to counteract the constant flooding and strong sedimentation of the watercourse. On December 12, 2000, the St. Gall Canton council agreed to the construction of a lower canal with a total cost of CHF 105 million. The project was designed by the Federal Waterways Administration. The general contractor was the joint venture Locher Parking, Implenia, Marti, Stucky, and Linth AG. In February 2003, the construction work was started. The work included the construction of three weirs, a 3.7 km long main channel, the construction of two pumping stations, and the construction of three compensation basins. On May 25, 2007, the new regulation was inaugurated. The new channel has a capacity of 400 ms and a total length of 3.7 km. The lower canal is 3.7 km long and connects the existing 8 km-long upper canal with the River Rhine. The channel was constructed by a joint venture of three companies. The work included the construction of three weirs, a 3.7 km long main channel, the construction of two pumping stations, and the construction of three compensation basins. The main channel was cut into a soft rock using controlled blasting. The rock was excavated by blasting and hydraulic pumping. The channel is 20 m wide and 7 m deep and has a capacity of 400 ms. The Rhine River is separated into an upper and lower channel. The upper channel is 8 km long and 120 m wide. It is located at Diepoldsau, the location of the old waterway. In the lower canal, the flow velocity is reduced from 1.8 ms to 0.7 ms. This decreases the transport capacity from 400 ms to 25 ms. In the 1980s, the idea of a regulation of the Rhine was called for, with an upper canal near Diepoldsau and a lower canal at Fussach, in order to counteract the constant flooding and strong sedimentation of the watercourse. In September 1993, the St. Gall Canton council decided to implement the project. The project was designed by the Federal Waterways Administration. In December 2000, the St. Gall Canton council agreed to the construction of a lower canal with a total cost of CHF 105 million. In February 2003, the construction work was started. The new channel was inaugurated on May 25, 2007.

original_text: Kenya won several medals during the Beijing Olympics, six gold, four silver and four bronze, making it Africa's most successful nation in the 2008 Olympics. New athletes gained attention, such as Pamela Jelimo, the women's 800m gold medalist who went home with Kenya's first gold and also set a new world record, David Rudisha, the men's 800m champion and world-record holder in 800m, and Samuel Wanjiru, the men's marathon champion. At the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Kenya was represented by 47 athletes in track and field, 12 in boxing, 5 in swimming, 4 in rowing, 1 in weightlifting, 1 in sailing, and 1 in badminton. Kenyan boxer Benson Gicharu failed to show up for his fight, and Kenya was disqualified. However, the disqualification was later overturned on appeal. The Kenyan team in the Beijing Olympics opened with a silver medal in men's 3000 metres steeplechase, thanks to Brimin Kipruto. It was followed by a gold medal in the men's 3000 metres steeplechase, courtesy of Ezekiel Kemboi. In the women's 800 metres, Pamela Jelimo won Kenya's first gold medal of the Beijing Olympics, and broke the world record for 800 metres, with a time of 1:54:87. She was followed by Janeth Jepkosgei, who won the silver medal in the same event. In the 10,000 metres, Sally Kipyego took the silver medal in the women's 10,000 metres. Vivian Cheruiyot won a gold medal in the women's 5000 metres, and a bronze in the 10,000 metres. In the women's 1500 metres, Nancy Langat won the silver medal, and Milcah Chemos Cheywa won a bronze medal. In the men's 1500 metres, Silas Kiplagat won a bronze medal. Kenya had a good performance in the women's 800 metres. In addition to the gold and silver medals won by Jelimo and Jepkosgei, Agnes Jebet Tirop won a bronze medal in the women's 800 metres. In the men's 110 metres hurdles, David Kimutai Rotich won a bronze medal. Kenya had a good performance in the women's 400 metres hurdles. In addition to the gold medal won by Beijing Olympics, Eunice Jepkoech Sum won the silver medal, while Janet Jepkosgei won the bronze medal. In the men's 3000 metres steeplechase, Paul Kipsiele Koech won a silver medal, while Richard Mateelong won the bronze medal. In the women's 1500 metres, Faith Macharia won the silver medal. In the men's marathon, Samuel Wanjiru won the gold medal. In the women's marathon, Catherine Ndereba won the silver medal. Kenya won a bronze medal in the women's 4x400 metres relay, courtesy of Janet Jepkosgei, Eunice Jepkoech Sum, Milcah Chemos Cheywa, and Nancy Langat. In the women's 4x100 metres relay, Kenya's team (Janeth Jepkosgei, Pamela Jelimo, Nancy Langat, and Violet Jelagat Roror) did not qualify for the final. In the men's 4x400 metres relay, Kenya's team (David Rotich, Alfred Kirwa Yego, Joseph Mutua Mwengi, and Wilfred Bungei) did not qualify for the final. Kenya's team (Paul Wanjiru, Davis Kamoga, and Paul Kibet) was disqualified from the final of the men's 4x100 metres relay, after Paul Kibet failed to pass the baton to the next runner. The university also contains a library system, the University of Chicago Press, the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, and the University of Chicago Medical Center, and holds ties with a number of independent academic institutions, including Fermilab, Argonne National Laboratory, and the Marine Biological Laboratory. original_text: If a problem X is in C and hard for C, then X is said to be complete for C. This means that X is the hardest problem in C. (Since many problems could be equally hard, one might say that X is one of the hardest problems in C.) Thus the class of NP-complete problems contains the most difficult problems in NP, in the sense that they are the ones most likely not to be in P. Because the problem P NP is not solved, being able to reduce a known NP-complete problem, P2, to another problem, P1, would indicate that there is no known polynomial-time solution for P1. This is because a polynomial-time solution to P1 would yield a polynomial-time solution to P2. Similarly, because all NP problems can be reduced to the set, finding an NP-complete problem that can be solved in polynomial time would mean that P NP.

original_text: The plague disease, caused by Yersinia pestis, is enzootic (commonly present) in populations of fleas carried by ground rodents, including marmots, in various areas including Central Asia, Kurdistan, Western Asia, and Northern and Eastern Africa. Humans acquire plague through the bite of a rodent flea that is carrying plague bacteria or through direct contact with an infected animal or human. Untreated, plague can be rapidly fatal. Early treatment is essential. Symptoms of bubonic plague include fever, headaches, chills, and weakness. These symptoms can appear suddenly and can be accompanied by painful, swollen lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin, armpits, or neck. Pneumonic plague is the most serious form of the disease. It is an advanced infection that is transmitted through droplets in the air and has a short incubation period. Symptoms include high fever, vomiting, and a cough that can produce bloody sputum. Septicemic plague is another serious form of plague and occurs when plague bacteria multiply in the blood. Symptoms include fever, chills, abdominal pain, and shock. Rapid antibiotic treatment is essential to prevent death from plague. Antibiotics can prevent the disease from developing in people who have been exposed. Plague is endemic in Madagascar. In 2017, there were 449 cases and 57 deaths reported, with 66 of cases reported in the capital, Antananarivo. In 2018, there were 2,560 cases and 211 deaths reported, with 77 of cases reported in Antananarivo. Madagascar experienced a large outbreak of plague in 2017, which was driven in part by large forest fires. Forest fires are a natural feature of the environment in Madagascar, but in 2017, these fires were extremely large and burned across a greater than usual area. The fires occurred at the same time as the start of the plague season, and it is believed that the fires contributed to the spread of plague by driving the rodents that carry the disease to more populated areas. For more information about the 2017 outbreak, see the Disease Outbreak News published by the World Health Organization.

original_text: Since the Peace of Westphalia, the Upper Rhine formed a contentious border between France and Germany. Establishing "natural borders" on the Rhine was a long-term goal of French foreign policy, and Napoleon was able to achieve this goal in 1805, when he annexed the Duchy of Baden. The Upper Rhine became the new border between France and Germany, and the Rhine was "liberated" from the Rhine bailiffs who had ruled the river since the Middle Ages. The Rhine also became an important shipping lane, as the French began to construct and expand ports on the Rhine. After the defeat of Napoleon, the 1815 Congress of Vienna reestablished a territorially weakened France, and in 1816 the Rhine was again demarcated as a border. However, the 1815 Congress of Vienna also created the German Confederation, in which the entire Upper Rhine was incorporated. During the nineteenth century, the French-German conflict over the Rhine became one of the central issues of European politics. When the German states founded the North German Confederation in 1867, the Rhine became the border between the Confederation and the Kingdom of France. The Franco-Prussian War of 187071 ended with the founding of the German Empire and the Rhine became a border of the new empire. The French desire for revenge and the German fear of a new French invasion led to the construction of the fortifications of the Upper Rhine. The Rhine lost its significance as a commercial waterway in the late nineteenth century, when the railways gradually replaced the Rhine as a shipping lane. The Treaty of Versailles granted the territories of Alsace and Lorraine to France. The German-French border was reestablished as a demilitarized zone, in which all fortifications were to be dismantled. With the German invasion of France in May 1940, the French-German border was re-established on the Rhine. This border was fixed in the Armistice of Compiegne in June 1940. The Wehrmacht occupied the entire left bank of the Upper Rhine, the so-called CdZ-Gebiet, and the right bank of the Rhine was occupied by French Vichy troops. The German-French border was not altered by the Armistice of 1944, and the border remained in place until the end of World War II in May 1945. The border was reestablished at the French-German border of 1939. The border between France and West Germany, which was established in 1949, was officially referred to as the "French-German border." The border between France and East Germany, which was established in 1949, was referred to as the "French-GDR border." The Treaty of the Elysee (French: traite de l'Elysee) of 22 January 1963 ended the military occupation of the Federal Republic of Germany and abolished the military status of West Berlin. The Treaty on Franco-German Cooperation (French: traite d'amitie franco-allemand) of 22 January 1963 laid the foundation for the Franco-German cooperation. The Schengen Agreement of 14 June 1985 and the Maastricht Treaty of 7 February 1992 abolished border controls between the member states of the European Community, including France and Germany. The Schengen acquis was fully implemented by France and Germany on 26 March 1995. The Treaty of Lisbon of 13 December 2007 established the Union for the Mediterranean. original_text: In the meantime, on August 1, 1774, an experiment conducted by the British clergyman Joseph Priestley focused sunlight on mercuric oxide (HgO) inside a glass tube, which liberated a gas he named "dephlogisticated air." He noted that candles burned brighter in the gas and that a mouse was more active and lived longer while breathing it. After breathing the gas himself, he wrote: "The feeling of it to my lungs was not sensibly different from that of common air, but I fancied that my breast felt peculiarly light and easy for some time afterwards." Priestley published his findings in 1775 in a paper titled "An Account of Further Discoveries in Air" which was included in the second volume of his book titled Experiments and Observations on Different Kinds of Air. Because he published his findings first, Priestley is usually given priority in the discovery.

original_text: In July 1968, ABC Radio launched a special programming project for its FM stations, which was spearheaded by Allen Shaw, a former program manager at WCFL in Chicago who was approached by ABC Radio president Harold L. Neal to develop a format to compete with the new progressive rock and DJ-helmed stations. The new concept called "LOVE Radio," which featured a limited selection of music genres, was launched on ABC's seven owned-and-operated FM stations in late November 1968; the concept replaced nearly all of the programming provided by these stations; however, several affiliates (such as KXYZ) retained the majority of their content. In August 1970, Shaw announced that ABC FM's music choice policy should be reviewed to allow listeners access to many styles of music.

The new concept called "LOVE Radio," which featured a limited selection of music genres, was launched on ABC's seven owned-and-operated FM stations in late November 1968; the concept replaced nearly all of the programming provided by these stations; however, several affiliates (such as KXYZ) retained the majority of their content. In August 1970, Shaw announced that ABC FM's music choice policy should be reviewed to allow listeners access to many styles of music.

Since 2000, ABC has also owned the television rights to most of the Peanuts television specials, having acquired the broadcast rights from CBS, which originated the specials in 1965 with the debut of A Charlie Brown Christmas (other Peanuts specials broadcast annually by ABC, including A Charlie Brown Christmas, include It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown and A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving).

original_text: Luther and his colleagues introduced the new order of worship during their visitation of the Electorate of Saxony, which began in 1527. They also assessed the standard of pastoral care and Christian education in the parishes. Their findings were alarming. In many parishes the pastors did not understand Latin and so were unable to conduct the Mass or preach a sermon. In addition, most people could not afford to buy missals, so few of the congregation knew even the most basic liturgical prayers by heart. The reformers responded by producing a simplified order of worship that could be used by every parish. This included the celebration of two communion services each Sunday, a service of the Word at 7am and the celebration of the Eucharist at 9am or 10am. The main focus of Luther's liturgical reforms was the sermon. He believed that God speaks to us through the word of the Bible, and that hearing and understanding that word is therefore the most important aspect of our encounter with God. Luther preached most Sundays, and he was the main author of the sermons that appeared in the new order of worship. The publication of the order of worship was controversial, however. It was not the business of a prince to interfere with the divine order of worship. That was the prerogative of the pope. Luther's response was that his reforms were not new, but simply a return to the practices of the apostles. The churches of the Reformation were not only reformed in worship, but also in church government. They were based on the principle of the 'priesthood of all believers'. This meant that they did not have bishops who had inherited their office from the apostles. Instead, the congregation elected their pastors. Within a few years of the Reformation beginning, there were calls for the churches to be reformed in other ways, too. In 1523, Andreas Karlstadt, one of Luther's colleagues at Wittenberg, argued that the veneration of saints, relics and images, as well as the exclusion of women from the church and the banning of the Bible from the laity, were all unbiblical and needed to be abandoned. He also believed that some aspects of traditional Christian morality were wrong, and that this needed to be addressed by the church. There were other reformers who agreed with some of Karlstadt's criticisms, but did not like his radicalism. They formed a group known as the 'Philipists', who promoted a more moderate approach to reform. Their opponents, who called themselves 'Gnesio-Lutherans' (meaning 'true Lutherans, thought that the Philipists were too conservative, and that they were not as committed to the Reformation as they should be. The Reformation in Germany was not a single movement, but a series of debates and arguments among a number of different individuals and groups who shared a common commitment to reform, but had different ideas about what that meant in practice. It was a dynamic and creative process, that would go on to affect every aspect of German society in the sixteenth century.
