original_text: Private schooling in the United States has been debated by educators, lawmakers and parents, since the beginnings of compulsory education in Massachusetts in 1852. The Supreme Court precedent appears to be that while states can regulate private schools, they cannot prohibit them. This report examines the arguments for and against regulation and concludes that the arguments against it are stronger. Education is the key to America's future. We know that education is important in preparing us to become the skilled, productive workers of tomorrow. It is also important in enabling us to function as informed citizens. Education is the key to America's future. We know that education is important in preparing us to become the skilled, productive workers of tomorrow. It is also important in enabling us to function as informed citizens. Education is crucial to our success in an ever-more competitive world. American business leaders have long argued that public schools have failed to prepare students for the workforce. Although students graduating from American high schools have achieved some of the highest reading, math, and science test scores in the world, employers complain that they cannot find enough people with the right skills. Many believe that businesses would be more willing to hire high school graduates if they had more training in basic skills, such as reading, writing, and math. The problem is not that American students are unintelligent. The average American high school student is quite capable of learning all of the basic skills that he or she will need in a career. The problem is that American schools are not giving them the education they need. Instead of training students to be the best workers in the world, they are turning out graduates with mediocre skills, and then expecting American businesses to train them in the skills they need to succeed in the workforce. Several factors may be at work in this educational failure. Some argue that the U.S. education system is simply too large and unwieldy. Many other countries have educational systems that are decentralized and locally controlled. Many of these countries also have national curriculum guidelines that local educators are free to tailor to the needs of their communities. In the U.S., however, local school boards are required to follow detailed state and federal curriculum mandates. Some of these mandates are well-intentioned. They ensure that schools prepare students for the challenges of the 21st century. However, they also place a huge burden on local school boards to adhere to state and federal standards. School boards that do not follow these standards risk losing federal funding or facing lawsuits from the federal government. This limits their freedom to adapt to local needs, and it increases their costs as they struggle to follow federal mandates. Students in many European countries attend a variety of different schools. In the Netherlands, for example, families can choose among a variety of different schools that are free, publicly funded, and locally controlled. There are more than 7,000 different schools in the Netherlands, and more than half are private. More than 75 percent of Dutch children attend private schools, which are subject to rigorous government standards but are given the freedom to set their own curricula. Unlike most private schools in the U.S., private schools in the Netherlands do not charge tuition. They are funded by a voucher system in which the government allocates an amount of money equal to what it spends per student in a public school. Families are free to use these vouchers to pay for a private school of their choice. Vouchers have proven to be an effective way to give families a voice in their children's education. They also give private schools the freedom to tailor their curricula to the needs of students. In the U.S., private schools are often subject to the same regulations as public schools. This gives parents a limited choice of schools that are all forced to comply with the same standards. While many of these standards are well-intentioned, they do not take into account the needs of different students. Some students need a more rigorous curriculum. Others need one that is more flexible and personalized. Some students are best suited to an environment where they can receive a lot of one-on-one attention. Others do better in a structured classroom. All students learn differently, and all students need a customized education. Unfortunately, many American schools are not able to provide this level of personalization. In large public schools, it is difficult for teachers to give individual students the attention they need. In schools that are too small, there is not enough diversity to prepare students for the realities of a multicultural world. Schools in
text: The American Enterprise Institute (AEI) has released a new report examining whether private schools in the United States should be regulated by the state or left to their own devices.

original_text: While experimenting, Tesla inadvertently faulted a power station generator, causing a power outage. In August 1917, Tesla explained what had happened in The Electrical Experimenter: "As an example of what has been done, just one of my many experiments is mentioned. At the Houston (Texas) power station of the Southern Company a generator was run up to 7,200 revolutions, 1200 above normal speed, and 1700 more than the maximum it had ever been run up to before. The result was a runaway. No provision had been made for this. The huge three-phase machine got out of control in a few minutes, and it was found impossible to shut it off or even to keep it from speeding up. The power was switched off at the mains, but this did not affect the machine. It was as if the giant had gone mad and rushed on its course blindly. The pressure rose to an unprecedented 12,000 and kept rising. Had it continued much longer there would have been a crash and a serious accident. After two hours the flames had to be extinguished with water and the machine shut down manually. It was found that many of the journals of the bearings had fused and that the shaft of the generator had been heated over the full length and was warped. Had it gone a minute or two longer, the shaft would have been broken. Fortunately, however, the damage was not serious, and in a short time the machine was in running order again."

original_text: In July 1977, General Zia-ul-Haq overthrew Prime Minister Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto's regime in Pakistan. Ali Bhutto, a leftist in democratic competition with Islamists, had announced banning alcohol and nightclubs within six months, shortly before he was overthrown. Zia-ul-Haq was much more committed to Islamism, and "Islamization" or implementation of Islamic law, became a cornerstone of his eleven-year military dictatorship and Islamism became his "official state ideology." Zia ul Haq was an admirer of Mawdudi and Mawdudi's party Jamaat-e-Islami became the "regime's ideological and political arm." In Pakistan this Islamization from above was "probably" more complete "than under any other regime except those in Iran and Sudan," but Zia-ul-Haq was also criticized by many Islamists for imposing "symbols" rather than substance, and using Islamization to legitimize his means of seizing power. Unlike neighboring Iran, Zia-ul-Haq's policies were intended to "avoid revolutionary excess," and not to strain relations with his American and Persian Gulf state allies. Zia-ul-Haq was killed in 1988 but Islamization remains an important element in Pakistani society.

In Pakistan this Islamization from above was "probably" more complete "than under any other regime except those in Iran and Sudan," but Zia-ul-Haq was also criticized by many Islamists for imposing "symbols" rather than substance, and using Islamization to legitimize his means of seizing power. Unlike neighboring Iran, Zia-ul-Haq's policies were intended to "avoid revolutionary excess," and not to strain relations with his American and Persian Gulf state allies. Zia-ul-Haq was killed in 1988 but Islamization remains an important element in Pakistani society.

original_text: The other category of schools are those run and partly or fully funded by private individuals, private organizations and religious groups. The ones that accept government funds are called'aided' schools. The private'un-aided' schools are fully funded by private parties. The standard and the quality of education is quite high. Technically, these would be categorized as private schools, but many of them have the name "Public School" appended to them, e.g., the Galaxy Public School in Kathmandu. Most of the middle-class families send their children to such schools, which might be in their own city or far off, like boarding schools. The medium of education is English, but as a compulsory subject, Nepali andor the state's official language is also taught. Preschool education is mostly limited to organized neighbourhood nursery schools.

original_text: For the third straight season, the number one seeds from both conferences met in the Super Bowl. The Carolina Panthers became one of only ten teams to have completed a perfect regular season, but lost to the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl the previous season. The Panthers entered the playoffs as the NFC's top seed for the second straight year with a record of 15-1, finishing 7 games ahead of the 8-8 second-seeded Tampa Bay Buccaneers in the NFC South. In the playoffs, the Panthers defeated the New York Giants in the divisional round 23-0, and then beat the Philadelphia Eagles in the NFC Championship Game 14-3. The Panthers became only the fourth team in NFL history to shut out their opponent in back-to-back playoff games. The Panthers were the first NFC team to win 15 regular season games since the 1998 Minnesota Vikings, and the only team to do so in the 21st century. The Seahawks, despite losing their season opener, won their next 12 games, becoming only the third team in NFL history to do so. However, in Week 13, the Seahawks lost a home game to the Pittsburgh Steelers, 21-10, and the following week lost to the Green Bay Packers in a snowy game in Lambeau Field, 33-27, ending their perfect season hopes. They won their final two games to finish 13-3, the best record in the NFC and the second-best record in the NFL, and earned home field advantage for the playoffs. In the playoffs, the Seahawks beat the Washington Redskins, 20-10, and the Carolina Panthers, 34-14, to advance to their first Super Bowl appearance in team history. This was the first Super Bowl to be played in the month of February. It was scheduled on February 1, 2009, a Sunday; the last time the Super Bowl was played on a Sunday was Super Bowl XXVII in 1993. The NFL promoted this game with the tagline "The Road to XLIII." The game was televised in the United States on NBC with play-by-play announcer Al Michaels, color commentators John Madden and Andrea Kremer, and sideline reporters Chris Collinsworth and Cris Collinsworth. Madden's final assignment after 30 seasons of NFL coverage, he was the only person to broadcast Super Bowls on all four major television networks. This also marked the first Super Bowl telecast for Andrea Kremer. The game was preceded by a pre-game show featuring many celebrity guests, including the American Idol Top 12 Finalists. This year's halftime show, again produced by MTV, featured British band The Who, who performed a medley of their hits, including "Baba O'Riley," "Pinball Wizard," "Who Are You," "Won't Get Fooled Again" and "Teenage Wasteland." The national anthem was performed by Jennifer Hudson. Hudson previously won the third season of American Idol and became the first Idol finalist to win an Academy Award when she won Best Supporting Actress in the 2006 film Dreamgirls. The game was broadcast on NBC in the United States and on CTV in Canada. The Super Bowl was broadcast on XM Satellite Radio in the U.S. and Canada, with the NBC broadcast (with NBC's announcers) on both the NFL and NBC channels, and on Spanish radio on XM channel 146, with the Univision Radio broadcast (with Univision Radio's announcers) and on Spanish channel 147, with the Univision TV broadcast (with Univision Radio's announcers). As has been the case with all Super Bowls since Super Bowl XXXIX, Sirius Satellite Radio carried the NBC broadcast on channel 123, and the Univision Radio broadcast on channel 147. The NBCWestwood One Radio broadcast was carried by local NBC affiliates in the teams' markets. WCBS-AM in New York City and KDKA in Pittsburgh carried the game with their own announcers. As it has for all NFL games, Compass Media Networks carried the game on radio, with Kevin Harlan as play-by-play announcer and Boomer Esiason as color analyst. "Super Bowl History." Vegas Insider. Retrieved February 4,

original_text: Conservative researchers have argued that income inequality is not significant because consumption, rather than income should be the measure of inequality, and inequality of consumption is less extreme than inequality of income in the US. Will Wilkinson of the libertarian Cato Institute states that "the weight of the evidence shows that the run-up in consumption inequality has been considerably less dramatic than the rise in income inequality," and consumption is more important than income. According to Johnson, Smeeding, and Tory, consumption inequality was actually lower in 2001 than it was in 1986. The debate is summarized in "The Hidden Prosperity of the Poor" by journalist Thomas B. Edsall. Other studies have not found consumption inequality less dramatic than household income inequality, and the CBO's study found consumption data not "adequately" capturing "consumption by high-income households" as it does their income, though it did agree that household consumption numbers show more equal distribution than household income.

original_text: Some episodes have been returned to the BBC from the archives of other countries who bought prints for broadcast, or by private individuals who acquired them by various means. Early colour videotape recordings made off-air by fans have also been retrieved, as well as excerpts filmed from the television screen onto 8 mm cine film and clips that were shown on other programmes. Audio versions of all of the lost episodes exist from home viewers who made tape recordings of the show. Short clips from every story with the exception of Marco Polo, "Mission to the Unknown" and The Massacre of St Bartholomew's Eve also exist.

original_text: To help reduce consumption, in 1974 a national maximum speed limit of 55 mph (about 88 kmh) was imposed through the Emergency Highway Energy Conservation Act. Development of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve began in 1975, and in 1977 the cabinet-level Department of Energy was created, followed by the National Energy Act of 1978.[citation needed] On November 28, 1995, Bill Clinton signed the National Highway Designation Act, ending the federal 55 mph (89 kmh) speed limit, allowing states to restore their prior maximum speed limit.

original_text: On 1 July 1851, writs were issued for the election of the first Victorian Legislative Council, and the absolute independence of Victoria from New South Wales was established proclaiming a new Governor and administration. In 1855, the Victorian gold rush transformed Melbourne into one of the world's largest and wealthiest cities. Throughout 1857, planning began for the construction of the first stage of the Parliament House, with Charles Pasley as architect and Peter Kerr as contractor. In January 1858, the foundation stone for the new Parliament House was laid by the Governor Sir Henry Barkly. The House was officially opened in October 1859, and the inaugural meeting of the Victorian Legislative Council was held on 21 November 1856. The first meeting of the Victorian Legislative Assembly took place on 21 November 1856. The new Victorian Constitution created two Houses of Parliament: a Legislative Assembly (now the Legislative Assembly), elected by popular vote, and a Legislative Council (now the Legislative Council), whose members were appointed. Under the new Constitution, the Legislative Council was to have a maximum membership of 34, of whom 18 were officials and 16 were non-officials. The Council could not refuse supply, and could be dissolved only in certain circumstances, mainly concerning money bills. The Council's membership was to be appointed by the Governor, on the recommendation of the premier, and was to hold office for life. The Legislative Council was granted equal power in financial matters to the popularly-elected Assembly. In 1858, the Victorian Electoral Office had been set up to administer the first secret ballot elections for the Victorian Parliament. The Electoral Office is responsible for the conduct of the state election process. The Victorian Parliament is responsible for making laws in Victoria. There are 128 Members of Parliament in Victoria, 88 in the Legislative Assembly and 40 in the Legislative Council. The Parliament of Victoria has its origin in the 1850s. It was elected in 1851, when Victoria was still part of the colony of New South Wales, but in 1856, under the new Constitution, the colony of Victoria was granted self-government. The Constitution established two Houses of Parliament: the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council. The Legislative Assembly is sometimes called the lower house and the Legislative Council the upper house, although they both have the same powers except when it comes to blocking money bills. The Council has more than 40 members elected for four-year terms by proportional representation. The Council could not refuse supply, and could be dissolved only in certain circumstances, mainly concerning money bills. The Council's membership was to be appointed by the Governor, on the recommendation of the premier, and was to hold office for life. The Legislative Council is sometimes called the upper house. The Legislative Assembly is sometimes called the lower house and the Legislative Council the upper house, although they both have the same powers except when it comes to blocking money bills. The Assembly is made up of 88 members elected for four-year terms by the people of Victoria. The Legislative Assembly has 88 members, each elected for four-year terms from single-member constituencies. The Legislative Council has 49 members, elected from eight multi-member constituencies, each of which returns five members elected by proportional representation. original_text: Some elements of the Brotherhood, though perhaps against orders, did engage in violence against the government, and its founder Al-Banna was assassinated in 1949 in retaliation for the assassination of the prime minister. Since 1954 the Brotherhood has generally renounced violence, but some elements are accused of violence today in Egypt and elsewhere. In the United States, the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) has sometimes been accused of being a front organization for the Brotherhood. CAIR denies this, saying it is an independent organization. The Brotherhood has been active in Libya and Tunisia for decades, and in 2011 it attempted to take over those governments after the uprisings. In 2011 it won 47 percent of the vote for parliament in Egypt, and in 2012 it won the presidency. It is still the largest single party in Egypt. In Turkey, the government of Recep Tayyip Erdogan is often described as Islamist, though it is more Islamic than Islamist. The Justice and Development Party (AKP) was founded in 2001 by Islamists, but it won power in 2002 by promising to respect Turkey's secular constitution. The AKP was re-elected in 2007 and 2011, and then Erdogan was elected president in 2014. It has been accused of increasingly subverting the constitution and the rule of law. The AKP's government also supports the Muslim Brotherhood and has, for example, condemned the Egyptian government for cracking down on the Brotherhood. Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Somalia have been the main battlegrounds in the war against al-Qaeda and its associated movements. As noted above, al-Qaeda was founded in 1988 by Osama bin Laden, a millionaire from a wealthy Saudi family. It quickly became the most active and notorious terrorist organization in the world. In 1998 it bombed the U.S. embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, killing over 200 people. In 2000 it was involved in the attack on the USS Cole in Yemen. But its most notorious action was the attack on New York and Washington on September 11, 2001. Bin Laden was killed by U.S. special forces in May 2011. The Taliban is a Sunni Islamist movement that ruled Afghanistan from 1996 to 2001. When it was in power, it carried out extreme punishments, including stoning and amputation. It also provided sanctuary for al-Qaeda and other terrorists. The Taliban was forced out of power by the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan in October 2001, but it continued to fight and today controls more territory than at any time since the invasion. Hezbollah is a Shiite Islamist movement and political party in Lebanon that was founded in the 1980s in response to the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Its military wing has engaged in terrorism against Israel and the United States, including the 1983 bombing of the U.S. embassy and the 1984 bombing of the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut. Hezbollah has also fought against Israel and other groups in Lebanon. It is funded by Iran, and has sent its fighters to aid the regime of Bashar al-Assad in the civil war in Syria. Hamas is a Sunni Islamist organization that was founded in 1987 in the Gaza Strip. Its military wing is believed to have carried out many terrorist attacks, including the 2004 bombing of a bus in Jerusalem, and rocket attacks on Israel. Hamas has engaged in power struggles with Fatah and other groups in Gaza, and has fought a war against Israel. It was elected to lead the Palestinian Authority in 2006 but was ousted from power in 2007 by Fatah. It retains control over the Gaza Strip, which it has ruled since 2007. It is believed to be funded by Iran. Al-Shabaab is a Sunni Islamist organization in Somalia that was founded in 2

text: Denver Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning beat Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton in what could be the final game of his career. Carolina's Cam Newton became the first quarterback to throw for 300 yards and rush for 50 yards in a Super Bowl, but he also threw two interceptions, including one that was returned for a touchdown.

original_text: There were tax exemptions for religious figures and, to some extent, teachers and doctors. The Mongol Empire practiced religious tolerance because Mongol tradition had long held that religion was a personal concept, and not subject to law or interference.[citation needed] Sometime before the rise of Genghis Khan, Ong Khan, his mentor and eventual rival, had converted to Nestorian Christianity. Various Mongol tribes were Shamanist, Buddhist or Christian. Religious tolerance was thus a well established concept on the Asian steppe.

original_text: In July 1977, General Zia-ul-Haq overthrew Prime Minister Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto's regime in Pakistan. Ali Bhutto, a leftist in democratic competition with Islamists, had announced banning alcohol and nightclubs within months of coming to power in 1971. Zia-ul-Haq, however, was much more zealous in his attempts to Islamize Pakistan. He declared that he would rule the country by Sharia. He banned nightclubs, cinemas and alcohol and made Friday the weekly holiday. He also set up the Federal Shariat Court and the Council of Islamic Ideology to ensure that laws were Islamic. The Ahmadis were declared non-Muslims through a constitutional amendment, which was made possible through a mass movement launched by the religious parties against the community. Blasphemy was made a cognizable and non-bailable offense and "enemies of the state" were publicly hanged. When General Zia-ul-Haq died in an air crash in 1988, his Islamization project remained incomplete. This was the task of his successor, General Mirza Aslam Beg. In December 1988, General Beg issued the notorious 'Fatwa of the Army', which declared that jihad was obligatory for all Muslims. He also announced that Pakistan's nuclear weapons were made for use against the infidels. The following month, General Beg announced that he would rule by Sharia. In 1989, Pakistan's legislative body, the National Assembly, passed a constitutional amendment which declared that the objective of the constitution was the glory of Islam. In 1991, the Federal Shariat Court was empowered to strike down any law or legal instrument that was against the injunctions of Islam. The Sharia laws that were introduced in Pakistan were a mixture of various schools of Islamic law. Although in theory it was argued that the Sharia was not specific to any sect, in reality the laws that were implemented were specific to the Sunni Muslim majority. The Shia Muslim minority was left to fend for itself and in many cases was specifically targeted through the laws. For example, the prohibition of music and dance was specifically targeted at the Shia festival of Muharram, which is traditionally marked by drum beats and theatrical performances. Similarly, the prohibition on Alam (a flag used in Muharram processions) was specifically aimed at the Shia community. In 1992, the government of Pakistan began a campaign to register all the madrasas in the country. The reason for this was that the government felt that the curriculum of these institutions did not incorporate sufficient material on Pakistan's ideology. The country's ideology, it should be noted, was Islam. There were three main reasons for this concern. Firstly, Pakistan was facing an insurgency in its tribal belt which was being fought by jihadi groups. It was being argued that the jihadi groups were using these madrasas as recruiting grounds. Secondly, the military was facing a threat from its own ranks. There were several instances of soldiers' refusal to fight the jihadi groups. This was attributed to their being taught the concept of jihad in the madrasas. Thirdly, the Afghan jihad had polarized the society and the government was under pressure to bring the jihadi groups to heel. In 1993, the Pakistan government banned the use of loudspeakers for the purpose of religious sermons. However, this ban was subsequently lifted. In 1994, the Federal Shariat Court declared that women could not become judges. Women were not allowed to be judges in Saudi Arabia as well. In 1994, the National Assembly declared that Friday was the weekly holiday in the country. In 1995, the Shariat Appellate Bench of the Supreme Court issued a verdict that declared that the selling of alcohol was a sin and that all Muslims were duty bound to stop such activities. In 1996, the government banned the television broadcast of Indian films. In 1997, the government banned the use of loudspeakers during religious festivals. text: In July 1977, General Zia-ul-Haq overthrew Prime Minister Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto's regime in Pakistan. Ali Bhutto, a leftist in democratic competition with Islamists, had announced banning alcohol and nightclubs within months of coming to power in 1971. Zia-ul-Haq, however, was much more zealous in his attempts to Islamize Pakistan. He declared that he would rule the country by Sharia. He banned nightclubs, cinemas and alcohol and made Friday the weekly holiday. He also set up the Federal Shariat Court and the Council of Islamic Ideology to ensure that laws were Islamic. The Ahmadis were declared non-Muslims through a constitutional amendment, which was made possible through a mass movement launched by the religious parties against the community. Blasphemy was made a cognizable and non-bailable offense and "enemies of the state" were publicly hanged. When General Zia-ul-Haq died in an air crash in 1988, his Islamization project remained incomplete. This was the task of his successor, General Mirza Aslam Beg. In December 1988, General Beg issued the notorious 'Fatwa of the Army', which declared that jihad was obligatory for all Muslims. He also announced that Pakistan's nuclear weapons were made for use against the infidels. The following month, General Beg announced that he would rule by Sharia. In 1989, Pakistan's legislative body, the National Assembly, passed a constitutional amendment which declared that the objective of the constitution was the glory of Islam. In 1991, the Federal Shariat Court was empowered to strike down any law or legal instrument that was against the injunctions of Islam. The Sharia laws that were introduced in Pakistan were a mixture of various schools of Islamic law. Although in theory it was argued that the Sharia was not specific to any sect, in reality the laws that were implemented were specific to the Sunni Muslim majority. The Shia Muslim minority was left to fend for itself and in many cases was specifically targeted through the laws. For example, the prohibition of music and dance was specifically targeted at the Shia festival of Muharram, which is traditionally marked by drum beats and theatrical performances. Similarly, the prohibition on Alam (a flag used in Muharram processions) was specifically aimed at the Shia community. In 1992, the government of Pakistan began a campaign to register all the madrasas in the country. The reason for this was that the government felt that the curriculum of these institutions did not incorporate sufficient material on Pakistan's ideology. The country's ideology, it should be noted, was Islam. There were three main reasons for this concern. Firstly, Pakistan was facing an insurgency in its tribal belt which was being fought by jihadi groups. It was being argued that the jihadi groups were using these madrasas as recruiting grounds. Secondly, the military was facing a threat from its own ranks. There were several instances of soldiers' refusal to fight the jihadi groups. This was attributed to their being taught the concept of jihad in the madrasas. Thirdly, the Afghan jihad had polarized the society and the government was under pressure to bring the jihadi groups to heel. In 1993, the Pakistan government banned the use of loudspeakers for the purpose of religious sermons. However, this ban was subsequently lifted. In 1994, the Federal Shariat Court declared that women could not become judges. Women were not allowed to be judges in Saudi Arabia as well. In 1994, the National Assembly declared that Friday was the weekly holiday in the country. In 1995, the Shariat Appellate Bench of the Supreme Court issued a verdict that declared that the selling of alcohol was a sin and that all Muslims were duty bound to stop such activities. In 1996, the government banned the television broadcast of Indian films. In 1997, the government banned the use of loudspeakers during religious festivals. In 1997, the National Assembly passed a law which made it mandatory for all students to study the Quran and Islamiat. This was challenged in the Supreme Court. However, the Supreme Court ruled that the teaching of the Quran and Islamiat did not violate the constitution. The court also ruled

original_text: There are hints in the surviving records of the ancient Egyptians that they had some knowledge of prime numbers: the Egyptian fraction expansions in the Rhind papyrus, for instance, have quite different forms for primes and for composites. However, the earliest surviving records of the explicit study of prime numbers come from the Ancient Greeks. Euclid's Elements (circa 300 BC) contain important theorems about primes, including the infinitude of primes and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic. Euclid also showed how to construct a perfect number from a Mersenne prime. The Sieve of Eratosthenes, attributed to Eratosthenes, is a simple method to compute primes, although the large primes found today with computers are not generated this way.

original_text: With International Criminal Court trial dates in 2013 for both President Kenyatta and Deputy President William Ruto related to the 2007 election aftermath, US President Barack Obama chose not to visit the country this week, the first US President not to visit Kenya since independence. The White House released a statement that "President Obama's decision not to travel to Kenya at this time reflects his commitment to encouraging the Kenyan government's continued progress on reforms and his concern about Kenya's failure to meet its international obligation to prosecute those responsible for the 2007-2008 post-election violence." Despite the bizarre and occasionally tone-deaf references to Kenya from Romney in the last US presidential campaign, I had imagined that Obama would be visiting Kenya as part of an African trip in 2013 or 2014, with the symbolism of a visit by the first African-American US President to his father's homeland, and with the "winds of change" Obama noted at a Cairo speech early in his presidency having reached Nairobi. On the other hand, my initial thought about the Obama-Kenyatta meeting at the White House in 2006 was that Obama was simply keeping his end of the bargain for the ODM strategy at the time which was for Raila to run for President and Kibaki to run for Prime Minister, and Obama, the future President, had to meet Raila, the future President. Thus I had expected the Obama visit to Kenya to be in connection with the Kenyatta-Ruto trial. But at the time of the meeting at the White House, even if there was a strategy for Raila to succeed Kibaki, Kenyatta and Ruto were still in the Kibaki camp. Thus it did not seem as clear that Obama should be making a commitment to Kenyatta. As you may recall, in 2006, Kenyans were still waiting to have the results of the 2005 referendum on the draft constitution ratified in a national referendum, which was later delayed until 2007. I remember Raila as a guest at a breakfast session at CSIS in Washington in 2006. The moderator was the late Ambassador Robert Houdek, who had been in Nairobi during the referendum and had a generally positive view of the process. I remember him asking Raila, "Would you accept the results of the referendum?." Raila said, "Yes, if I win," which the moderator could not let go without some comment about how Raila was not in the right spirit. The PNUODM coalition fell apart in 2006 and the 2007 elections were the most hotly contested in Kenya's history. After the contested election results, the ODM and PNU coalitions formed new, respectively "Government of National Unity" and "Grand Coalition Government." As Obama prepares to visit South Africa in June, the Washington Post story from yesterday is headlined, "Kenyans say Obama's absence from a visit to their country is a snub." The Obama administration has been criticized by some Kenyans and their political leaders for not visiting the country. Kenyans note that when Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited in 2012, she was met by throngs of people and cheering crowds. Several polls indicate that Kenyatta's popularity has fallen after his election last year, and he faces the possibility of indictment by the International Criminal Court on charges of crimes against humanity for his alleged involvement in the violence that followed the 2007 election. The Post story also notes that in 2006, then-Sen. Obama was one of only four Senators to vote against a bill that would allow the United States to extend military aid to countries that had not signed the International Criminal Court treaty. Also the story says that "U.S. law prohibits the government from providing assistance to any individual facing charges at the ICC." In a Time magazine article, "U.S.-Kenya Relations: The Price of Democracy," Simon Robinson writes: The U.S. - Kenya's largest trading partner - has been careful not to criticize Kenyatta's government too openly, although it has raised concerns about the potential abuse of human rights. In April, the U.S. withdrew 21 million in fund
text: President Uhuru Kenyatta's visit to the United States this week is the first visit by a Kenyan head of state to the US since President Kibaki's trip to Washington in 2006.

original_text: Chloroplasts have their own DNA, often abbreviated as ctDNA, or cpDNA. It is also known as the plastome. Its existence was first proved in 1962, and first sequenced in 1986. It was, at one time, thought to be an organelle, but it is now known to be a genetic element found in the chloroplasts. The ctDNA encodes the proteins of the photosynthetic machinery, and other essential chloroplast functions. It is arranged in a single circular molecule, like the mitochondrial DNA. The ctDNA is a small genome, consisting of about 160,000 base pairs, and contains 114 genes, of which 78 encode proteins. There are also 8 ribosomal RNA genes, and 30 tRNA genes.

The Super Bowl is set to be played on February 7, 2016.

The pandemic reached Africa in 1900, and the Americas in 1900 and 1909. By 1911, it had reached Hawaii, New Zealand and Australia. According to WHO, the Fourth Pandemic was declared in 1909. The plague outbreaks were recorded in India, Manchuria, China, and South Africa. The disease spread to port cities in India, the Middle East and Africa between 1903 and 1907, and to port cities in the Western Hemisphere in 1909 and 1911. Plague is found in nature among rodents and their fleas. It is not known whether the plague originated in rodents or among humans, but it can be traced back as far as 2500 B.C. in Egypt. text: The bubonic plague, also known as the Black Death, is one of the world's most deadly diseases, killing more than 200 million people since it was first identified in the 14th century.

original_text: The Amazon rainforest (Portuguese: Floresta Amazonica or Amazonia; Spanish: Selva Amazonica, Amazonia or usually Amazonia; French: Foret amazonienne; Dutch: Amazoneregenwoud), also known in English as Amazonia or the Amazon Jungle, is a moist broadleaf forest in the Amazon biome that covers most of the Amazon basin of South America. This basin encompasses 7,000,000 square kilometres (2,700,000 sq mi), of which 5,500,000 square kilometres (2,100,000 sq mi) are covered by the rainforest. This region includes territory belonging to nine nations. The majority of the forest is contained within Brazil, with 60 of the rainforest, followed by Peru with 13, Colombia with 10, and with minor amounts in Venezuela, Ecuador, Bolivia, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana. States or departments in four nations contain "Amazonas" in their names. The Amazon represents over half of the planet's remaining rainforests, and comprises the largest and most biodiverse tract of tropical rainforest in the world, with an estimated 390 billion individual trees divided into 16,000 species. The rainforest likely formed during the Eocene era. It appeared following a global reduction of tropical temperatures when the Atlantic Ocean had widened sufficiently to provide a warm, moist climate to the Amazon basin. The rainforest has been in existence for at least 55 million years, and most of the region remained free of savanna-type biomes at least until the current ice age, when the climate was drier and savanna more widespread. original_text: The capture of Waruhiu Itote (aka General China) on 15 January 1954 and the subsequent interrogation led to a better understanding of the Mau Mau command structure. Operation Anvil opened on 24 April 1954, after weeks of planning by the army with the approval of the War Council. The operation effectively placed Nairobi under military siege, and the occupants were screened and the Mau Mau supporters moved to detention camps. The Home Guard formed the core of the government's strategy as it was composed of loyalist Africans, not foreign forces like the British Army and King's African Rifles. By the end of the emergency, the Home Guard had killed 4,686 Mau Mau, amounting to 42 of the total insurgents. The capture of Dedan Kimathi on 21 October 1956 in Nyeri signified the ultimate defeat of the Mau Mau and essentially ended the military offensive. During this period, substantial governmental changes to land tenure occurred. The most important of these was the Swynnerton Plan, which was used to both reward loyalists and punish Mau Mau.

original_text: Fresno has three large public parks, two in the city limits and one in county land to the southwest. Woodward Park, which features the Shinzen Japanese Gardens, numerous picnic areas and several miles of trails is in North Fresno and is adjacent to the San Joaquin River Parkway. Roeding Park, near Downtown Fresno, is home to the Fresno Chaffee Zoo, and Rotary Storyland and Playland. Kearney Park is the largest of the Fresno region's park system and is home to historic Kearney Mansion and plays host to the annual Civil War Revisited, the largest reenactment of the Civil War in the west coast of the United States. The City of Fresno offers 75 neighborhood and regional parks covering 2,500 acres (10 km2) throughout the city. These parks feature over 100 miles (160 km) of multi-use trails. The Fresno parks system has several properties listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and features several historic houses. Fresno is one of the first U.S. cities to use solar-powered trash compactors, which use solar energy to compact larger-sized trash cans, increasing their waste capacity. Fresno is also one of the first U.S. cities to use Megahome units that use solar energy to treat wastewater. The Fresno Municipal Sanitary Landfill was the first modern landfill in the United States, and includes one of the first modern leachate treatment systems in the nation. The San Joaquin River Parkway is a planned 22-mile (35 km) long parkway, presently estimated to cost 310 million, along the southern edge of Fresno. The planned parkway would connect the San Joaquin River Parkway to the Friant-Kern Canal Trail via 5 bridges. When completed, the parkway will connect with the Lewis S. Eaton Trail System. The City of Fresno has set aside over 200,000 for the project. In 2006, Fresno Mayor Alan Autry initiated a city-wide campaign to revitalize and invest in the local downtown community of Fresno. The campaign, called Fresno Prospers, focuses on a five-point plan to "foster and improve the development, vitality and stability of Downtown Fresno as the region's civic core, entertainment center, employment and business center, and education core." As part of the Fresno Prospers initiative, the city purchased several buildings in the downtown area, including the Fresno Bee building, with the intent of transforming them into mixed-use developments. The Fresno Bee building, now called the Grand 1401, was purchased in 2007 and is currently undergoing renovation. In 2007, the city broke ground on a new 200 million, 800,000 square foot (74,000 m) Federal Courthouse in downtown Fresno to consolidate and improve the security of federal operations in the city. The Robert E. Coyle Federal Courthouse is expected to be completed in 2010. The city also purchased the Fulton Mall, with plans to reopen it to traffic and revitalize the downtown area. The 170 million Fulton Corridor Revitalization project, approved by the Fresno City Council in 2006, will demolish the Fulton Mall, replace it with two-way traffic, and construct high-density retail and residential buildings in the area. In October 2007, Mayor Autry announced a five-point economic development plan to create more jobs, attract more businesses, reduce traffic, and expand the Fresno economy. The plan includes road improvements, diversification of industry, efforts to make the city a hub of alternative energy research and development, a new initiative to support small business, and a jobs training program.
text: The City of Fresno is the largest city in California's Central Valley and is home to more than half a million people, making it one of the most densely populated cities in the United States.

original_text: Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia. Nearly 50,000 Huguenots established themselves in Germany, 20,000 of whom were welcomed by Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg. In addition, 20,000 settled in the Lutheran cities and principalities of Baden, Franconia, and the Palatinate. Over 10,000 Huguenots emigrated to the Dutch Republic during the 16th and 17th centuries. They found refuge in Amsterdam, the cultural and economic centre of the Netherlands at the time. The Dutch Republic was the only place in Europe where Huguenots found full freedom of religion and could worship openly. At the end of the 16th century, Huguenots fled the French persecution and found refuge in Italy. The most important French-speaking community in Italy was founded by the weavers who were invited by Pope Clement VII in 1533 to work in the silk and wool manufactories in the region of Lucca, near Florence. This community of Protestants was protected by the grand dukes of Tuscany and the King of France. The community of Huguenots in Ireland formed in the 17th century. They were attracted by the religious tolerance of the English colony. The majority of Huguenots found refuge in Dublin, the country's largest city, but they also established settlements in Cork, Limerick, and Waterford. The Dutch Republic was the only place in Europe where Huguenots found full freedom of religion and could worship openly. Huguenots who settled in England were welcomed by Queen Elizabeth I in 1562, but it was under James I's reign that they were finally recognised as French citizens in England. Between 1685 and 1687, England welcomed more than 20,000 Huguenots. Some of them settled in London, but most of them established communities in Canterbury, the City of Rochester, and Norwich. In 1683, King Charles II of Spain issued the royal decree of "the Pardo" Pragmatica de las Cortes de Castilla which granted the Protestants of France the right to live and work in Spain. Many of them found refuge in the Basque Country and in Catalonia. In the mid-17th century, the royal court of Denmark-Norway granted asylum to several thousand Huguenots. The newcomers were welcomed by Christian IV, king of Denmark, and Frederick III, king of Denmark and Norway, who made several decrees in favour of the French Protestants. After 1685, Huguenot refugees spread all over Scandinavia. The Huguenots who settled in Sweden, in particular in the cities of Stockholm and Gothenburg, worked in the iron and steel industry. In Finland, Huguenots established a colony in the city of Turku, which became the capital of the country. The majority of Huguenots who fled France found refuge in the Holy Roman Empire, one of the largest European territories. Around 250,000 Huguenots were welcomed in the Lutheran states in the region of Brandenburg, Pomerania, Mecklenburg, and Silesia. The largest number of Huguenots settled in the Prussian cities of Berlin, Konigsberg, and Magdeburg. Huguenots also established communities in the Palatinate, Saxony, Hesse-Kassel, and Wurttemberg. Many of them were weavers and settled in the textile manufactories of Ulm and Stuttgart. Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia.
text: Huguenots were Protestants who fled the persecution of Huguenots in France in the 16th and 17th centuries to find sanctuary in Germany, the Netherlands, Italy and Ireland.

original_text: The immune system protects organisms from infection with layered defenses of increasing specificity. In simple terms, physical barriers prevent pathogens such as bacteria and viruses from entering the organism. If a pathogen breaches these barriers, the innate immune system provides an immediate, but non-specific response. Innate immune systems are found in all plants and animals. If pathogens successfully evade the innate response, vertebrates possess a second layer of protection, the adaptive immune system, which is activated by the innate response. Here, the immune system adapts its response during an infection to improve its recognition of the pathogen. This improved response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated, in the form of an immunological memory, and allows the adaptive immune system to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.

Here, the immune system adapts its response during an infection to improve its recognition of the pathogen. This improved response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated, in the form of an immunological memory, and allows the adaptive immune system to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.

original_text: A study by the World Institute for Development Economics Research at United Nations University reports that the richest 1 of adults alone owned 40 of global assets in the year 2000. The three richest people in the world possess more financial assets than the lowest 48 nations combined. The combined wealth of the "10 million dollar millionaires" grew to nearly 41 trillion in 2008. A January 2014 report by Oxfam claims that the 85 wealthiest individuals in the world have a combined wealth equal to that of the bottom 50 of the world's population, or about 3.5 billion people. According to a Los Angeles Times analysis of the report, the wealthiest 1 owns 46 of the world's wealth; the 85 richest people, a small part of the wealthiest 1, own about 0.7 of the human population's wealth, which is the same as the bottom half of the population. More recently, in January 2015, Oxfam reported that the wealthiest 1 percent will own more than half of the global wealth by 2016. An October 2014 study by Credit Suisse also claims that the top 1 now own nearly half of the world's wealth and that the accelerating disparity could trigger a recession. In October 2015, Credit Suisse published a study which shows global inequality continues to increase, and that half of the world's wealth is now in the hands of those in the top percentile, whose assets each exceed 759,900. A 2016 report by Oxfam claims that the 62 wealthiest individuals own as much wealth as the poorer half of the global population combined. Oxfam's claims have however been questioned on the basis of the methodology used: by using net wealth (adding up assets and subtracting debts), the Oxfam report, for instance, finds that there are more poor people in the United States and Western Europe than in China (due to a greater tendency to take on debts).[unreliable source?unreliable source?] Anthony Shorrocks, the lead author of the Credit Suisse report which is one of the sources of Oxfam's data, considers the criticism about debt to be a "silly argument" and "a non-issue.... a diversion."

original_text: Sociologist Jake Rosenfield of the University of Washington asserts that the decline of organized labor in the United States has played a more significant role in expanding the income gap than previously thought. According to Rosenfield, the diminishing influence of unions in the workplace has been compounded by an eroding support system for unions among the public, policymakers, and corporate leaders. In an article in the June 2010 issue of the American Journal of Sociology, Rosenfield argues that, although the decline in union membership has been long-established as a consequence of the economic restructuring that occurred in the United States from the 1970s onwards, this trend has been exacerbated by a growing social and political disdain for the labor movement. Rosenfield says the role of the "right-to-work" lobby in preventing unions from gaining a stronghold in the workplace has been significant. "Right-to-work" laws permit workers to enjoy the benefits of unionized labor without paying dues. In 1977, just 11.5 percent of private-sector workers were employed in right-to-work states. Today, the figure is 33.5 percent. Rosenfield further points to growing public distrust of unions as a reason for the decline. The Pew Research Center, for example, found that the percentage of Americans who believe that labor unions are too powerful rose from 16 percent in 1967 to 53 percent in 2009. "The public debate over unions and union organizing in recent years has been particularly contentious," Rosenfield says. In addition to Rosenfield, the authors of the study are James M. Sullivan, of the University of Notre Dame, and Melissa S. Williams, of the University of Toronto.
text: The income gap between rich and poor in the United States is widening, according to a new analysis of US Census data, with the top one-tenth of one percent now earning more than the bottom half of the population.

original_text: The IPCC does not carry out research nor does it monitor climate related data. Lead authors of IPCC reports assess the available information about climate change based on published sources. According to IPCC guidelines, authors should give priority to peer-reviewed sources. Authors may refer to non-peer-reviewed sources (the "grey literature, provided that they are of sufficient quality. Examples of non-peer-reviewed sources include model results, reports from government agencies and non-governmental organizations, and industry journals. Each subsequent IPCC report notes areas where the science has improved since the previous report and also notes areas where further research is required.

original_text: While most chloroplasts originate from that first set of endosymbiotic events, Paulinella chromatophora is an exception that acquired a photosynthetic cyanobacterial endosymbiont more recently. It is not clear whether that event occurred via horizontal gene transfer (HGT) or by endosymbiosis. To address this issue, we determined the complete chloroplast genomes of 18 Paulinella strains. Comparisons with chloroplast genomes of other organisms indicate that Paulinella is a sister group to plants and diatoms, which supports an endosymbiotic origin of chloroplasts. The chloroplast genome of Paulinella is organized similarly to that of algae and plants, including inverted repeat regions. It contains the smallest genome of photosynthetic eukaryotes, but is larger than cyanobacterial genomes, suggesting that endosymbiosis occurred at an early stage of chloroplast evolution. Paulinella chloroplasts contain only 48 unique genes, most of which are plastid-specific genes found in algae, diatoms and plants. A phylogenetic tree constructed using chloroplast-encoded genes shows that Paulinella is a sister group of diatoms andor plants. Furthermore, the phylogenetic trees of 11 chloroplast-encoded genes constructed using the Paulinella sequences and those of other eukaryotes do not support an HGT scenario. These results strongly suggest that the chloroplast in Paulinella was acquired via endosymbiosis. We estimate that the chloroplast was transferred from the cyanobacterial endosymbiont of Paulinella to the common ancestor of extant Paulinella strains 83-47 million years ago. The Paulinella chloroplast genome has lost genes at a higher rate than other chloroplast genomes. We also identified novel insertion sequences and several chloroplast genes that have undergone positive selection. The results suggest that the chloroplast in Paulinella has been independently reduced in size via gene loss and that selection has played a major role in the evolution of this chloroplast genome. Chloroplasts are the sites of photosynthesis in eukaryotic organisms and have a long evolutionary history. The endosymbiotic origin of chloroplasts was suggested decades ago and is now well-supported by both morphological and molecular evidence. However, the sequence of the endosymbiotic events and the exact identity of the cyanobacterial endosymbiont that gave rise to the chloroplast are still controversial. Most chloroplasts are thought to originate from a single primary endosymbiotic event, which occurred when a cyanobacterium was engulfed by a heterotrophic eukaryotic cell. Chloroplasts that originated from that event are referred to as "green" or "primary" chloroplasts and are found in algae and plants. By contrast, the red algae and glaucophytes are thought to have originated from a separate endosymbiotic event involving a different cyanobacterium, a "secondary" endosymbiotic event. More recently, a unicellular eukaryote, Paulinella chromatophora, was found to have acquired a cyanobacterial endosymbiont. The Paulinella endosymbiont resembles a free-living cyanobacterium in its morphology and physiology, yet it also contains a chloroplast genome that shares many features with those of algae and plants. It is not clear how the Paulinella chloroplast arose, whether by the uptake of a free-living cyanobacterium with a chloroplast or by the uptake of a cyanobacterium that contained a "green" chloroplast. If the Paulinella chloroplast was obtained via the uptake of a free-living cyanobacterium with a chloroplast, then Paulinella is an example of endosymbiotic gene transfer (HGT) in which the chloroplast was transferred from the cyanobacterial endosymbiont to the host. Such a case would support the hypothesis that chloroplasts are not essential to the lifestyle of an endosymbiont and that a chloroplast could be transferred between cells. If,

original_text: The galleries also link design to wider trends in British culture. For instance, design in the Tudor period was influenced by the spread of printed books and the work of European artists and craftsmen employed in Britain. In the Stuart period, increasing trade, especially with Asia, enabled wider access to luxuries like carpets, lacquered furniture, silks and porcelain. In the Georgian age there was increasing emphasis on entertainment and leisure. For example, the increase in tea drinking led to the production of tea paraphernalia such as china and caddies. European styles seen on the Grand Tour also influenced taste. As the Industrial Revolution took hold, the growth of mass production produced entrepreneurs such as Josiah Wedgwood, Matthew Boulton and Eleanor Coade. In the Victorian era new technology and machinery had a significant effect on manufacturing, and for the first time since the reformation, the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches had a major effect on art and design such as the Gothic Revival. There is a large display on the Great Exhibition which, among other things, led to the founding of the VA. In the later 19th century, the increasing backlash against industrialization, led by John Ruskin, contributed to the Arts and Crafts movement.

original_text: During his time at his lab, Tesla observed unusual signals from his receiver which he concluded may be communications from another planet. He mentioned them in a letter to reporter Julian Hawthorne at the Philadelphia North American on 8 December 1899 and in a December 1900 letter about possible discoveries in the new century to the Red Cross Society where he referred to messages "from another world" that read "1.... 2.... 3...." Reporters treated it as a sensational story and jumped to the conclusion Tesla was hearing signals from Mars. He expanded on the signals he heard in a 9 February 1901 Collier's Weekly article "Talking With Planets" where he said it had not been immediately apparent to him that he was hearing "intelligently controlled signals" and that the signals could come from Mars, Venus, or other planets. It has been hypothesized that he may have intercepted Marconi's European experiments in July 1899 - Marconi may have transmitted the letter S (dotdotdot) in a naval demonstration, the same three impulses that Tesla hinted at hearing in Colorado - or signals from another experimenter in wireless transmission.

He mentioned them in a letter to reporter Julian Hawthorne at the Philadelphia North American on 8 December 1899 and in a December 1900 letter about possible discoveries in the new century to the Red Cross Society where he referred to messages "from another world" that read "1.... 2.... 3...." Reporters treated it as a sensational story and jumped to the conclusion Tesla was hearing signals from Mars. He expanded on the signals he heard in a 9 February 1901 Collier's Weekly article "Talking With Planets" where he said it had not been immediately apparent to him that he was hearing "intelligently controlled signals" and that the signals could come from Mars, Venus, or other planets. It has been hypothesized that he may have intercepted Marconi's European experiments in July 1899 - Marconi may have transmitted the letter S (dotdotdot) in a naval demonstration, the same three impulses that Tesla hinted at hearing in Colorado - or signals from another experimenter in wireless transmission.

original_text: The Ten Commandments, and the beginnings of the renewed life of Christians accorded to them by the sacrament of baptism, are a present foreshadowing of the believers' future angel-like life in heaven, where there is neither marrying nor giving in marriage. The sacrament of marriage is a present proclamation of the eschatological reality of the Church as the Bride of Christ and the future marriage of the Lamb, a present participation in the joy of the resurrection. Marriage is the union of a man and a woman. God made us male and female. He commanded us to be fruitful and multiply. The marriage of man and woman is the only setting for sexual intercourse, that is, for the procreation and upbringing of children. This is the way God made us. It is not our right to change it. -St. John Chrysostom, Homilies on Ephesians, 20.2 A Christian marriage is the union of a baptized man and a baptized woman, consummated in sexual intercourse. It is a covenant between the spouses before God and the Church. It is intended by God to be indissoluble, and so should only be undertaken with the greatest care, and with the firm intention to remain faithful to one's spouse as long as both shall live. The sacrament of matrimony imparts the grace needed to live faithfully and chastely in marriage. Marriage is an icon of the relationship between Christ and his Church. "For the husband is the head of the wife as Christ is the head of the church, his body, and is himself its Savior. As the church is subject to Christ, so let wives also be subject in everything to their husbands" (Eph 5:23-24). Marriage is also an icon of the relationship between God and his people. He is the loving husband to his bride Israel, and Christ, the new Israel, is the bridegroom who gave himself up for his Church. The Church is also the bride of Christ, and Christ is the bridegroom. Christ is the divine bridegroom of the Church, as God said to Israel, "I will take you for my wife" (Hos 2:19), and as the Church sings, "as a young man marries a virgin, so will your sons marry you; and as the bridegroom rejoices over the bride, so will your God rejoice over you" (Is 62:5). The Holy Scripture, which is completely inspired by God, says: "From the beginning of the creation, God made them male and female. For this cause a man shall leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and they twain shall be one flesh: so then they are no more twain, but one flesh. What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder" (Mark 10:6-9). Marriage is a covenant between the spouses before God and the Church. It is a union of two persons, a man and a woman, both baptized in the Name of the Holy Trinity. It is intended by God to be indissoluble, and so should only be undertaken with the greatest care, and with the firm intention to remain faithful to one's spouse as long as both shall live. Those who marry should marry "in the Lord" (1 Cor. 7:39). They should marry for love, in the fear of God, not out of selfishness or mere desire, and with due consideration for the partner God gives them. The bond of marriage involves three relationships: 1) the relationship of the spouses to each other, 2) the relationship between them and their children, if God grants them any, and 3) the relationship between them and the community of the Church. As in baptism, there is a triple "unity" in marriage. The spouses become "one flesh" (Gen. 2:24). They beget "one" child, who then continues the existence of both parents. Finally, they enter into "one" relationship to the Church and to God. The family is the fundamental unit of society and is an icon of the Church. The family is the first school of Christian love. "The love of husband and wife is the force that welds society together. Men will take up arms and even sacrifice their lives for the sake of this love, yet they will not renounce their sense of honor. It is a splendid thing when man and wife are of one heart and mind. God rejoices at such a sight" (St. John

original_text: The Education Service Contracting scheme of the government provides financial assistance for tuition and other school fees of students turned away from public high schools because of enrollment overflows. The Tuition Fee Supplement is geared to students enrolled in priority courses in post-secondary and non-degree programmes, including vocational and technical courses. The Private Education Student Financial Assistance is made available to underprivileged, but deserving high school graduates, who wish to pursue collegetechnical education in private colleges and universities.
text: The Education Service Contracting scheme of the government provides financial assistance for tuition and other school fees of students turned away from public high schools because of enrollment overflows. The Tuition Fee Supplement is geared to students enrolled in priority courses in post-secondary and non-degree programmes, including vocational and technical courses. The Private Education Student Financial Assistance is made available to underprivileged, but deserving high school graduates, who wish to pursue collegetechnical education in private colleges and universities.

original_text: Super Bowl 50 featured numerous records from individuals and teams. Denver won despite being massively outgained in total yards (315 to 194) and first downs (21 to 11). Their 194 total yards were the fewest for a Super Bowl winner in the game's history. The Panthers 15 rushing yards were also the fewest for a Super Bowl loser. It was also the first Super Bowl to end on an interception, and the only one where the team that had the ball last won. Carolina opened the game with the kickoff and got the ball at their own 20-yard line. They were able to move the ball, but their drive stalled at the Denver 38-yard line and they were forced to punt. The Broncos started their drive from their own 13-yard line and were quickly pushed backwards. Denver punter Britton Colquitt's 45-yard punt was downed at the Carolina 40-yard line by Jordan Norwood. The Panthers went three-and-out and punted the ball back to the Broncos, who started from their own 10-yard line after a 16-yard punt return by Norwood. The Broncos were able to get one first down, but once again they were forced to punt, this time from their own 30-yard line, after Denver quarterback Peyton Manning was sacked on 3rd-and-13. Colquitt's punt was downed at the Carolina 39-yard line by return man Omar Bolden. After a Carolina punt, Denver got the ball at their own 13-yard line with 2:25 left in the quarter. On the first play of the drive, Manning completed a 22-yard pass to tight end Owen Daniels. Two plays later, a 31-yard completion from Manning to wide receiver Demaryius Thomas moved the ball to the Carolina 23-yard line. Kicker Brandon McManus ended the drive with a 34-yard field goal, giving the Broncos a 3-0 lead with 31 seconds left in the first quarter. The Panthers had a great opportunity to score at the beginning of the second quarter, but on a 4th-and-goal from the Denver 1-yard line, quarterback Cam Newton threw an incomplete pass in the end zone, turning the ball over to the Broncos. Denver was unable to move the ball and Manning was sacked on third down, forcing a Colquitt punt that was downed on the Carolina 8-yard line after a 27-yard return by Ted Ginn. Two plays later, a 45-yard completion from Newton to Jerricho Cotchery moved the ball into Broncos territory, and two plays after that, Newton completed a 25-yard pass to wide receiver Corey Brown, giving the Panthers a first down at the Denver 14-yard line. Following two short runs, the Panthers called their second timeout of the game with 58 seconds left in the half. On the next play, Newton completed a 2-yard touchdown pass to tight end Greg Olsen, giving the Panthers a 7-3 lead with 41 seconds left. McManus attempted a 50-yard field goal to send the game into halftime tied, but the kick was no good, and the score remained 7-3 in favor of the Panthers at halftime. The third quarter started with a Carolina punt that was downed at the Denver 12-yard line by punter Brad Nortman. Following an exchange of punts, the Panthers got the ball with great field position when returner Ted Ginn, Jr. returned Colquitt's 43-yard punt 22 yards to the Denver 41-yard line. On the next play, Newton completed a 39-yard pass to Ted Ginn, moving the ball to the Broncos 2-yard line. Three plays later, Jonathan Stewart scored a 2-yard touchdown run, increasing the Panthers lead to 14-3. After a Denver punt, Carolina got the ball on their own 48-yard line. original_text: Luther came to understand justification as entirely the work of God. This teaching by Luther was clearly expressed in his 1525 publication On the Bondage of the Will, which was written in response to On Free Will by Desiderius Erasmus (1524). Luther based his position on predestination on St. Paul's epistle to the Ephesians 2:8-10. Against the teaching of his day that the righteous acts of believers are performed in cooperation with God, Luther wrote that Christians receive such righteousness entirely from outside themselves; that righteousness not only comes from Christ but actually is the righteousness of Christ, imputed to Christians (rather than infused into them) through faith. "That is why faith alone makes someone just and fulfills the law," he wrote. "Faith is that which brings the Holy Spirit through the merits of Christ." Faith, for Luther, was a gift from God; the experience of being justified by faith was "as though I had been born again." His entry into Paradise, no less, was a discovery about "the righteousness of God" - a discovery that "the just person" of whom the Bible speaks (as in Romans 1:17) lives by faith. He explained his concept of "justification" in the Smalcald Articles:

original_text: Doctor Who follows the adventures of the primary character, a rogue Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey, who simply goes by the name "The Doctor." He fled from Gallifrey in a stolen TARDIS, a machine that allows him to travel through time and space. The Doctor often brings along companions, who usually accompany him in the TARDIS. They include humans and aliens. The Doctor has a variety of recurring enemies such as the Daleks, the Cybermen, the Master, Omega, Rassilon, the Black Guardian, and the Rani. The Doctor also encounters new enemies such as the Nestene Consciousness and the Weeping Angels. I liked the idea of going backwards to see how the Doctor started out. I really liked the 11th Doctor, and I wanted to see how he got to be the Doctor. I am still going through the series, so I will write more later.
text: The BBC's Doctor Who is one of the most popular sci-fi television series of all time, and has been broadcast in the United States since 2005.

original_text: The alga Cyanophora, a glaucophyte, is thought to be one of the first organisms to contain a chloroplast. The glaucophyte chloroplast group is the smallest of the three primary chloroplast lineages, being found in only 13 species, and is thought to be the one that branched off the earliest. Glaucophytes have chloroplasts that retain a peptidoglycan wall between their double membranes, like their cyanobacterial parent. For this reason, glaucophyte chloroplasts are also known as muroplasts. Glaucophyte chloroplasts also contain concentric unstacked thylakoids, which surround a carboxysome - an icosahedral structure that glaucophyte chloroplasts and cyanobacteria keep their carbon fixation enzyme rubisco in. The starch that they synthesize collects outside the chloroplast. Like cyanobacteria, glaucophyte chloroplast thylakoids are studded with light collecting structures called phycobilisomes. For these reasons, glaucophyte chloroplasts are considered a primitive intermediate between cyanobacteria and the more evolved chloroplasts in red algae and plants.

This research can be extrapolated to the field to understand metamorphic processes and the conditions of crystallization of igneous rocks. This work can also help to explain processes that occur within the Earth, such as subduction and magma chamber evolution.

original_text: Civil disobedients have chosen a variety of different illegal acts. Bedau writes, "There is a whole class of acts, undertaken in the name of civil disobedience, which, even if they are in some sense illegal, do not involve coercion and are not properly called lawbreaking. These include such acts as trespassing in a federal building, violating curfew, or sitting in a warehouse in the path of a truck to prevent it from unloading its cargo of weapons at a military base.15] Other illegal acts of civil disobedience may involve trespassing, breaking and entering, vandalism, and violation of traffic codes.[16] In the United States, in the 1960s, civil disobedience was used extensively as part of the civil rights movement. Notable examples were the refusal to give up a seat on the bus to a white person (Rosa Parks); sit-ins at cafeterias and lunch counters; marches to allow the entrance of African Americans to universities such as the University of Mississippi; and marches for desegregation, most notably the Birmingham Children's Crusade of 1963 and the Selma to Montgomery marches of 1965. Fundamentally, the American Revolution, the secession of the southern states, and the American Civil War were all cases of civil disobedience. For example, the Colonists had no moral obligation to obey the British Government's laws, but they did have a moral obligation to obey the god of the bible. Thus, the American Revolutionaries acted in civil disobedience when they refused to obey the king's laws and, in the end, seceded from the British Empire. W. R. Bion observed that civilization is based on the 'phantasy that one day the fight will end'.[22] This shows how we have to be willing to accept the fight within ourselves to understand and manage conflict. If we fail to manage conflict and our aggression, it will result in violence. Since its inception, the psychodynamic perspective has focused on the psychological aspect of human aggression. Freud considered civilization to be an achievement in terms of human development but it was achieved at the cost of conflict. Humans have a need to express their aggression. The civilizing process has transformed these primary drives into secondary drives, such as aggression into a controlled form of violence. People are encouraged to control their aggression and direct it towards activities that are seen as socially acceptable, such as sports, war, competition, and hobbies.[23] The term "civil disobedience" was coined by Henry David Thoreau in his essay about resistance to slavery and the Mexican War, and the writing went on to inspire numerous nonviolent resistance movements. Thoreau's essay asks people to recognize their conscience and uphold it. A common misconception is that Thoreau's message was about the immorality of slave ownership. In fact, Thoreau was an abolitionist, but he focused his writings on the injustice of slave ownership. Thoreau recognized that not everyone shared the same moral compass, but he believed that using civil disobedience could provoke the conscience of a nation to move in the direction of justice. Thoreau himself was jailed for his refusal to pay taxes to support the Mexican War, of which he disapproved. He famously said, "I heartily accept the motto, 'That government is best which governs least'; and I should like to see it acted up to more rapidly and systematically. Carried out, it finally amounts to this, which also I believe - 'That government is best which governs not at all'; and when men are prepared for it, that will be the kind of government which they will have.11] Thoreau's theory of civil disobedience influenced the political thoughts and actions of such later figures as Leo Tolstoy, Mohandas Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr. In particular, it stirred the conscience of King, who later wrote his doctoral thesis on Thoreau's concept of civil disobedience. King also noted how one of Thoreau's most famous quotations, "that government is best that governs least," could be interpreted in a way that was not in line with his own ideas. King believed that this quote, despite its seemingly strong libertarian and anarchist overtones, could be interpreted in such a way that the government could become more active and centralized so long as the laws it was passing were in line

original_text: The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine. The cycle is an arrangement of components as is typically used for simple power production, and utilizes the phase change of water (boiling water producing steam, condensing exhaust steam, producing liquid water to provide a practical heatpower conversion system. The heat is supplied externally to a closed loop with some of the heat added being converted to work and the waste heat being removed in a condenser. The Rankine cycle is used in virtually all steam power production applications. In the 1990s, Rankine steam cycles generated about 90 of all electric power used throughout the world, including virtually all solar, biomass, coal and nuclear power plants. It is named after William John Macquorn Rankine, a Scottish polymath.

original_text: Kenya's services sector, which contributes 61 of GDP, is dominated by tourism. The tourism sector has exhibited steady growth in most years since independence and by the late 1980s had become the country's principal source of foreign exchange. Tourism earns more foreign exchange than coffee, tea, and horticulture combined. Kenya's tourism sector has great potential but is currently held back by political instability. In July 2011, Kenya experienced a spike in violence, much of it ethnically motivated, in the wake of contested national elections. While the violence has subsided, investors remain concerned about Kenya's security situation. In 2010, tourist arrivals rebounded from the previous year's depressed levels, but they were below their 2007 levels. Kenya's coast is a popular beach destination, and Mt. Kilimanjaro and the game parks of the eastern and southern interior are key attractions.
