original_text: Throughout the Middle Ages, Newcastle was England's northern fortress. Incorporated first by Henry II, the city had a new charter granted by Elizabeth in 1589. A 25-foot (7.6 m) high stone wall surrounded the town in the 13th century. The Scots king William the Lion was imprisoned in Newcastle in 1174, and Edward I brought the Stone of Scone and William Wallace south through the town. Newcastle was successfully defended in 1640 against a Scottish army during the English Civil War. The city had a number of English Civil War sieges and conflicts, including a 1644 siege by Scottish Covenanters. The city developed as a major coal mining area, and was a major centre of shipbuilding and manufacturing. Heavy engineering contributed significantly to the wealth of the city. In 1882, Newcastle became the seat of an Anglican diocese, with St Nicholas' Church becoming a cathedral. In the 19th century, the city developed as the home of William George Armstrong, Lord Armstrong, the successful Tyneside industrialist whose inventions transformed warfare and the manufacture of armaments. He built the first hydraulic cranes, which were installed on the quayside for unloading collier ships. This resulted in the city becoming a major shipbuilding centre. The population of Newcastle increased rapidly from 1801, as the city developed as the major coal mining area for the Industrial Revolution in Britain. The port developed in the Victorian era, being developed as a major centre for coal mining and export. By 1900, the city was the sixth most productive manufacturing centre in the United Kingdom. During World War II the city and surrounding area were bombed heavily by the German Luftwaffe, suffering 163 air raids in the period 1939-45 and killing 1,141 people. In the post-war period the city's heavy industries went into decline and many jobs were lost. The 1980s saw large-scale regeneration in Newcastle, including the refurbishment of much of the city centre, the opening of the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art, the opening of the MetroCentre, one of the UK's largest shopping centres, and the creation of the NewcastleGateshead Initiative, a joint venture between Newcastle City Council and Gateshead Council to develop the area's economy. The city has hosted the world's most popular half marathon, the Great North Run, since it began in 1981. The city is also known for its Geordie dialect and the Newcastle Brown Ale, the local beer.
text: Newcastle is the largest city in the north-east of England and one of the most important ports in the country. The city developed as a major coal mining area, and was a major centre of shipbuilding and manufacturing.

original_text: Philosophers in antiquity used the concept of force in the study of stationary and moving objects and simple machines, but thinkers such as Aristotle and Archimedes retained fundamental errors in understanding force. In the Middle Ages, thinkers such as John Philoponus applied the laws of Aristotle to objects in motion as well as to the heavens, but errors in understanding fundamental laws of force led to the adoption of "epicycles" by astronomers in order to explain retrograde motion. Buridan and Oresme, in the 14th century, were the first to discard the theory of Aristotle in favor of a more correct theory for the motion of projectiles. This was a major step in the evolution of the modern concept of force. Galileo first used the idea of inertia as describing the motion of objects that happen to be moving: objects that are moving (whether on the ground, or floating in the air, or in interplanetary space) tend to keep moving unless some force causes them to slow down or change direction. Isaac Newton explained this phenomenon by adopting the theory of inertia as a fundamental law of motion: in Newton's words, "Every body continues in its state of rest, or of uniform motion in a right line, unless it is compelled by forces impressed upon it." While Newton originally used the term "force" to describe a cause of motion, he later cleared this up in his work "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy," saying that "the causes I have assigned of the motion of the planets are gravity, regarding the sun as fixed in this treatise, and a certain inherent force, which is in the planet, and draws or drives it continually towards the sun." In this work Newton laid the foundation for what is now called "classical mechanics." It was further developed by other scientists, notably by Pierre-Simon Laplace and William Rowan Hamilton. In classical mechanics, forces still appear in the same role today as they did in earlier times, as explanations of motion and changes in motion. In the 19th century, James Clerk Maxwell, Michael Faraday and others unified the theory of electricity and magnetism into one theory of electromagnetism. In their theory, the fundamental aspects of the forces of electricity and magnetism were seen to be much the same: both exhibited the properties of forces, namely that they can act on matter, transmitted via fields, and can be both attractive and repulsive. At the same time, the understanding of the weak force and strong force were improved, and in the 20th century the electroweak theory unified these two interactions with electromagnetism. Another major development of the 20th century was the introduction of the concept of the fundamental force of nature. In part, this was possible due to the use of Newtonian mechanics in building successful theories of electromagnetism and thermodynamics. In addition, the discovery of radioactivity and nuclear energy showed that the atom was not an elementary particle, but contained smaller constituents: protons, neutrons, and electrons. The electromagnetic force was seen to not only apply to protons and electrons, but to atomic nuclei as well. How was it possible that electrons and protons, considered elementary particles, were subject to a force (the electromagnetic force) while the atoms they formed were not? Early in the 20th century, attempts to answer this paradox led to the postulation of a new particle, the neutrino. However, this proved insufficient to explain the apparent loss of energy in radioactive decay, and the concept of a "force carrier particle" to transmit the force was formulated. This concept was refined to the modern concept of the gauge boson. Finally, through the work of Enrico Fermi, this particle was shown to be not an elementary particle, but a composite of other particles. This set the stage for the modern concept of the fundamental force of nature, and the modern standard model of particle physics was developed. In the 20th century, physics theories considered the existence of a single unified field theory, which would resolve inconsistencies between relativity and quantum mechanics. Einstein sought but failed to find this theory in his last years. It is believed that such a theory would explain the nature of the four fundamental forces (electromagnetic, strong, weak, and gravitational) as different manifestations of a single force. Particle physicists currently describe the four fundamental interactions of nature as the strong interaction, the electromagnetic interaction, the weak interaction and the gravitational interaction. The weak and electromagnetic interactions are responsible for practically all of the phenomena one encoun

original_text: Some of the income was dispensed in the form of aid to other underdeveloped nations whose economies had been caught between higher oil prices and lower prices for their own agricultural exports. OPEC: A cartel of oil-exporting nations formed in the 1970s to regulate the production and price of oil. OPEC, founded in 1960, is an organization of oil-exporting countries that has its headquarters in Vienna, Austria. The current members of OPEC are Algeria, Angola, Ecuador, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Venezuela. OPEC members account for about 40 of global oil production and 75 of the world's "proven" oil reserves, giving OPEC a major influence on global oil prices that has sometimes been controversial. The effect of OPEC's actions can be readily seen by examining the price of oil. The price of oil displayed a long decline from the early 1980s to the mid-1990s, and then a rapid increase to record highs in mid-2008. This price increase triggered a worldwide economic slowdown. The organization was founded in Baghdad, Iraq, by five countries, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela, and it was known then as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. In the 1970s the organization gained its current name and expanded to include Nigeria, Algeria, and Libya, and then in the 1990s, Qatar and Angola. Individual oil-exporting countries have also been known to try to exert their own influence on world oil prices, with the exporters' control over their internal supply generally increasing the price of oil. OPEC's largest producer Saudi Arabia is by far the largest exporter of petroleum in the world. OPEC was formed to unify and coordinate members' petroleum policies. Between 1960 and 1975 the organization expanded to include Qatar (1961), Indonesia (1962), Libya (1962), the United Arab Emirates (1967), Algeria (1969), and Nigeria (1971). Ecuador and Gabon were early members of OPEC, but Ecuador withdrew on December 31, 1992, because it was unwilling or unable to pay a 2 million membership fee and felt that it needed to produce more oil than it was allowed to under the OPEC quota. Similar concerns prompted Gabon to suspend membership in January 1995. Angola joined on the first day of 2007. Norway and Russia have attended OPEC meetings as observers. Individual members within OPEC do not always agree on the best course of action for world oil prices or how to distribute the organization's income. The first of the so-called "oil shocks" occurred in 1973. A few months after the outbreak of the Yom Kippur War, Egypt and Syria attacked Israel and oil-exporting countries in OPEC proclaimed an oil embargo against Canada, Japan, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and the United States, while Arab oil-producing countries also embargoed the United States. Oil prices skyrocketed, and many non-oil-producing countries experienced a major recession. OPEC's actions have also been criticized by other countries. In 2008, the members of the International Energy Agency, which had for years pressured OPEC to increase production to lower prices, accused the organization of not investing enough money in oil exploration. At the same time, there have been calls by American politicians for the federal government to sue OPEC for antitrust violations and treason. African Petroleum Producers' Association: The African Petroleum Producers' Association (or APPA) is an organization of African oil-producing countries. original_text: Private schools, also known as independent schools, non-governmental, or nonstate schools, are not administered by local, state or national governments; thus, they retain the right to select their students and are funded in whole or in part by charging their students tuition, rather than relying on mandatory taxation through public (government) funding; at some private schools students may be able to get a scholarship, which makes the cost cheaper, depending on a talent the student may have (e.g. sport scholarship, art scholarship, academic scholarship), financial need, or tax credit scholarships that might be available. Private schools are sometimes considered "public" because they are usually open to the general public, as opposed to schools restricted to the children of employees of a particular company or those admitted through selective entrance procedures. Admittance to some private schools is often competitive, or the private school may have a religious affiliation. Private schools are not subject to the same accountability or teacher certification requirements as public schools. Private schools are often relatively small when compared to other schools in the area, and this, along with other factors, can lead to higher teacher salaries and a lower teacherstudent ratio. These factors often translate into a superior educational experience when compared to public schools. Private schools also frequently offer a wide variety of extra-curricular activities in addition to a solid core academic program. They are also not subject to the same curriculum restrictions as public schools. One of the big advantages of private schools is the additional funds available for extracurricular activities. Private schools can also be more flexible when it comes to class size. If your child is particularly gifted in a certain area, you may find a private school that offers a curriculum that can challenge your child and further develop her or his talents. Some private schools offer accelerated academic programs, which may include advanced placement classes. Private schools may also provide more personal attention to individual students. The quality of education in private schools can vary widely. Private schools are not subject to the same accountability and teacher certification requirements as public schools. The tuition and other costs associated with a private school can be very high. The quality of private schools can vary widely. The average per-pupil expenditure in private schools in 2002-2003 was 6,601, compared to 8,783 for public schools. This is not surprising considering the fact that most private schools are not government funded. Public schools may offer more extracurricular activities than private schools. original_text: Established originally by the Massachusetts legislature and soon thereafter named for John Harvard (its first benefactor), Harvard is the United States' oldest institution of higher learning, and the Harvard Corporation (formally, the President and Fellows of Harvard College) is its first chartered corporation. Although never formally affiliated with any denomination, the early College primarily trained Congregationalist and Unitarian clergy. Its curriculum and student body were gradually secularized during the 18th century, and by the 19th century Harvard had emerged as the central cultural establishment among Boston elites. Following the American Civil War, President Charles W. Eliot's long tenure transformed the college and affiliated professional schools into a modern research university; Harvard was a founding member of the Association of American Universities in 1900. James Bryant Conant led the university through the Great Depression and World War II and began to reform the curriculum and liberalize admissions after the war. The undergraduate college became coeducational after its 1977 merger with Radcliffe College.

original_text: The first Huguenots to leave France sought freedom from persecution in Switzerland and the Netherlands.[citation needed] A group of Huguenots was part of the French colonisers who arrived in Brazil in 1555 to found France Antarctique. A couple of ships with around 500 people arrived at the Guanabara Bay, present-day Rio de Janeiro, and settled on an island in baia de Guanabara. A fort, named Fort Coligny, was built to protect them from attack from the Portuguese troops and Brazilian natives. It was the first permanent French settlement in the Americas. The French Wars of Religion were primarily fought in France, but the country's Catholic king Henry III also sought to suppress Protestantism in the French royal possessions of Normandy, Brittany, and Guyenne, as well as in Naples (a Kingdom of the House of Anjou) and in Flanders. When the French king Henry IV, who was originally a Huguenot, converted to Catholicism and promulgated the Edict of Nantes (1598), the Huguenots became assimilated into the dominant Catholic population. The French Huguenots, as well as Protestants from northern Europe, eventually developed two unique strains of Protestantism. These were differentiated by their geographic origins. The first was primarily Calvinist and followed the theological tenets set forth by John Calvin in Geneva, Switzerland. It became known as Calvinism. The second was located in central Europe. It followed the teaching of Martin Luther. This was called Lutheranism. In 1715, Louis XIV died and was succeeded by his five-year-old great-grandson, Louis XV. Philosophe Voltaire was a prominent Huguenot. The French Revolution , which started after the middle of the 18th century, saw a new birth of religious persecution. The French Revolution "did not mark an end to persecution of Protestants in France. It in fact simply shifted persecutors. The state, and many elements within it, remained hostile to the Protestant minority.3] The Law of 20 May 1802 made Lutherans, Calvinists and other non-Catholics liable to severe penalties. Many Protestants emigrated or abjured their faith. The Concordat of 1801 ended religious persecution and the re-establishment of Catholicism as a state religion, but not before 6,000 Protestants had been forced to emigrate. The remainder were allowed to continue in their Protestant worship, under the supervision of local priests.[citation needed] The Concordat also stripped Protestants of their special privileges, such as special tax breaks, which placed them on an equal footing with Catholics. The laws separating the clergy from the laity were re-established. The clergy was once again required to be celibate. The Concordat restored much power to the Pope and the Papacy. The Huguenot community in England is one of the best-known of the French Protestant communities in exile, due to their association with the Glorious Revolution of 1688. In the late 17th and early 18th centuries, it was successful in establishing itself with many members of the French aristocracy. The Huguenot cross is an Maltese cross with two interlocking crescents in the center. It is now used as the standard emblem of the Huguenot Society of Great Britain and Ireland. text: The French Huguenots were a group of Protestants who arrived in the Americas in the 15th and 16th centuries to escape the Roman Catholic rule of France.

original_text: Chloroplasts are highly dynamic - they circulate and are moved around within plant cells, and occasionally pinch in two to reproduce. Their behavior is strongly influenced by environmental factors like light color and intensity. Chloroplasts, like mitochondria, contain their own DNA, which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor - a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell. Chloroplasts cannot be made by the plant cell and must be inherited by each daughter cell during cell division.

original_text: The United Methodist Church is organized into conferences. The highest level is called the General Conference and is the only organization which may speak officially for the church. The General Conference is the only body that can create and change the Book of Discipline and the Book of Resolutions, which contain the church's official positions and policies. It meets every four years. The South Georgia Conference is a regional body of The United Methodist Church and includes 700 congregations serving more than 160,000 members. The South Georgia Conference covers the southern part of Georgia. The district is the next level of organization in the church. The South Georgia Conference is divided into nine districts, and each district is served by a superintendent. The South Georgia District includes 138 United Methodist Churches in 11 counties in the southwestern corner of the South Georgia Conference. The church is a connectional organization. The church is local in many ways, but it is also connected to other United Methodist churches throughout the world. It is a connection of people who work together to do the mission and ministry of Jesus Christ. It is a connection of people who care for each other and provide for each other's needs. It is a connection of people who are working together to make disciples of Jesus Christ for the transformation of the world.

original_text: Kenya is a presidential representative democratic republic. The President is both the head of state and head of government, and of a multi-party system. Executive power is exercised by the government. Legislative power is vested in both the government and the National Assembly and the Senate. The Judiciary is independent of the executive and the legislature. The highest elected position in the country is President of Kenya. Kenya's current president is Mwai Kibaki. The current Prime Minister is Raila Odinga. Kenya is a member of the United Nations, the Commonwealth of Nations, the East African Community, the African Union, and the World Trade Organization. In 2008 the government of Kenya adopted a new constitution, which will be implemented in stages. Among the first provisions to be implemented was the establishment of a second house of parliament (the Senate). The first election to this house was held in March 2013. The new constitution also brings about the division of the former single post of Attorney General into the Office of the Attorney General and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Further information on Kenya's government can be found at . The current president of Kenya is Mwai Kibaki. Kenya's current prime minister is Raila Odinga. Kenya has a National Assembly and a Senate. The Senate is the second house of parliament and has 68 elected and six nominated members. The Senate was established following the promulgation of a new constitution in 2010. The first elections to the Senate took place in March 2013. The National Assembly has 349 elected members.
text: Kenya is one of Africa's largest democracies, with a population of more than 46 million people. Kenya's current prime minister is Raila Odinga.

In many situations teachers in publicly funded schools must be members in good standing with the college, and private schools may also require their teachers to be college peoples. In other areas these roles may belong to the State Board of Education, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the State Education Agency or other governmental bodies. In still other areas Teaching Unions may be responsible for some or all of these duties.

original_text: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism." Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

Among the events worth particular attention are: the International Frederic Chopin Piano Competition, the International Contemporary Music Festival Warsaw Autumn, the Jazz Jamboree, Warsaw Summer Jazz Days, the International Stanislaw Moniuszko Vocal Competition, the Mozart Festival, and the Festival of Old Music.
text: Thanks to numerous musical venues, including the Teatr Wielki, the Polish National Opera, the Chamber Opera, the National Philharmonic Hall and the National Theatre, as well as the Roma and Buffo music theatres and the Congress Hall in the Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw hosts many events and festivals. Among the events worth particular attention are: the International Frederic Chopin Piano Competition, the International Contemporary Music Festival Warsaw Autumn, the Jazz Jamboree, Warsaw Summer Jazz Days, the International Stanislaw Moniuszko Vocal Competition, the Mozart Festival, and the Festival of Old Music.

original_text: Some theories of civil disobedience hold that civil disobedience is only justified against governmental entities. Brownlee argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of non-governmental agencies such as trade unions is also justified. Brownlee discusses two hypothetical cases. In the first, a union strike breaks out against the wishes of the majority of union members. In the second, an employer refuses to follow a union's recommendation to recognize the union as the exclusive bargaining agent for its employees. In both cases, the strike is against a non-governmental entity. Brownlee concludes that civil disobedience can be justified in both cases.
text: Civil disobedience can be justified against non-governmental entities, according to the author, who argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of trade unions is also justified. Brownlee argues that disobeying a governmental entity is not only justified against governmental entities.

original_text: Oxygen was discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, in Uppsala, in 1773 or earlier, and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire, in 1774, but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first. The name oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier, whose experiments with oxygen helped to discredit the then-popular phlogiston theory of combustion and corrosion. Its name derives from the Greek roots oxus oxys, "acid," literally "sharp," referring to the sour taste of acids and -genes -genes, "producer," literally "begetter," because at the time of naming, it was mistakenly thought that all acids required oxygen in their composition. Common uses of oxygen includes the production cycle of steel, plastics and textiles, brazing, welding and cutting of steels and other metals, rocket propellant, in oxygen therapy and life support systems in aircraft, submarines, spaceflight and diving.

original_text: The IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) published in 2007 featured a graph showing 12 proxy based temperature reconstructions, including the three highlighted in the 2001 Third Assessment Report (TAR); Mann, Bradley and Hughes (1999, MBH99), Jones et al. (1998, J98) and Briffa (2000). The Briffa reconstruction was highlighted in AR4 with a red line. The TAR had shown the original version of the Briffa reconstruction, based on 15 long-lived trees from a remote Siberian site, as extending to 1980. The new version shown in AR4 was truncated, ending in 1960, thus omitting the post-1960 decline. The AR4 Chapter 6 text falsely stated that Briffa (2000) had shown the late 20th century decline as "within the range of reconstructed variability over recent millennia." In fact, the decline was not "within the range"; it was at the very bottom of the reconstruction. The truncated Briffa reconstruction was shown on the spaghetti graph in the AR4 without its provenance being indicated. As the graphic was very similar to a graphic in the earlier Jones et al. (1999, J99) paper, it could be supposed that the same data had been used. The Briffa reconstruction was also shown in an earlier version of the AR4 without its provenance being indicated. This version of the AR4 featured a second spaghetti graph, which was not in the final version. The AR4 also featured a graphic of the divergence of the Briffa reconstruction from the modern instrumental record, captioned "Briffa et al. (2001) estimated the variability of the real temperature history from a long tree-ring chronology in northern Russia. The instrumental record is shown for comparison and recent warming is clear. The apparent decline over recent decades in this tree-ring temperature history is likely to be an artifact of sampling." The text falsely described the divergence as being from the "real temperature history" when the divergence was from a reconstruction. The graphic falsely implied that the "recent warming" was clear in the Briffa reconstruction, when it was not even visible. The graphic contained a link to a paper by Briffa, Osborn and Schweingruber (2004, BOS04), which included a graph similar to that in the AR4. AR4 also referred to the divergence in the text of the IPCC Working Group I Fourth Assessment Report. The text stated: "New data sets (updating the original work by Briffa et al., 1998, 2001) now exist that allow a longer tree-ring based reconstruction (Osborn and Briffa, 2006) that shows the existence of a 'Little Ice Age' and 'Medieval Warm Period' in the extra-tropical NH similar to those found in the Jones et al. (1998) reconstruction, but with larger amplitude. This new reconstruction agrees well with the multiproxy reconstructions presented in Figure 6.10. As noted in Section 6.6.1, high-latitude tree-ring density data show a positive correlation with summer temperatures, but a negative correlation with growing season precipitation and this appears to apply to the Tornetrask data (Briffa et al., 2001) ." The reference to Osborn and Briffa (2006) was incorrect, since that paper showed neither a "Little Ice Age" nor a "Medieval Warm Period" in the extra-tropical NH. The Osborn and Briffa paper referred to the divergence, stating that "there is increasing evidence of a breakdown in the ability of these proxies to track low-frequency variations in temperature at some sites. An important consequence of this "divergence," particularly in high-latitude regions, is that a progressively worse match is obtained between observed temperature and reconstructions based on the tree-ring data" and that "we apply a simple "correction" for this effect, where the difference between observed and proxy-based temperatures are defined as the correction to be added to the proxy data to linearly "correct" the data so as to better align them with the observed temperature series.
text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has been accused of misleading the public about the extent of the late 20th century decline in global temperatures.

original_text: Following their loss in the divisional round of the previous season's playoffs, the Denver Broncos underwent numerous coaching changes, including a mutual parting with head coach John Fox (who had guided the team to a 49-22 regular season record and four divisional titles in his four seasons with the team) in favor of Gary Kubiak. Kubiak's offensive system was geared toward a power running game and playing with a strong defense, which was reflected in the team's draft picks in the 2015 NFL Draft. The team selected offensive tackle Ty Sambrailo in the second round and defensive end Shane Ray in the first round, and the Broncos then signed free agent defensive endoutside linebacker DeMarcus Ware. The Broncos also signed free agents safety Darian Stewart, cornerback Aqib Talib, and quarterback Mark Sanchez. The Broncos then traded away starting quarterback Peyton Manning and Brock Osweiler to the Houston Texans and the Cleveland Browns, respectively. Denver would begin the season with a 5-2 record, but they would later lose three consecutive games to the Indianapolis Colts, Kansas City Chiefs, and Detroit Lions, respectively. After the loss to the Lions, the Broncos would win seven consecutive games to finish the season, the last of which was a 27-20 victory over the San Diego Chargers in Week 17. With the win, the Broncos earned the AFC West title and the number one seed in the AFC playoffs. The Broncos clinched the top seed after the Cincinnati Bengals defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers 18-16 in Week 17. The Broncos also tied an NFL record of most consecutive games with 300 total yards, dating back to Week 3 of the 2014 season. The Broncos defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers 23-16 in the Divisional Round and the New England Patriots 20-18 in the AFC Championship, advancing to Super Bowl 50. The Broncos defeated the Carolina Panthers 24-10 in Super Bowl 50 for their third NFL title. With the win, the Broncos became the first team since the 1972 Miami Dolphins to win the Super Bowl with a losing record at home during the regular season. The Broncos were the first 1 seed in the AFC playoffs to win the Super Bowl since the 2003 New England Patriots. The Broncos were coming off of a 43-8 loss to the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl XLVIII. For the first time since 2006, John Fox was not with the Broncos after accepting a job as the head coach of the Chicago Bears. Under Fox, the Broncos went 49-22 (.690) in the regular season and 5-4 (.556) in the playoffs. On January 11, 2015, John Elway hired Gary Kubiak to be the 15th head coach in franchise history. Elway and Kubiak previously worked together from 1983 to 1991, where Kubiak was the backup quarterback to Elway. As the Broncos' offensive coordinator from 1995 to 2005, Kubiak coached Pro Bowl players such as Hall of Fame running back Terrell Davis, Hall of Fame quarterback John Elway, Pro Bowl quarterbacks Jake Plummer and Brian Griese, as well as Pro Bowl wide receiver Rod Smith. In 2006, Kubiak was hired as the head coach of the Houston Texans, where he spent eight seasons with the team. Among Kubiak's assistant coaches were Wade Phillips (defensive coordinator), Joe DeCamillis (special teams coordinator), Adam Gase (offensive coordinator), Rick Dennison (quarterbacks coach), Clancy Pendergast (linebackers coach), Reggie Herring (defensive line coach), Tyke Tolbert (wide receivers coach), Bill Kollar (defensive line coach), Brian Pariani (tight ends coach), Jeff Davidson (offensive line coach), and Bobby Turner (running backs coach). Peyton Manning and the Broncos offense huddling in a game against the Oakland Raiders. The Broncos entered the 2015 NFL Draft with nine selections, including two compensatory picks. On April 30, 2

original_text: Many of the farms in the Western Cape province in South Africa still bear French names. Many families, today mostly Afrikaans-speaking, have surnames indicating their French Huguenot ancestry. Examples include: Blignaut, Cilliers, de Klerk (Le Clercq), de Villiers, du Plessis, Du Preez (Des Pres), du Randt (Durand), du Toit, Duvenhage (Du Vinage), Franck, Fouche, Fourie (Fleurit), Gervais, Giliomee (Guilliaume), GousGouws (Gauch), Hugo, Jordaan (Jourdan), Joubert, Kriek, Labuschagne (la Buscagne), le Roux, Lombard, Malan, Malherbe, Marais, Maree, Minnaar (Mesnard), Nel (Nell),Naude', Nortje (Nortier), Pienaar (Pinard), Retief (Retif), Rossouw (Rousseau), Taljaard (Taillard), TerBlanche, Theron, Viljoen (Villion) and Visagie (Visage). The wine industry in South Africa owes a significant debt to the Huguenots, some of whom had vineyards in France, or were brandy distillers, and used their skills in their new home.

original_text: Other important complexity classes include BPP, ZPP and RP, which are defined using probabilistic Turing machines; AC and NC, which are defined using Boolean circuits; and BQP and QMA, which are defined using quantum computers. Complexity theory is a branch of the theory of computation in theoretical computer science and mathematics that focuses on classifying computational problems according to their inherent difficulty, and relating those classes to each other. A computational problem is understood to be a task that is in principle amenable to being solved by a computer. A description of the problem is an algorithm. The theory formalizes this intuition, by introducing mathematical models of computation to study these problems. In doing so, it has broadened the classical theory of computation by allowing for more complex models of computation that are more suited for studying computation in the real world. It has also led to the development of new concepts such as cryptographic protocols (which have practical applications), and more efficient data structures. A problem is regarded as inherently difficult if its solution requires significant resources, whatever the algorithm used. The theory formalizes this intuition by introducing mathematical models of computation to study these problems and relating the resource use of algorithms and problem complexity. A computational problem can be solved by a Turing machine, which is a mathematical model of a general-purpose computer that has an infinite memory and is able to manipulate symbols, perform logical operations, and move back and forth through its memory. An algorithm is a precise list of well-defined instructions for completing a task from a given initial state, using a finite amount of time and space. An example of such an algorithm is the sieve of Eratosthenes for finding prime numbers. A problem is regarded as inherently difficult if its solution requires significant resources, whatever the algorithm used. The theory formalizes this intuition by introducing mathematical models of computation to study these problems and relating the resource use of algorithms and problem complexity. The theory formalizes this intuition by introducing mathematical models of computation to study these problems and relating the resource use of algorithms and problem complexity. A formal definition of "difficulty" is given by the concept of a computational problem. A problem is simply a question that can be asked about an input, along with an acceptable answer. A decision problem is a problem where the output is either "yes" or "no." A function problem is a problem where the output is a specific (but not necessarily unique) string of bits of a specific length. Thus, a computational problem can be viewed as a mathematical function. A formal definition of "difficulty" is given by the concept of a computational problem. original_text: The main gallery was redesigned in 1994, the glass balustrade on the staircase and mezzanine are the work of Danny Lane, the gallery covering contemporary glass opened in 2004 and the sacred silver and stained-glass gallery in 2005. In this latter gallery stained glass is displayed alongside silverware starting in the 12th century and continuing to the present. Some of the most outstanding stained glass, dated 1243-48 comes from the Sainte-Chapelle, is displayed along with other examples in the new Medieval Renaissance galleries. The important 13th-century glass beaker known as the Luck of Edenhall is also displayed in these galleries. Examples of British stained glass are displayed in the British Galleries. One of the most spectacular items in the collection is the chandelier by Dale Chihuly in the rotunda at the Museum's main entrance.

original_text: Although the European Union does not have a codified constitution, like every political body it has laws which "constitute" its basic governance structure. The EU's primary constitutional sources are the European Communities (EC) primary law treaties. The same treaties have been used throughout the history of European integration to incrementally build the EU's political structure from the original European Economic Community formed by the Treaty of Rome in 1957. The treaties establish the EU's supranational institutions, declare the general aims and values of the EU, define the powers of each EU institution and lay out the rules and procedures by which they must operate. 1 Founding treaties 1.1 The EU's legal personality 1.2 Aims and principles 2 New member states 3 Other treaties 3.1 Consolidated treaties 3.2 Other agreements 4 Amending treaties Founding treaties The European Economic Community (EEC) was established by the 1957 Treaty of Rome, which "forged a new special relationship between European States on the basis of common economic interests.1] Although the EEC Treaty had provided for a common set of institutions along with policies that would support the objective of a common market, the development of the Community relied on unanimity and majority voting with the consequent need to seek compromise and common ground in order to maintain the necessary unity amongst its members. The 1992 Maastricht Treaty established the European Union (EU) on the foundations of the European Communities. The three European Communities (EC) - the European Coal and Steel Community, the European Economic Community and the European Atomic Energy Community - are continued in the European Union under the same name of "European Communities." The EU has been compared to a federal system of governance. However, the EU is not a federal state. Unlike a federal state, the member states of the EU only transfer some limited powers to the EU and all the rest of the powers remain with the member states. Also, the member states of the EU cannot be considered the constituent states of a federal state. While member states of a federation are subdivisions of the federal state, which is constituted by them, the member states of the EU are not subdivisions of the EU. The EU is also unique in having a three-pillar structure, with a number of areas of joint competence. The EU's legal personality The treaties have been amended by other treaties over the 50 years since they were signed. However, it was not until the Maastricht Treaty that the term European Community (EC) was replaced by European Union (EU) to reflect the much greater degree of integration of member states that was by then taking place. The Maastricht Treaty established the three pillars of the European Union. The first pillar was common foreign and security policy (CFSP) and the second was co-operation in justice and home affairs (JHA), while the third remained the European Communities (EC) pillar which continued to be the main source of power for the EU. The treaty also provided the basis for the creation of the euro. The name European Economic Community was replaced by European Community with the signing of the Maastricht Treaty. In 2002 the Treaty of Paris which established the EC was abolished and the term European Community ceased to exist. The Treaty of Lisbon merged the JHA and EC pillars, as well as repealing the term European Community.

original_text: In addition to climate assessment reports, the IPCC is publishing Special Reports on specific topics. The preparation and approval process for all IPCC Special Reports follows the same procedures as for IPCC Assessment Reports. In the year 2011 two IPCC Special Report were finalized, the Special Report on Renewable Energy Sources and Climate Change Mitigation (SRREN) and the Special Report on Managing Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation (SREX). Both Special Reports were requested by governments.
text: In addition to climate assessment reports, the IPCC is publishing Special Reports on specific topics. The preparation and approval process for all IPCC Special Reports follows the same procedures as for IPCC Assessment Reports. In the year 2011 two IPCC Special Report were finalized, the Special Report on Renewable Energy Sources and Climate Change Mitigation (SRREN) and the Special Report on Managing Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation (SREX). Both Special Reports were requested by governments.

In his Address To The Christian Nobility Of The German Nation he argued that Christians should "Buy" indulgences for other believers in purgatory, but not for themselves, since faith alone, not good works, is sufficient to attain salvation. He also argued that the Gospel did not need the Pope's approval: "For the true treasure of the church is the most holy gospel of the glory and grace of God." The Catholic Church taught that the Pope had the power to forgive people for their sins, and the Pope would grant that forgiveness, in the form of a document known as an indulgence, which would allow the forgiven person to go to heaven. In order to earn an indulgence, one had to perform good deeds, such as giving money to the church. One of the good deeds one could do was give money to the church in order to build St. Peter's Basilica, so that the Pope would have a new, grand church in which to hold masses. Luther argued that faith, not good works, was sufficient to gain salvation. He also argued that one should not need to give money to the church in order to go to heaven. His argument became very popular in Germany, and many people agreed with him. Many people in Germany had been concerned about corruption in the Catholic Church, including the selling of indulgences, so Luther's argument was very popular with them. Luther was called before the Diet of Worms (a meeting of the Holy Roman Empire's leaders) to defend his teachings. The meeting was held in Worms, Germany, in the year 1521. Luther defended himself before the meeting, but his arguments were rejected by the meeting's leaders. In spite of his failure to convince the Diet, Luther's argument was very popular in Germany, and it soon became widely believed that faith was more important than good works, and that indulgences should not be sold. Excommunication meant that Luther was now no longer a monk, and no longer part of the Catholic Church. However, Luther's teachings became popular in Germany, and many Germans supported him, including several of the princes of the German states. original_text: In 1226, immediately after returning from the west, Genghis Khan began a retaliatory attack on the Tanguts. His armies quickly took Heisui, Ganzhou, and Suzhou (not the Suzhou in Jiangsu province), which had been in Xia hands for only five years. By the end of 1227, the Xia had been pushed back to their original border of the Yellow River. At this point, Genghis Khan faced a dilemma: whether to continue his attack on the Xia or to turn west to fight the Western Xia. Genghis Khan decided to attack the Western Xia, but before he left, he appointed his third son, Tolui, as the commander in chief of the operations against the Xia. Tolui was given 50,000 troops, and he was ordered to continue the attack on the Xia capital city, Yinchuan. Tolui reached the outskirts of Yinchuan in 1228, but he was not strong enough to take the city. Tolui was ordered by his father to withdraw his army, leaving only a small garrison at Heisui to maintain a presence on the Yellow River. In 1229, Genghis Khan's campaign against the Western Xia ended with their annihilation. In 1230, he returned to Mongolia, leaving Tolui behind to continue the campaign against the Xia. Tolui's army was now stationed in Heisui, and he was reinforced by a large army under the command of his brother, Kadan, who had just returned from a successful campaign against the Jin in the north. In 1232, the combined Mongol forces began the final assault on the Xia capital. They crossed the Yellow River and were joined by the remnants of Xia resistance in the border area. The two armies marched to Yinchuan and laid siege to the city. The city was surrounded and all the roads leading to it were blocked. Yinchuan was defended by the Xia emperor, Emperor Mozhu, who was a brilliant military strategist. He had successfully defended the city against the Khitans for eight years in the past, but this time, the city fell in 1233. Emperor Mozhu surrendered, and the Mongols ended their 34-year campaign against the Xia.

original_text: When finally Edward the Confessor returned from his father's refuge in 1041, at the invitation of his half-brother Harthacnut, he brought with him a Norman-educated mind. He also brought many Norman counsellors and fighters, some of whom established an English cavalry force. This concept never really took root, but it is a typical example of the attitudes of Edward. He appointed Robert of Jumieges archbishop of Canterbury and made Ralph the Timid earl of Hereford. He invited his brother-in-law Eustace II, Count of Boulogne to his court in 1051, an event which resulted in the greatest of early conflicts between Saxon and Norman and ultimately resulted in the exile of Earl Godwin of Wessex.

original_text: Throughout the 18th century, Enlightenment ideas of the power of reason and free will became widespread among Congregationalist ministers, putting those ministers and their congregations in tension with more traditionalist, Calvinist parties.:1-4 When the Hollis Professor of Divinity David Tappan died in 1803 and the president of Harvard Joseph Willard died a year later, in 1804, a struggle broke out over their replacements. Henry Ware was elected to the chair in 1805, and the liberal Samuel Webber was appointed to the presidency of Harvard two years later, which signaled the changing of the tide from the dominance of traditional ideas at Harvard to the dominance of liberal, Arminian ideas (defined by traditionalists as Unitarian ideas).:4-5:24

original_text: In addition to chlorophylls, another group of yellow-orange pigments called carotenoids are also found in the photosystems. There are about thirty photosynthetic carotenoids. They help transfer and dissipate excess energy, and their bright colors sometimes override the chlorophyll green, like during the fall, when the leaves of some land plants change color. b-carotene is a bright red-orange carotenoid found in nearly all chloroplasts, like chlorophyll a. Xanthophylls, especially the orange-red zeaxanthin, are also common. Many other forms of carotenoids exist that are only found in certain groups of chloroplasts.
text: In addition to chlorophylls, another group of yellow-orange pigments called carotenoids are also found in the photosystems. There are about thirty photosynthetic carotenoids. They help transfer and dissipate excess energy, and their bright colors sometimes override the chlorophyll green, like during the fall, when the leaves of some land plants change color. b-carotene is a bright red-orange carotenoid found in nearly all chloroplasts, like chlorophyll a. Xanthophylls, especially the orange-red zeaxanthin, are also common. Many other forms of carotenoids exist that are only found in certain groups of chloroplasts.

original_text: For most of human history higher material living standards - full stomachs, access to clean water and warmth from fuel - led to better health and longer lives. This pattern of higher incomes-longer lives still holds among poorer countries, where life expectancy increases rapidly as per capita income increases, but in recent decades it has slowed down among middle income countries and plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world. Americans live no longer on average (about 77 years in 2004) than Greeks (78 years) or New Zealanders (78), though the USA has a higher GDP per capita. Life expectancy in Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82) - where income was more equally distributed - was longer.
text: For most of human history higher material living standards - full stomachs, access to clean water and warmth from fuel - led to better health and longer lives. This pattern of higher incomes-longer lives still holds among poorer countries, where life expectancy increases rapidly as per capita income increases, but in recent decades it has slowed down among middle income countries and plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world. Americans live no longer on average (about 77 years in 2004) than Greeks (78 years) or New Zealanders (78), though the USA has a higher GDP per capita. Life expectancy in Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82) - where income was more equally distributed - was longer.

original_text: With Istanbul as its capital and control of lands around the Mediterranean basin, the Ottoman Empire was at the center of interactions between the Eastern and Western worlds for six centuries. Following a long period of military setbacks against European powers, the Ottoman Empire gradually declined into the late nineteenth century. The empire allied with Germany in the early 20th century, with the imperial ambition of recovering its lost territories, but it dissolved in the aftermath of World War I, leading to the emergence of the new state of Turkey in the Ottoman Anatolian heartland, as well as the creation of modern Balkan and Middle Eastern states, thus ending Turkish colonial ambitions.

original_text: Another important library - the University Library, founded in 1816, is home to over two million items. The building was designed by architects Marek Budzynski and Zbigniew Badowski and opened on 15 December 1999. It is surrounded by green. The University Library garden, designed by Irena Bajerska, was opened on 12 June 2002. It is one of the largest and most beautiful roof gardens in Europe with an area of more than 10,000 m2 (107,639.10 sq ft), and plants covering 5,111 m2 (55,014.35 sq ft). As the university garden it is open to the public every day.

original_text: The results of the Haensch study have since been confirmed and amended. Based on genetic evidence derived from Black Death victims in the East Smithfield burial site in England, Schuenemann et al. concluded in 2011 "that the Black Death in medieval Europe was caused by a variant of Y. pestis that may no longer exist." A study published in Nature in October 2011 sequenced the genome of Y. pestis from plague victims and indicated that the strain that caused the Black Death is ancestral to most modern strains of the disease.
text: The results of the Haensch study have since been confirmed and amended. Based on genetic evidence derived from Black Death victims in the East Smithfield burial site in England, Schuenemann et al. concluded in 2011 "that the Black Death in medieval Europe was caused by a variant of Y. pestis that may no longer exist." A study published in Nature in October 2011 sequenced the genome of Y. pestis from plague victims and indicated that the strain that caused the Black Death is ancestral to most modern strains of the disease.

original_text: A function problem is a computational problem where a single output (of a total function) is expected for every input, but the output is more complex than that of a decision problem, that is, it isn't just yes or no. Notable examples include the traveling salesman problem and the integer factorization problem.
text: A function problem is a computational problem where a single output (of a total function) is expected for every input, but the output is more complex than that of a decision problem, that is, it isn't just yes or no. Notable examples include the traveling salesman problem and the integer factorization problem.

original_text: As well as being added, forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other. A horizontal force pointing northeast can therefore be split into two components pointing north and east respectively. The component pointing north is at 45 degrees to the horizontal. The resultant of the two resolved forces is the diagonal of the rectangle drawn to enclose them. This is the resolution of a horizontal force into components pointing north and east. This is the resolution of a force pointing at an angle of 45 degrees. Resolution of a force pointing at an angle of 60 degrees. This is the resolution of a force pointing at an angle of 30 degrees. This is the resolution of a force pointing at an angle of 15 degrees. As in addition, the vertical and horizontal components of the two forces are equal in magnitude. This is the resultant of a force of 100 N at 45 degrees. This is the resultant of a force of 100 N at 30 degrees. This is the resultant of a force of 100 N at 60 degrees. This is the resultant of a force of 100 N at 15 degrees. The two components of this resultant are 50 N at 45 degrees and 50 N at 135 degrees. The two components of this resultant are 50 N at 30 degrees and 50 N at 150 degrees. The two components of this resultant are 50 N at 60 degrees and 50 N at 120 degrees. The two components of this resultant are 50 N at 15 degrees and 50 N at 165 degrees.
text: A force can be added to a rectangle by drawing a line from the centre of the rectangle to the point at which the force is added. The two components of this resultant are 50 N at 30 degrees and 50N at 150 degrees.

original_text: In 1096, Crusaders passing by the siege of Amalfi were joined by Bohemond of Taranto and his nephew Tancred with an army of Italo-Normans. Bohemond was the de facto leader of the Crusade during its passage through Asia Minor. After the successful Siege of Antioch in 1097, Bohemond began carving out an independent principality around that city. Tancred was instrumental in the conquest of Jerusalem and he worked for the expansion of the Crusader kingdom in Transjordan and the region of Galilee.[citation needed]

original_text: One of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis, the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy, to subsequently produce food in the form of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. The chloroplast is a double membrane organelle. The inner membrane is folded into infoldings, called thylakoids, that contain photosynthetic pigments. The process of photosynthesis occurs in two stages called the light reactions and the dark reactions. The light reactions consist of the collection of light energy and its conversion into chemical energy. The dark reactions consist of the production of glucose from carbon dioxide and water. The light reactions take place in the thylakoid membranes of the chloroplast. The dark reactions take place in the stroma. The first step in photosynthesis is the absorption of light by a chlorophyll pigment called chlorophyll a. Chlorophyll a is located in the thylakoid membrane and is the site of light absorption. The energy absorbed by the chlorophyll is used to split water into its two components, hydrogen ions and oxygen. The oxygen is released into the atmosphere. The hydrogen ions are stored in the thylakoid membrane. Next, an electron is transferred from the chlorophyll a pigment to a pigment called pheophytin. The energy gained by the pheophytin is transferred to an electron acceptor molecule called quinone. The quinone is reduced by the electron and becomes a new molecule, called plastoquinone. The oxygen that was released in the light reaction is used as an electron acceptor by the plastoquinone. This process is called the cyclic reaction and is part of the light reactions. The cyclic reaction occurs in the thylakoid membrane, where there are many pigments. The energy gained by the pigments is stored in the thylakoid membrane. The plastoquinone is now oxidized to its original form, and the cycle begins again. During the cyclic reaction, the thylakoid membrane becomes positively charged. In the stroma, there is another pigment called chlorophyll b. This pigment is located in the stroma, not in the thylakoid membrane, and absorbs a different wavelength of light than chlorophyll a. The energy absorbed by the chlorophyll b is used to reduce NADP to NADPH. The NADPH is used in the stroma in the dark reaction. The electrons that were stored in the thylakoid membrane are used in the stroma in the dark reaction. The electrons are transferred from the thylakoid membrane to the stroma. As a result, the NADPH and plastoquinone in the stroma are reduced. NADPH and plastoquinone are used to form glucose in the stroma in the dark reaction. A good thing to remember is that chlorophyll a is found in the thylakoid membrane. The light reactions occur in the thylakoid membrane. Chlorophyll b is found in the stroma. The dark reactions occur in the stroma.
text: One of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis, the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy, to subsequently produce food in the form of carbohydrates, fats and proteins. The chloroplast is a double membrane organelle. The inner membrane is folded into infoldings, called thylakoids, that contain photosynthetic pigments. The process of photosynthesis occurs in two stages called the light reactions and the dark reactions. The light reactions consist of the collection of light energy and its conversion into chemical energy. The dark reactions consist of the production of glucose from carbon dioxide and water. The light reactions take place in the thylakoid membranes of the chloroplast. The dark reactions take place in the stroma. The first step in photosynthesis is the absorption of light by a chlorophyll pigment called chlorophyll a. Chlorophyll a is located in the thylakoid membrane and is the site of light absorption. The energy absorbed by the chlorophyll is used to split water into its two components, hydrogen ions and oxygen. The oxygen is released into the atmosphere. The hydrogen ions are stored in the thylakoid membrane. Next, an electron is transferred from the chlorophyll a pigment to a pigment called pheophytin. The energy gained by the pheophytin is transferred to an electron acceptor molecule called quinone. The quinone is reduced by the electron and becomes a new molecule, called plastoquinone. The oxygen that was released in the light reaction is used as an electron acceptor by the plastoquinone. This process is called the cyclic reaction and is part of the light reactions. The cyclic reaction occurs in the thylakoid membrane, where there are many pigments. The energy gained by the pigments is stored in the thylakoid membrane. The plastoquinone is now oxidized to its original form, and the cycle begins again. During the cyclic reaction, the thylakoid membrane becomes positively charged. In the stroma, there is another pigment called chlorophyll b. This pigment is located in the stroma, not in the thylakoid membrane, and absorbs a different wavelength of light than chlorophyll a. The energy absorbed by the chlorophyll b is used to reduce NADP to NADPH. The NADPH is used in the stroma in the dark reaction. The electrons that were stored in the thylakoid membrane are used in the stroma in the dark reaction. The electrons are transferred from the thylakoid membrane to the stroma. As a result, the NADPH and plastoquinone in the stroma are reduced. NADPH and plastoquinone are used to form glucose in the stroma in the dark reaction. A good thing to remember is that chlorophyll a is found in the thylakoid membrane. The light reactions occur in the thylakoid membrane. Chlorophyll b is found in the stroma. The dark reactions occur in the stroma.

original_text: The War of the Austrian Succession (whose North American theater is known as King George's War) formally ended in 1748 with the signing of the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle. The treaty gave the British many of the concessions they had been fighting for, while the French managed to retain a few key concessions in India. The 1750s saw war loom once more on the horizon. The main antagonists were the same, but by this time, the French and British colonies were both expanding into the Ohio River valley, and clashes between British colonists and French troops were increasingly frequent. In 1756, the Seven Years' War (known as the French and Indian War in North America) began. The French and Indian War was a conflict between the colonies of France and Britain, with their native American allies. Many of the battles took place in North America, although the conflict was essentially a European one, fought in several other theaters around the world. The war began with a series of French victories. The French captured several of Britain's Caribbean islands, and overwhelmed a large force under General Edward Braddock at the Battle of the Monongahela (July 9, 1755). However, the war would ultimately be decided in North America. The French lost control of the Ohio River valley at the Battle of the Monongahela in 1755, and British general James Wolfe captured Quebec in 1759. At the same time, British Admiral Edward Hawke won a decisive naval victory over a French fleet in the Battle of Quiberon Bay, giving the British complete control of the seas. In 1760, a force of British troops and colonists captured Montreal, effectively ending the war. France was forced to cede Canada and much of Louisiana to Britain. France's only consolation was that Spain agreed to exchange Florida for Cuba. This was a consolation because it meant that France was able to maintain its colony of Saint-Domingue (Haiti), which was a rich sugar producer and had become an important trading partner of France. The Seven Years' War was a watershed in the history of North America. France's defeat ended its ambitions to expand its empire in North America and left Britain as the dominant colonial power in North America. The British, however, were left with a huge debt from the war. This would eventually lead to taxation of the colonies, which would set the stage for the American Revolution. The Seven Years' War had a profound effect on the British colonies, which, for the first time, found themselves involved in a European-style war on their own soil. Many colonists took part in the war, and, for the first time, British officers were forced to rely on the militia to a large extent. This was a factor in a change in the way that British officers viewed the militia. Although the militia had performed well in several key battles (such as the Battle of Quebec), it was difficult to maintain discipline among the militia and they were not always available when needed. This led to a change in the way that the militia was regarded by the British army, and a shift in the way that it would be used in later conflicts.
text: The French and Indian War was a conflict between the French colonies of France and Britain, with their native American allies, which took place in several other theaters around the world.

original_text: Many types of Turing machines are used to define complexity classes, such as deterministic Turing machines, probabilistic Turing machines, non-deterministic Turing machines, quantum Turing machines, symmetric Turing machines and alternating Turing machines. They are all equally powerful in principle, but when resources (such as time or space) are bounded, some of these may be more powerful than others.

original_text: The owner produces a list of requirements for a project, giving an overall view of the project's goals. Several DB contractors present different ideas about how to accomplish these goals. The owner selects the ideas he or she likes best and hires the appropriate contractor. Often, it is not just one contractor, but a consortium of several contractors working together. Once these have been hired, they begin building the first phase of the project. As they build phase 1, they design phase 2. This is in contrast to a design-bid-build contract, where the project is completely designed by the owner, then bid on, then completed.

original_text: Official corporal punishment, often by caning, remains commonplace in schools in some Asian, African and Caribbean countries. For details of individual countries see School corporal punishment. In many other countries, corporal punishment has been outlawed in schools but not in other settings. It is legal and common in some countries in the home and in day care centres. It is often legal in the home and not elsewhere. In 2014, 48 states (66) had laws which specifically prohibited the use of corporal punishment in schools. However, in many states, corporal punishment remained legal and in common use. In 2014, 37 states (53) had laws which explicitly prohibited corporal punishment in other settings. However, in many states corporal punishment remained legal and in common use. In 2014, 33 states (48) had laws which explicitly prohibited corporal punishment in all settings. For more detailed information, see the Facts and Figures section.
text: Corporal punishment, often by caning, remains commonplace in schools in some Asian, African and Caribbean countries, but it is legal and common in the home and day care centres.

original_text: The smaller galleries cover Korea, the Himalayan kingdoms and South East Asia. Korean displays include green-glazed ceramics, silk embroideries from officials' robes and gleaming boxes inlaid with mother-of-pearl made between 500 AD and 2000. Himalayan items include important early Nepalese bronze sculptures, repousse work and embroidery. Tibetan art from the 14th to the 19th century is represented by notable 14th- and 15th-century religious images in wood and bronze, scroll paintings and ritual objects. Art from Thailand, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia and Sri Lanka in gold, silver, bronze, stone, terracotta and ivory represents these rich and complex cultures, the displays span the 6th to 19th centuries. Refined Hindu and Buddhist sculptures reflect the influence of India; items on show include betel-nut cutters, ivory combs and bronze palanquin hooks.

original_text: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt, and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system; however, multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system, in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections. Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, antimicrobial peptides called defensins, and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates, including humans, have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms, including the ability to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.

original_text: In another incident, around 1177, he was captured in a raid and held prisoner by his father's former allies, the Tayichi'ud. The Tayichi'ud enslaved Temujin (reportedly with a cangue, a sort of portable stocks), but with the help of a sympathetic guard, the father of Chilaun (who later became a general of Genghis Khan), he was able to escape from the ger (yurt) in the middle of the night by hiding in a river crevice.[citation needed] It was around this time that Jelme and Bo'orchu, two of Genghis Khan's future generals, joined forces with him. Temujin's reputation also became widespread after his escape from the Tayichi'ud.

original_text: There are various mechanisms by which teacher enthusiasm may facilitate higher levels of intrinsic motivation. Teacher enthusiasm may contribute to a classroom atmosphere full of energy and enthusiasm which feed student interest and excitement in learning the subject matter. Enthusiastic teachers may also lead to students becoming more self-determined in their own learning process. The concept of mere exposure indicates that the teacher's enthusiasm may contribute to the student's expectations about intrinsic motivation in the context of learning. Also, enthusiasm may act as a "motivational embellishment"; increasing a student's interest by the variety, novelty, and surprise of the enthusiastic teacher's presentation of the material. Finally, the concept of emotional contagion, may also apply. Students may become more intrinsically motivated by catching onto the enthusiasm and energy of the teacher.[citation needed]

original_text: ABC currently holds the broadcast rights to the Academy Awards, Emmy Awards (which are rotated across all four major networks on a year-to-year basis), American Music Awards, Disney Parks Christmas Day Parade, Disney Parks Magical Christmas Celebration, Academy of Country Music Awards, and CMA Music Festival, as well as the country music specials from the Grand Ole Opry. The network also broadcasts the primetime portion of the March for Life rally held annually in Washington, D.C. in January, with no commentary, limited interruption for commercials, and the coverage usually introduced by one of the network's news anchors. The March for Life coverage includes pro-life speakers in the crowd, but none are interviewed or otherwise acknowledged on-camera.[7] The network also broadcasts the Citrus Bowl on New Year's Day, generally when CBS airs an NFL playoff game in the afternoon, and the Celebrity Golf Classic, a celebrity pro-am golf tournament held in November in Lake Tahoe, Nevada, the latter of which is produced by Silver Chalice, the digital media arm of the Chicago Bulls and Chicago White Sox ownership group, and is co-produced by the ATT Sports Networks. As of September 2015[update], ABC affiliates also carry the ESPN-produced Saturday morning sports-focused program ESPN College Football from the college football season through the network's Saturday afternoon game package. ESPN College Football (and more recently, Saturday afternoon college games) moved to ABC from ESPN2 in 2009, after ESPN gained partial broadcast rights to the Bowl Championship Series (a package now maintained by the successor of the BCS, the College Football Playoff). ABC broadcasts in 720p HDTV, the native resolution format for The Walt Disney Company's television properties. Most of the network's programming is produced in 1080i, while programs provided by Touchstone Television and other companies are broadcast in 480i standard definition (some shows, such as Desperate Housewives and Ugly Betty, are transmitted in 1080i, though the former was shot in 480i). ABC is one of the few U.S. broadcast networks that continued to use a 4:3 aspect ratio longer than the others. In 2006, Walt Disney Television chairman Anne Sweeney discussed the possibility of ABC broadcasting in high definition, with a Disney-produced show expected to be the first to be broadcast in the format.[8] In 2007, Disney-ABC Television Group announced that ABC would start broadcasting in 720p high definition, becoming the second U.S. broadcast network (after CBS) to announce plans to convert to the format.[9] The network began to broadcast in the format on April 15, 2008, with the broadcast of the ACM Awards telecast.[10] During the 2010s, the network began to use 16:9 framing for all of its programming outside of news and sports programming, regardless of whether a program was produced in 16:9 or in 4:3. ABC launched its live streaming and video-on-demand service, ABC Go, on April 30, 2013, with its initial slate of network programming, including all episodes of the first season of Scandal; users must authenticate with participating pay television providers in order to access the service's programming.[111213] The service became available to Comcast and Cablevision subscribers on October 1, 2013,[14] and to Time Warner Cable and Verizon FiOS subscribers on November 27.[15] The service was renamed as the ABC app in 2018. On December 14, 2016, ABC announced that it would begin to offer its owned-and-operated stations' live programming on Hulu's subscription service as part of a new deal reached between the network and streaming service.[16] ABC affiliate list List of ABC television affiliates (by U.S. state) List of ABC television affiliates (table) List of ABC television affiliates (by Nielsen DMA) "Ted Turner's TV 'revolution'." BBC News. October 1, 2007. Retrieved June 23, 2009. templatestyles src"Module:CitationCS1styles.css"templatestyles
text: The Disney-owned ABC network broadcasts a number of high-profile events each year, including the Academy Awards, American Music Awards, CMA Music Festival, and the March for Life rallies.

original_text: Following the election of the UK Labour Party to government in 1997, the UK formally subscribed to the Agreement on Social Policy, which allowed it to be included with minor amendments as the Social Chapter of the 1997 Treaty of Amsterdam. The UK subsequently adopted the main legislation previously agreed under the Agreement on Social Policy, the 1994 Works Council Directive, which required workforce consultation in businesses, and the 1996 Parental Leave Directive. In the 10 years following the 1997 Treaty of Amsterdam and adoption of the Social Chapter the European Union has undertaken policy initiatives in various social policy areas, including labour and industry relations, equal opportunity, health and safety, public health, protection of children, the disabled and elderly, poverty, migrant workers, education, training and youth.
