original_text: The clinical pharmacist's role involves creating a comprehensive drug therapy plan for patient-specific problems, identifying goals of therapy, and reviewing all prescribed medications prior to dispensing and administration to the patient. Clinical pharmacists monitor for incompatibilities, drug-drug interactions, and drug-disease contraindications. Clinical pharmacists are the foremost experts on the use of medications, acting as a critical resource for physicians. Clinical pharmacists apply their medication expertise in collaboration with physicians, physician assistants, nurse practitioners, and other healthcare professionals to optimize patient's medication therapy and improve patient outcomes. Clinical pharmacists practice in hospitals, clinics, and other settings to optimize the medication-use process and improve patient outcomes. Clinical pharmacists are patient-focused and work directly with patients to provide patient-specific medication information and advice. Clinical pharmacists are able to provide guidance to patients on how and when to take medication, monitor for drug-related problems, and conduct patient-specific drug therapy reviews. Clinical pharmacists also educate patients and caregivers on topics related to preventative care such as immunizations and smoking cessation. Clinical pharmacists focus on the quality of medication use and safety in healthcare systems. Clinical pharmacists work to optimize medication-use processes, identify areas of medication risk, and implement strategies to reduce drug-related problems. Clinical pharmacists also lead and facilitate interdisciplinary teams to improve patient care. Clinical pharmacists are involved in the medication-use process from prescribing to administration. Clinical pharmacists review prescriptions to ensure the correct drug is being prescribed for the patient and the dosage and duration of therapy are appropriate. Clinical pharmacists identify drug-related problems and recommend resolutions. They are responsible for providing medication and drug information to other healthcare professionals and patients. Clinical pharmacists also are responsible for the procurement, preparation, and dispensing of medications to patients.
text: A clinical pharmacist is a member of the healthcare team who works directly with patients to ensure the safe and effective use of medications. Clinical pharmacists are able to provide patients with guidance on how and when to take medication, monitor drug-related problems, and conduct patient-specific drug therapy reviews.

original_text: Jacksonville is in the First Coast region of northeast Florida and is centered on the banks of the St. Johns River, about 25 miles (40 km) south of the Georgia state line and about 340 miles (550 km) north of Miami. The Jacksonville Beaches communities are along the adjacent Atlantic coast. The area was originally inhabited by the Timucua people, and in 1564 was the site of the French colony of Fort Caroline, one of the earliest European settlements in what is now the continental United States. Under British rule, settlement grew at the narrow point in the river where cattle crossed, known as Wacca Pilatka to the Seminole and the Cow Ford to the British. A platted town was established there in 1822, a year after the United States gained Florida from Spain; it was named after Andrew Jackson, the first military governor of the Florida Territory and seventh President of the United States.

original_text: In addition to the Riemann hypothesis, many more conjectures revolving about primes have been posed. Often having an elementary formulation, many of these conjectures have withstood a proof for decades: all four of Landau's problems from 1912 are still unsolved. One of them is Goldbach's conjecture, which asserts that every even integer n greater than 2 can be written as a sum of two primes. As of February 2011[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to n 2 1017. Weaker statements than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a sum of three primes. Chen's theorem says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a semiprime, the product of two primes. Also, any even integer can be written as the sum of six primes. The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.

As of February 2011[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to n 2 1017. Weaker statements than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a sum of three primes. Chen's theorem says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a semiprime, the product of two primes. Also, any even integer can be written as the sum of six primes. The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.

original_text: The first recorded travels by Europeans to China and back date from this time. The most famous traveler of the period was the Venetian Marco Polo, whose account of his trip to "Cambaluc," the capital of the Great Khan, and of life there astounded the people of Europe. The account of his travels, Il milione (or, The Million, known in English as the Travels of Marco Polo), appeared about the year 1299. Some argue over the accuracy of Marco Polo's accounts due to the lack of mentioning the Great Wall of China, tea houses, which would have been a prominent sight since Europeans had yet to adopt a tea culture, as well the practice of foot binding by the women in capital of the Great Khan. Some suggest that Marco Polo acquired much of his knowledge through contact with Persian traders since many of the places he named were in Persian.

original_text: Musicians Eric Burdon, Sting, Mark Knopfler, Alan Hull, Cheryl Cole and Neil Tennant lived in Newcastle. Hank Marvin and Bruce Welch were both former pupils of Rutherford Grammar School, actors Kevin Whately, James Bolam, Eric Idle, Tim Healy and Rowan Atkinson, plus author Lee Hall, were born in the city, as was the late British Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, who was born at 46 Hill Street in the West End. MacDonald, the son of a wharf clerk, was one of nine children, and he lived in the city until he was 17. Another well known son of Newcastle is the actor Robson Green, who was born on 18 December 1964, in Hexham, Northumberland, but brought up in Woolsington, on the south side of Newcastle, and educated at the Royal Grammar School. He became a professional footballer for Sunderland, and later became a TV actor, with several series to his credit. He is currently working on a new series, in which he will be playing the part of an ex-footballer, who is now a successful architect, called Charlie Wise. Singer, songwriter and musician Alan Hull , lead singer and songwriter with the folk-rock group Lindisfarne, was born in the West End of Newcastle and went to Heaton High School. He later attended Newcastle University. In the 1960s, he and fellow musician The Birtles Brothers formed the band Brethren. After several years of touring and recording with Lindisfarne, Alan Hull left in 1973 to pursue a solo career, recording three albums, Pipedream (1973), Pipedream (1976) and Squire (1979). Actor James Bolam (born 1935) attended Heaton Grammar School and was born and brought up in the West End of Newcastle. He is best known for his roles in the BBC TV series The Likely Lads and its sequel, Whatever Happened to the Likely Lads?, as Terry Collier, as Jack Ford in the ITV drama series New Tricks, and in the BBC series Grandpa in My Pocket. He lives in the seaside town of Alnmouth, Northumberland. The well known BBC TV presenter and naturalist, Chris Packham (born 1961), was born in the West End of Newcastle, and attended Heaton Manor School. He presented the popular BBC children's TV programme The Really Wild Show, and has presented numerous wildlife documentaries for the BBC. The playwright and novelist, Lee Hall (born 1966) is another son of the West End of Newcastle. He attended Heaton High School, and then studied English at Cambridge University. He is best known for his screenplay for the 2000 film Billy Elliot, and for writing the stage version of the same name, which won the Evening Standard Award for Best New Musical. He also wrote the screenplay for the film adaptation, directed by Stephen Daldry. The journalist and presenter Nick Owen (born 1947) was born in the West End of Newcastle. He studied English at Durham University and began his career as a journalist with the Morpeth Herald. He later joined the BBC, and in 1981, he moved to ITN to work as a reporter, before becoming an anchorman for the ITV Lunchtime News and ITV Evening News. In 1996 he moved to London to present the ITV Breakfast show, GMTV. Britain's most famous private eye, Peter Francis (born 1946) in Wallsend, and brought up in the West End of Newcastle, where his father, Tom, worked as a baker at the Newcastle Arms Pub. Peter is the grandson of the actor and dancer, Abe Francis, and the son of the comedian and singer, Tommy Francis, who were both born in the West End of Newcastle. Peter's career as a private detective has been featured in several books and films, including the Oscar-winning 2000 film The Insider. The actor, comedian, writer and director, Ricky Tomlinson (born 1939), best known for his roles as Jim Royle in the BBC sitcom The Royle Family, and as Bobby Grant in the soap opera Brookside, was born

original_text: For most of human history higher material living standards - full stomachs, access to clean water and warmth from fuel - led to better health and longer lives. This pattern of economic growth and improving health was true in all regions of the world. But this is no longer the case. For the first time in human history, in many countries health improvements are not keeping up with economic growth. That is, there are some countries in which health is improving more slowly than the economy is growing. In other countries, health is improving at a rate that is slower than it used to be. As a result, life expectancy at birth has stopped rising in a number of countries. In the United States, for example, life expectancy actually fell from 2015 to 2016. Such recent trends in health are not attributable to factors such as war or famine. Rather, they appear to be the result of different types of economic growth. The economic growth we have achieved in the 21st century has come at a cost to health. Another recent development is that some countries have experienced declines in life expectancy. Again, this trend is not due to war or famine. Rather, it is a result of the drug overdose and suicide epidemics in the United States. Not all is doom and gloom. There are some countries and regions of the world - such as China and Latin America - in which health is improving at a faster pace than economic growth. This is due to a variety of factors, including economic growth that has lifted many out of extreme poverty. With the exception of the U.S., which has seen a recent reversal, health improvements have generally kept pace with economic growth in high-income countries. The next step is to identify the policy interventions that work. In the United States, we are in the midst of an experiment to test whether universal health care will reverse recent trends in health.
text: Life expectancy has been rising in many parts of the world in recent years, but it is not keeping up with economic growth, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

original_text: The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates minimality or indecomposability, in an appropriate sense. This article lists some of the more important generalizations of prime numbers. The main article for each generalization is given first, followed by a list of other related articles. 1 Number theorists 2 Arithmetic and number theorists 3 Analysis and mathematical physics 5 Set theorists 6 Geometricians 7 Topologists Number theorists The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of positive divisors of its arithmetic function. A prime number is a number with exactly two positive divisors (1 and itself). The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime divisors. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime ideals in a factorization of the integers. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime factors. In ring theory, a prime ideal is a proper ideal that is not contained in any other ideal except itself and the whole ring. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of a polynomial over a field. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of irreducible factors. In abstract algebra, a polynomial f (x) over a field K is irreducible if it cannot be factored as the product of two nonconstant polynomials in K[x]. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of a polynomial over a ring. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of irreducible factors. In abstract algebra, a polynomial f (x) over a ring R is irreducible if it cannot be factored as the product of two nonconstant polynomials in R[x]. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of an ideal in a ring. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of irreducible factors. In ring theory, an ideal I in a ring R is called prime if for any elements a, b in R with ab in I, we must have either a in I or b in I. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of a module over a ring. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of irreducible factors. In ring theory, a module M over a ring R is called a primary module if for any elements a, b in R and any element m in M, if am in Rad (M) (i.e., if am is a radical element of M), then either a is in Rad (R) (the Jacobson radical of R) or b is in Rad (M). The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of a lattice. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime elements. In order theory, a partially ordered set (poset) is called a lattice if every two elements x and y have a supremum xy and an infimum xy. An element of a lattice is called prime if it is not the supremum of a strictly smaller subset. Arithmetic and number theorists The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime elements in the factorization of an algebra. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime elements. In abstract algebra, an algebra over a field K is a vector space over K together with a multiplication operation that is K-bilinear. The element 0 of the algebra is the zero vector. An element of an algebra is called prime if it is not the product of two elements that are not both zero. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime factors in the factorization of a group. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime divisors. In group theory, the prime divisors of a group are the orders of its proper subgroups, that is, proper subgroups whose index is finite. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime divisors of an integer lattice. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime divisors. An integer lattice is a set of integers closed under addition and multiplication. The number of prime divisors of a positive integer is the same as the number of prime divisors of a rational vector space. The arithmetic function for prime numbers is the number of prime divisors. A rational vector space is a vector space over the rationals. The

original_text: Super Bowl 50 was an American football game to determine the champion of the National Football League (NFL) for the 2015 season. The American Football Conference (AFC) champion Denver Broncos defeated the National Football Conference (NFC) champion Carolina Panthers, 24-10. The game was played on February 7, 2016, at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California, the home stadium of the San Francisco 49ers. Super Bowl 50 was the 46th Super Bowl in the modern era and the 48th overall. Denver's defense made three critical stops on Carolina's final possession, including two sacks on Newton by Broncos linebacker Von Miller, and cornerback Bradley Roby intercepting a pass by Newton in the end zone on the last play of the game, to seal the victory. The Broncos' defense was ranked first overall in the NFL for the 2015 season. The Broncos had the top-ranked defense in the NFL in 1997, 2014 and 2015. Peyton Manning, who was the starting quarterback for the Broncos, was named the Super Bowl MVP. He finished the game with 141 passing yards and two passing touchdowns, and also rushed for a touchdown. Manning had previously announced that he would retire from football following the game. His final pass was a completion to wide receiver Bennie Fowler, and the final play was a victory formation. Manning was the first quarterback to start and win Super Bowls with two different teams, and also the oldest quarterback to start a Super Bowl at age 39. This page was last edited on 14 February 2019, at 21:02 (UTC).

original_text: In 1981, the Presidential Working Party on the Second University was commissioned to look at both the possibilities of setting up a second university in Kenya as well as the prospects of creating a constituent college of the University of Nairobi in the North Eastern Region. The Working Party submitted its report in April 1982, making several recommendations. One of these was that a private university college be set up in North Eastern Province of Kenya. The Report of the Working Party was presented to Parliament on 31st October 1983 and subsequently became a Government White Paper. In the same year, the Commission for Higher Education endorsed the establishment of a private university college to be located in North Eastern Province of Kenya. The University College was to specialise in the following subjects: Food Science and Technology, Education, and It was to be established within three years of the White Paper on Higher Education. In the same year, the Commission for Higher Education, the Kenya Universities and Colleges Central Placement Service and the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology made a public appeal in the press, inviting interested groups to apply for the establishment of a private university college. In 1985, the Commission for Higher Education, in its report to the Minister of Education, Science and Technology, recommended that Moi University be granted a Letter of Interim Authority and that its Charter be processed. The Minister accepted this recommendation. On 23rd March 1985, the Moi University Interim Governing Council was appointed by the Commission for Higher Education. The Council held its first meeting on 3rd May 1985 and elected Dr. Daniel Arap Moi as its Chairman. Later in May 1985, the Interim Council held a public meeting at the Nairobi Showground, where the University College was officially launched. On 17th May 1985, the Interim Council appointed a Selection Panel for the appointment of the first Vice-Chancellor of the University College. The Panel recommended the appointment of Professor Peter Koech. The Vice-Chancellor was to take over the office on 1st July 1985. On 27th November 1985, the Interim Council appointed the first Principals and Deans of the University College. In March 1986, the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology appointed Dr. Daniel Arap Moi as Chancellor of the University College. On 10th May 1986, the first Senate of the University College was constituted. In May 1986, the University College was incorporated as a company limited by guarantee. On 28th July 1986, the College was formally gazetted. In October 1986, the Commission for Higher Education granted the University College a Letter of Interim Authority and a Provisional Certificate of Registration. On 14th December 1986, the College was opened by the Chancellor and the first students were admitted. The first graduation ceremony was held on 12th December 1989 when 479 students graduated. On 13th May 1990, the University College was granted a Charter by the Commission for Higher Education and became Moi University. On 15th July 1990, the University held its first graduation ceremony as a full-fledged university. On 2nd February 1991, Moi University was admitted to full membership of the Inter-University Council for East Africa. On 10th December 1992, the University became a full member of the Association of Commonwealth Universities (ACU). On 20th August 1993, the University was admitted to full membership of the Association of African Universities (AAU). On 28th April 1994, Moi University became a full member of the International Association of Universities (IAU).
text: Moi University was established as a constituent college of the University of Nairobi on 1st January 1986, with the aim of establishing a second university in Kenya and a private university college in North Eastern Province of Kenya.

original_text: If a problem X is in C and hard for C, then X is said to be complete for C. This means that X is the hardest problem in C. Conjecture: if X is complete for C, then X is NP-complete, that is, X is NP-hard and in NP. We will prove the conjecture by reducing an NP-complete problem to X. In order to do this we need a reduction from a given NP-complete problem A to X. That is, given an instance I of A, we will construct an instance I of X such that I is a yes-instance of A if and only if I is a yes-instance of X. In a reduction, the instance I of X is often called the certificate or the witness for the yes-instance of A. The reduction is polynomial time computable if the size of I is polynomial in the size of I. Definition: A problem X is NP-complete if X is NP-hard and in NP. Theorem: If X is in NP and hard for NP, then X is NP-complete. Proof: Let A be an NP-complete problem. Let I be an instance of A. We will construct a polynomial time reduction from A to X. Let I be the instance of X constructed from I as follows. We will assume that all the instances of A and X are encoded as bit strings. This is not always the case, but it simplifies the presentation. If I is a yes-instance of A, then I is a yes-instance of X. Suppose that I is a no-instance of A. In this case we must show that I is a no-instance of X. Assume to the contrary that I is a yes-instance of X. Then there is a solution S for I. We show how to construct an A-solution for I from S. Since A is in NP, this can be done in polynomial time. Suppose that S is a solution for I. We will show how to construct an A-solution for I from S. Suppose that S is a yes-instance of X. Then there is a solution S for I. Let T be a solution for A constructed from S. For each v in the solution S, create a clone cv. Let T be the set of all vertices cv such that v S. It is clear that T is a solution for A. Suppose that S is a no-instance of X. Then there is no solution S for I. Suppose that S is a no-instance of X. Since I is a yes-instance of X, there is a solution S for I. It is clear that T is not a solution for A. We have shown that T is a solution for A if and only if S is a solution for I. We have shown that if S is a solution for I, then T is a solution for A. We have shown that if T is a solution for A, then S is a solution for I. Since A is NP-complete, this implies that X is NP-complete.

original_text: To make new legislation, TFEU article 294 defines the "ordinary legislative procedure" that applies for most EU acts. The essence is there are three readings, starting with a Commission proposal, where the Parliament must vote by a majority of all MEPs (not just those present) to block or suggest changes, and the Council must vote by qualified majority to approve changes, but by unanimity to block Commission amendment. Where the different institutions cannot agree at any stage, a "Conciliation Committee" is convened, representing MEPs, ministers and the Commission to try and get agreement on a joint text: if this works, it will be sent back to the Parliament and Council to approve by absolute and qualified majority. This means, legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament, a minority in the Council, and a majority in the Commission: it is harder to change EU law than stay the same. A different procedure exists for budgets. For "enhanced cooperation" among a sub-set of at least member states, authorisation must be given by the Council. Member state governments should be informed by the Commission at the outset before any proposals start the legislative procedure. The EU as a whole can only act within its power set out in the Treaties. TEU articles 4 and 5 state that powers remain with the member states unless they have been conferred, although there is a debate about the Kompetenz-Kompetenz question: who ultimately has the "competence" to define the EU's "competence." Many member state courts believe they decide, other member state Parliaments believe they decide, while within the EU, the Court of Justice believes it has the final say.
text: To make new legislation, TFEU article 294 defines the "ordinary legislative procedure" that applies for most EU acts. The essence is there are three readings, starting with a Commission proposal, where the Parliament must vote by a majority of all MEPs (not just those present) to block or suggest changes, and the Council must vote by qualified majority to approve changes, but by unanimity to block Commission amendment. Where the different institutions cannot agree at any stage, a "Conciliation Committee" is convened, representing MEPs, ministers and the Commission to try and get agreement on a joint text: if this works, it will be sent back to the Parliament and Council to approve by absolute and qualified majority. This means, legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament, a minority in the Council, and a majority in the Commission: it is harder to change EU law than stay the same. A different procedure exists for budgets. For "enhanced cooperation" among a sub-set of at least member states, authorisation must be given by the Council. Member state governments should be informed by the Commission at the outset before any proposals start the legislative procedure. The EU as a whole can only act within its power set out in the Treaties. TEU articles 4 and 5 state that powers remain with the member states unless they have been conferred, although there is a debate about the Kompetenz-Kompetenz question: who ultimately has the "competence" to define the EU's "competence." Many member state courts believe they decide, other member state Parliaments believe they decide, while within the EU, the Court of Justice believes it has the final say.

original_text: The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those who do are unlikely to reach higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections, and, in serious cases, may be expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with many Parliaments, the independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to be low, and backbench rebellions by members who are discontent with their party's policies are rare. In some circumstances, however, parties announce "free votes," which allows Members to vote as they please. This is typically done on moral issues.

original_text: In many poor and developing countries much land and housing is held outside the formal or legal property ownership registration system. Much unregistered property is held in informal form through various associations and other arrangements. Reasons for extra-legal ownership include excessive bureaucratic red tape in buying property and building, In some countries it can take over 200 steps and up to 14 years to build on government land. Other causes of extra-legal property are failures to notarize transaction documents or having documents notarized but failing to have them recorded with the official agency.

original_text: The Victoria and Albert Museum's Word and Image Department was under the same pressure being felt in archives around the world, to digitize their collection. A large scale digitization project began in 2007 in that department. That project was entitled the Factory Project to reference Andy Warhol and to create a factory to completely digitize the collection. The first step of the Factory Project was to take photographs utilizing digital cameras. The Word and Image Department had a collection of old photos but they were in black and white and in variant conditions, so new photos were shot. Those new photographs will be accessible to researchers to the Victoria and Albert Museum web-site. 15,000 images were taken during the first year of the Factory Project, including drawings, watercolors, computer-generated art, photographs, posters, and woodcuts. The second step of the Factory Project is to catalog everything. The third step of the Factory Project is to audit the collection. All of those items which were photographed and cataloged, must be audited to make sure everything listed as being in the collection was physically found during the creation of the Factory Project. The fourth goal of the Factory Project is conservation, which means performing some basic preventable procedures to those items in the department. There is a "Search the Collections" feature on the Victoria and Albert web-site. The main impetus behind the large-scale digitization project called the Factory Project was to list more items in the collections in those computer databases.

original_text: The Harvard Crimson competes in 42 intercollegiate sports in the NCAA Division I Ivy League. Harvard has an intense athletic rivalry with Yale University culminating in The Game, although the Harvard-Yale Regatta predates the football game. This rivalry, though, is put aside every two years when the Harvard and Yale Track and Field teams come together to compete against a combined Oxford University and Cambridge University team, a competition that is the oldest continuous international amateur competition in the world.

original_text: Daniel Burke departed from Capital CitiesABC in February 1994, with Thomas Murphy taking over as president before ceding control to Robert Iger. September 1994 saw the debut of NYPD Blue, a gritty police procedural from Steven Bochco (who created Doogie Howser, M.D. and the critically pilloried Cop Rock for ABC earlier in the decade); lasting ten seasons, the drama became known for its boundary pushing of network television standards (particularly its occasional use of graphic language and rear nudity), which led some affiliates to initially refuse to air the show in its first season.

original_text: The historian Frederick W. Mote wrote that the usage of the term "social classes" for this system was misleading and that the position of people within the four-class system was not so much determined by their economic position as it was by their political position. "The principle that was supposed to distinguish men was not economic but political. Society was to be organized and stratified politically. Every person was to have a politically defined place and function. The aim was to distinguish between the politically worthy and unworthy, and this aim became the guiding principle of the whole system of society." During the Song Dynasty, the scholar-officials functioned as a kind of elite and formed the upper stratum of society. The scholar-officials were educated in writings of Confucius and other Chinese philosophers and were trained in calligraphy and other literary arts. The emperor was the head of the government and he appointed the chancellor. The chancellor was in charge of drafting policy, which would be discussed in the Grand Council. The policy was then carried out by the six ministries, each headed by two vice chancellors. The ministries were responsible for the military, personnel, justice, revenue, rites, and public works. There was also a censorate, which was charged with supervising the implementation of policy. At the beginning of the dynasty, the leading scholar-officials generally were selected through an examination system. The exams were based on knowledge of the Chinese classics and literary style. Later on, the exams were expanded to cover practical matters such as revenue and taxes. Theoretically, the system allowed anyone to become a scholar-official. However, those from disadvantaged groups such as the poorer peasantry found it extremely difficult to compete in the examination system, usually having to travel long distances to take the examinations, which were held in the capital. Throughout the Song period, the system of promoting officials was based on the imperial examination system. Theoretically, any man who passed the exams and performed well in the eyes of his superiors could become a high-ranking official, even up to the Emperor. The imperial examination system became institutionalized by the Song Dynasty and continued until its abolition in 1905. The exams required applicants to write essays and answer questions on topics ranging from classical Chinese literature to mathematics. Theoretically, the system allowed anyone to become a government official, but in reality it was only available to the landed gentry, and, as a result, only the well-educated and wealthier families were able to educate their children for the exams. The competitive nature of the examination system meant that it was dominated by those already in power. "The examination system was designed to select the best possible people for the task of government. This was one of the key features of the civil service system and why it was copied by virtually every major bureaucratic empire in the last 2,000 years." "The examination system helped to draw men of exceptional talent to the service of the state. Examinations gave large numbers of ambitious but impoverished men the opportunity to obtain official positions and thereby to become members of the elite." "The examination system worked in the main and some able men rose through the ranks and the very poor had a chance to compete." "The examination system...enabled individuals of exceptional talents to be discovered and promoted. At the lower levels of the examination system, the examinations may have been true tests of intellectual attainment; at the higher levels, successful candidates were those who had the right friends and acquaintances, knew the 'right' answers and expressed themselves in elegant and witty language." "One of the basic assumptions of the Chinese administrative system was that the purpose of education was to train men for public duty...In this way, it was assumed, those who showed the most talent and merit would be chosen and that the system would work its way inevitably toward meritocracy...Until 1905, when the system was abolished, it ensured that the Chinese bureaucracy remained a meritocracy and government posts were open to talented men regardless of their family background." "The system of recruitment of officials by examination was based on merit and meant that government service was not restricted to the aristocracy." "The examination system was based on the assumption that administrative positions should be open to all men of proven merit. This system helped to insure that at least a number of men of exceptional ability rose to positions of some importance in the bureau

original_text: The Lower Rhine flows through North Rhine-Westphalia. Its banks are usually heavily populated and industrialized, in particular the agglomerations Cologne, Dusseldorf and Ruhr area. Here the Rhine flows through the largest conurbation in Germany, the Rhine-Ruhr region. One of the most important cities in this region is Duisburg with the largest river port in Europe (Duisport). The region downstream of Duisburg is more agricultural. In Wesel, 30 km downstream of Duisburg, is located the western end of the second east-west shipping route, the Wesel-Datteln Canal, which runs parallel to the Lippe. Between Emmerich and Cleves the Emmerich Rhine Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in Germany, crosses the 400 m wide river. Near Krefeld, the river crosses the Uerdingen line, the line which separates the areas where Low German and High German are spoken.

original_text: Super Bowl 50 was an American football game to determine the champion of the National Football League (NFL) for the 2015 season. The American Football Conference (AFC) champion Denver Broncos defeated the National Football Conference (NFC) champion Carolina Panthers, 24-10. The game was played on February 7, 2016, at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California, the home stadium of the San Francisco 49ers. With this victory, the Broncos set a new NFL record with seven Super Bowl wins. This page was last changed on 13 March 2019, at 18:50.

The Chargers' Norv Turner was the offensive coordinator for the 2000 Ravens Super Bowl winning team. With the win, the Chargers became the first team in NFL history to win their 1st three playoff games after trailing in the fourth quarter of each game. original_text: It is recognised that an epidemiological account of the plague is as important as an identification of symptoms, but researchers are hampered by the lack of reliable statistics from this time. As a result, much of our knowledge about the plague comes from contemporary accounts, which tend to be biased in favour of the wealthy, and to be sensational and exaggerated. Statistics are notoriously unreliable. For instance, the death rate in one city may be recorded as being 20, when it was actually 40 - because the living were too busy to count the dead. In the case of the Black Death, people were often buried immediately, or without ceremony, by groups of volunteers. Church graveyards were quickly full, so bodies were interred anywhere, including in the streets or in mass graves. Some were thrown into rivers, so accurate statistics are impossible to ascertain. The Black Death was the most significant epidemic in human history. The event is widely considered to have killed 50 million people, and reduced the world's population from an estimated 450 million to 350-375 million in the 14th century. The Black Death is estimated to have killed 30-60 of Europe's population. The Black Death is estimated to have killed 30-60 of Europe's population. The Black Death had a profound effect on medieval society. It hastened the decline of feudalism and brought an end to the dominance of the Roman Catholic Church. In addition, the Black Death initiated numerous social, political, religious, and economic upheavals. In the years after the Black Death, wages increased, while land rents fell, and Europeans enjoyed a higher standard of living. In the long run, the Black Death may have helped to pave the way for the Renaissance. The Black Death was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which was spread by fleas carried by rats. These rats lived on the hundreds of merchant ships that arrived each year in the ports of the Middle East and Europe. Within two years, the plague had reached nearly every European country, as well as much of Asia and northern Africa. Plague was spread in three forms. The most common was bubonic plague, which accounted for 75 of all deaths. It began with the lymph nodes becoming inflamed, causing the formation of painful, red buboes. The buboes were commonly found in the armpits, groin and neck. Bubonic plague was often accompanied by fever, chills, extreme pain and headache. The bacteria could also spread to the lungs, causing a more virulent form of plague called pneumonic plague. This was the least common form of plague, but was the most dangerous. The third type of plague was septicemic plague, where the bacteria entered the bloodstream. The Black Death was not the first major epidemic in the Middle Ages. In the 6th century, 100,000 people died of plague in Constantinople. The first pandemic, which became known as the Plague of Justinian, began in Egypt in 541, and spread to the Middle East and Europe, where it killed up to 100 million people. In 1347, the disease returned to Europe, and was much more virulent. It struck in 1347 and recurred in Europe for four years. The plague then returned in 1361, 1369, and 1374. In 1389, a new outbreak occurred, killing 20,000 people in London alone. Plague continued to strike throughout the 14th and 15th centuries, and in 1563, 20,000 people died of it in London. The third major epidemic was the Great Plague, which began in 1665 in London. It is believed to have been bubonic plague, but the symptoms were so severe that it is possible it was pneumonic. It spread in the crowded streets of London, and by the summer of 1665, it had killed 10,000 people. It was so contagious that families were thrown together in pest houses to die. The Plague Riot of 1665 occurred in London, when a mob of citizens, believing they were being treated cruelly by the authorities, attempted to storm the gates of the city. They were unsuccessful,

The third major epidemic was the Great Plague, which began in 1665 in London. It is believed to have been bubonic plague, but the symptoms were so severe that it is possible it was pneumonic. It spread in the crowded streets of London, and by the summer of 1665, it had killed 10,000 people. It was so contagious that families were thrown together in pest houses to die. The Plague Riot of 1665 occurred in London, when a mob of citizens, believing they were being treated cruelly by the authorities, attempted to storm the gates of the city. They were unsuccessful,

original_text: Child labour is common in Kenya. Most working children are active in agriculture. In 2006, UNICEF estimated that up to 30 of girls in the coastal areas of Malindi, Mombasa, Kilifi, and Diani were subject to prostitution. Most of the prostitutes in Kenya are aged 9-18. The Ministry of Gender and Child Affairs employed 400 child protection officers in 2009. The causes of child labour include poverty, the lack of access to education and weak government institutions. Kenya has ratified Convention No. 81 on labour inspection in industries and Convention No. 129 on labour inspection in agriculture.

original_text: The Broncos' defense ranked first in the NFL yards allowed (4,530) for the first time in franchise history, and fourth in points allowed (296). Defensive ends Derek Wolfe and Malik Jackson became the first Broncos defensive linemen to earn Pro Bowl berths since 1997. The Broncos' offense, however, was among the least productive in the league. The offense ranked 28th in yards per game (312.2), 28th in points per game (18.1), 28th in total touchdowns (21) and 31st in third-down conversions (32.1 percent). Especially in the season's final month, Manning's accuracy and decision-making declined. Manning completed 12 of 22 passes in a 20-17 win at Pittsburgh, but averaged just 3.6 yards per attempt and threw an interception. The Broncos dropped a 17-3 decision at Kansas City and Manning was limited to 15-of-32 passing for 150 yards. Manning finished the season with 23 interceptions, his most in a season since 1997. Still, Manning led the Broncos to a 7-0 record in the AFC West and 11-5 mark overall. "Peyton Manning, I love the guy," Elway said. "He's a great quarterback. He's done everything he can do for this football team. It's one of those things where you can't keep doing the same thing and expect different results. "Sometimes, you've got to make a change. We've got to look at what we're doing offensively. We've got to look at what we're doing defensively and special teams. I'm going to take a look at everything. And when I'm done looking at that, then I'll decide what changes I want to make." Still, Elway said he expects Manning will return for a 19th season in the NFL. "I think he's going to play," Elway said. "I think he can still play. He still has it. I still think he can play at a high level. He had an MVP-type season two years ago. "He still has the desire. And he's still got it between the ears. He still has it there. We just have to figure out what's the best way to utilize him." Manning declined comment Sunday, deferring all questions to Elway.
text: Denver Broncos general manager John Elway and head coach Gary Kubiak have been named as AFC coaches of the year, while quarterback Peyton Manning has been named the league's top player.

original_text: Hence, 6 is not prime. The image at the right illustrates that 12 is not prime: 12 3 4. No even number greater than 2 is prime because by definition, any such number n has at least three distinct divisors, namely 1, 2, and n. This implies that n is not prime. Accordingly, the term odd prime refers to any prime number greater than 2. Similarly, when written in the usual decimal system, all prime numbers larger than 5 end in 1, 3, 7, or 9, since even numbers are multiples of 2 and numbers ending in 0 or 5 are multiples of 5.

original_text: In cases where the criminalized behavior is pure speech, civil disobedience can consist simply of engaging in the forbidden speech. An example would be WBAI's broadcasting the track "Filthy Words" from a George Carlin comedy album, after a 1973 Supreme Court decision temporarily prohibited its broadcast. The execution of laws which have outlived their usefulness, and the disestablishment of policies that inhibit freedom. For example, the burning of draft cards in the 1960s was intended to protest the Vietnam War. Breaking a law which is believed never to have been valid. For example, prior to the repeal of prohibition, there were groups such as The Woman's Organization for National Prohibition Reform. During the Vietnam War, some people intentionally destroyed their draft cards as an act of civil disobedience, in spite of the fact that this was illegal. A more passive and symbolic civil disobedience takes the form of nonviolent protesters obstructing a street or highway. Such nonviolent physical obstruction is usually done in small numbers. If done as a mass protest, or if it employs more aggressive tactics, it is usually called a blockade, which is a more confrontational and less civil form of civil disobedience. In a variation on nonviolent obstruction, a group may decamp from its normal location and occupy a site that is more symbolic or otherwise useful to the cause. These tactics of occupation are usually followed by arrests, but in some cases, such as the Occupy Wall Street movement, the occupiers continue to occupy for several weeks or months. Because civil disobedience is intended to be nonviolent, it is normally accepted that the protesters will avoid any physical altercation with the authorities. One of the best-known examples of this is Martin Luther King's 1963 Letter from Birmingham Jail. He explains that the "Birmingham police have shown consistently that they will not protect the lives and property of Negroes." Therefore, he argues, it is only by disobeying an unjust law that the higher moral principle can be made clear to the police and the government. Similarly, Gandhi argued that "civil disobedience can be civil only if the protesters mindfully put their own lives and bodies at risk by resisting the police." In this view, it is the willingness of the protesters to accept punishment (by doing so, following the precepts of non-violence) for their actions that differentiates it from simple law-breaking. The theory behind civil disobedience is that a government's foundation is dependent upon the consent of the governed. Civil disobedience is thus a mechanism to express, reinforce, or indicate the withdrawal of the consent on which the government's authority is completely dependent. In other words, if enough of the governed withdraw their consent from a law, government can no longer claim that law is valid, and the law becomes a "dead letter." The government cannot be the final arbiter of its own legitimacy, since it might have a vested interest in immunizing its own authority from criticism. If the government is not the source of the law, then it cannot be the source of its own authority, because there would be no way for the government to say that its authority applies to itself. To summarize: the government cannot be the source of its own authority, because if the government determines its own authority, then it would be the source of its own authority. But the government is not the source of its own authority, so the government cannot be the source of its own authority. This contradiction is resolved by positing a higher source of authority, which does not depend on the government's say-so, and which therefore provides a basis for challenging the government's claims. In the United States, the higher source of authority is usually regarded to be the Constitution, which is regarded as a social contract binding the government, not the governed. In other societies, the source of authority may be religious. Gandhi's concept of civil disobedience is similar to, but differs in important respects from, Socrates' civil disobedience. Socrates' civil disobedience was that of not accepting the majority opinion that sentenced him to death. Gandhi's civil disobedience was that of not accepting the British tax laws. Gandhi's disobedience of the British law is an important part of his philosophy of nonviolent resistance. It was grounded in the principle that when a government
text: Civil disobedience is the act of doing something which is illegal, but which is not criminalised by the laws of the country it is done in.

original_text: Jacques Legardeur de Saint-Pierre, who succeeded Marin as commander of the French forces after the latter died on October 29, invited Washington to dine with him. Over dinner, Washington presented the French commander with a proposal that would free hundreds of American troops to fight on land, if not the sea. The troops in question were some 3,000 Continentals under Brigadier General David Wooster, who had been sent to defend Newport in August, but had never made it to the island. Wooster's men were now in the process of marching up from New York to join Washington in White Plains. What if, Washington asked Legardeur, they were instead diverted to Newport? There, they could serve as the French navy's army, marching overland from the mainland and joining French forces already on the island. The French commander was delighted. Such a plan would free up the French fleet to sail elsewhere, and the presence of a few hundred Americans on the island would significantly strengthen the French position. That night, Legardeur and his officers presented the proposal to the French commander, the Comte d'Estaing, who approved. The next morning, d'Estaing and Legardeur sent Washington a letter, confirming their agreement. "We think it so interesting to the welfare of the united cause that we do not doubt your consenting to it." On the surface, Washington's acceptance of the proposal seems baffling. After all, he had only just arrived in White Plains, where he was struggling to organize an army to oppose the British. And yet, the proposal came with a tempting side benefit: if the French occupied Newport, it would remove the British fleet's ability to threaten New York from the sea, and might even provide an opportunity to strike against the enemy's New York base. Furthermore, the proposal seemed to fit with Washington's overall strategic objective. For years, the goal had been to expel the British from North America, and now, with the French fleet in New York waters, the moment seemed ripe to accomplish that objective. But it was a risk. If the French were unable to hold the island, the British would still be able to strike at New York, and Washington would be left with a weakened army in New York and an isolated French force on the island. On November 5, Washington gave his consent to the French proposal, with the caveat that they were to occupy the island only as long as the war continued, and that the British should be permitted to evacuate. With that, d'Estaing and his forces sailed for Newport. The next morning, Washington, as promised, set off with the rest of his army for White Plains. On November 11, Washington reached White Plains and, with the arrival of the Continental Army, the town of White Plains began to buzz with activity. The British force under General Howe, which had occupied the town only a few days earlier, was now nowhere to be seen. On the morning of November 3, they had set off, chasing after the Americans, who had once again moved their army up the Bronx River to a position on the high ground overlooking White Plains. The British pursued them, and at midday, the armies clashed again. But the Americans were too far away from the British lines, and the battle was over quickly, with the Continental Army once again withdrawing before the British force. The British, though, were in no shape to pursue the Americans. They had lost two hundred men, and Washington had lost less than fifty. The British had also suffered a serious blow when General Howe, who had been leading the pursuit, was felled by a musket ball to the head. Howe was carried back to New York, where he lay in a fever for several days before recovering. The British army now under the command of General William Howe, his brother. After retreating from White Plains, Washington's army crossed the Croton River and marched on to the next ridge, where they now regrouped. The position they had taken was a defensible one, with the British facing a steep climb to reach them. After the failed engagement at White Plains, the British seemed to have lost their taste for battle, and instead of advancing, they settled into a position across the river. For the next several days, Washington and his men remained at White Plains, preparing for battle. On November 11, the army was reinforced by the arrival of Major General Charles Lee's division, and by the following day, it had grown to over 20,000 men.

original_text: The two symbols most commonly associated with pharmacy in English-speaking countries are the mortar and pestle and the (recipere) character, which is often written as "Rx" in typed text. The show globe was also used until the early 20th century. Pharmacy organizations often use other symbols, such as the Bowl of Hygieia which is often used in the Netherlands, conical measures, and caduceuses in their logos. Other symbols are common in different countries: the green Greek cross in France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India, the increasingly rare Gaper in the Netherlands, and a red stylized letter A in Germany and Austria (from Apotheke, the German word for pharmacy, from the same Greek root as the English word'apothecary.

original_text: In 1854 at Ballarat there was an armed rebellion against the government of Victoria by miners protesting against mining taxes (the "Eureka Stockade. This was crushed by British troops, but some of the leaders of the protest subsequently were elected to the Victorian parliament. Between 1855 and 1890, the six colonies individually gained responsible government, managing most of their own affairs while remaining part of the British Empire. The Colonial Office in London retained control of some matters, notably foreign affairs, defence, and international shipping. On 1 January 1901, the colonies of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, and Tasmania federated, forming the Commonwealth of Australia. The new constitutional monarchy of Australia came into being under the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act (Imp). This had been passed by the British parliament in 1900. The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) was formed in 1911 as the location for the future federal capital of Canberra. It was formally brought under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth by the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. The Northern Territory was transferred from the control of the South Australian government to the Commonwealth's in 1911. In 1927, the United Kingdom Parliament passed the Statute of Westminster, conferring a large degree of power on the Dominions, including the Australian Commonwealth. Under the statute, the United Kingdom could no longer make new laws for the Australian Commonwealth without its consent. However, the Australian Commonwealth did not ratify the statute until 1942. Australian history is characterised by a strong emphasis on political and economic liberalism. The most important event in the 20th century history of Australia is the increase of economic ties between the Australian economy and the economies of the east Asia region, which started in the 1960s and 1970s. This led to economic reform through the 1980s and 1990s. There was less emphasis on government regulation and protection of Australian businesses. In the late 1960s, Australian Prime Minister John Gorton, Labour Prime Minister Gough Whitlam and Democrat Senator Don Chipp, were involved in an intense debate about multiculturalism in Australia. Australia has always had a very multicultural society, but in the 1960s the population of Australia had its largest percentage of people from British background. In the 1960s Australia's population was very different to that of the 21st century. There was a policy of assisted passage, which meant that the Australian government paid part of the air fare for people to migrate to Australia from Europe. The immigration policy of the 1960s encouraged European people from Britain, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Yugoslavia to migrate to Australia. In the 1970s there was a second wave of immigration from Asian countries like Vietnam. Multiculturalism was a policy of the Whitlam Labour government. Whitlam abolished assisted passage and did not encourage new migrants to Australia. This meant that the Australian economy had a shortage of labour in the 1970s. In 1972, the Australian population was 13 million. In 2009, the population was 22 million, with over 45 of the population born outside Australia or having a parent born outside Australia. During the 1980s and 1990s, the Australian economy was hit by a severe economic recession, which led to a change of government. The government of the day made large cuts to education and public services. During this time, the Prime Minister, Paul Keating, said in a speech in 1992 that Australia should not be a monocultural society. In the 1990s, Australia continued to have a large immigration program. The immigrants came from many different countries. In 1996, Pauline Hanson was elected to the Australian House of Representatives for the party One Nation. She made a speech in parliament, in which she said Australia was being swamped by Asians. This speech helped her to become well known. In 1998, John Howard of the Liberal party was elected Prime Minister. Howard's government cut immigration to Australia. This was because Australia was having a recession in the 1990s. In 2001, there was a large wave of immigration

original_text: The Romans kept eight legions in five bases along the Rhine. The actual number of legions present at any base or in all, depended on whether a state or threat of war existed at the time. The Roman Empire divided the army into different classes. The legions were the elite heavy infantry. Each legion was composed of ten cohorts of 480 men. The Roman legion was composed of 5,280 infantry, 120 cavalry and 30 trumpeters and standard bearers. The Romans also had auxiliary troops that served with the legions. These troops were generally from the area where the legion was stationed. They were paid less than the legionaries but were considered to be professional soldiers. They served for twenty five years.
text: The Roman legions were the army of the Roman Empire and were stationed along the banks of the Rhine river in Germany. The Romans also had auxiliary troops that served with the legions.

original_text: Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder (or Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (nee Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours. His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council. The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant. He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been close to one of them, Jacob. Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer. He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in 1497, where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498. The three schools focused on the so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic. Luther later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.

original_text: In April 1191 Richard the Lion-hearted left Messina with a large fleet in order to reach Acre. But a storm dispersed the fleet. After some searching, it was discovered that the boat carrying his sister and his fiancee Berengaria was anchored on the south coast of Cyprus, together with the wrecks of several other ships, including the treasure ship. Survivors of the wrecks had been taken prisoner by the island's despot Isaac Komnenos. On 1 May 1191, Richard's fleet arrived in the port of Limassol on Cyprus. He ordered Isaac to release the prisoners and the treasure. Isaac refused, so Richard landed his troops and took Limassol.

original_text: The Victorian parts of the building have a complex history, with piecemeal additions by different architects. Founded in May 1852, it was not until 1857 that the museum moved to the present site. This area of London was known as Brompton but had been renamed South Kensington. The land was occupied by Brompton Park House, which was extended, most notably by the "Brompton Boilers," which were starkly utilitarian iron galleries with a temporary look and were later dismantled and used to build the VA Museum of Childhood. The first building to be erected that still forms part of the museum was the Sheepshanks Gallery in 1857 on the eastern side of the garden. Its architect was civil engineer Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers, who was appointed by Cole. The next major expansions were designed by the same architect, the Turner and Vernon galleries built 1858-9 to house the eponymous collections (later transferred to the Tate Gallery) and now used as the picture galleries and tapestry gallery respectively. The North and South Courts, were then built, both of which opened by June 1862. They now form the galleries for temporary exhibitions and are directly behind the Sheepshanks Gallery. text: The Victorian parts of the building have a complex history, with piecemeal additions by different architects. Founded in May 1852, it was not until 1857 that the museum moved to the present site. This area of London was known as Brompton but had been renamed South Kensington. The land was occupied by Brompton Park House, which was extended, most notably by the "Brompton Boilers," which were starkly utilitarian iron galleries with a temporary look and were later dismantled and used to build the VA Museum of Childhood. The first building to be erected that still forms part of the museum was the Sheepshanks Gallery in 1857 on the eastern side of the garden. Its architect was civil engineer Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers, who was appointed by Cole. The next major expansions were designed by the same architect, the Turner and Vernon galleries built 1858-9 to house the eponymous collections (later transferred to the Tate Gallery) and now used as the picture galleries and tapestry gallery respectively. The North and South Courts, were then built, both of which opened by June 1862. They now form the galleries for temporary exhibitions and are directly behind the Sheepshanks Gallery. On the very northern edge of the site is situated the Secretariat Wing, also built in 1862 this houses the offices and board room etc. and is not open to the public.

original_text: The network's troubles with sustaining existing series and gaining new hits spilled over into its 2010-11 schedule: ABC's dramas during that season continued to fail, with the midseason forensic investigation drama Body of Proof being the only one that was renewed for a second season. The network also struggled to establish new comedies to support the previous year's debuts, with only late-season premiere Happy Endings earning a second season. Meanwhile, the new lows hit by Brothers Sisters led to its cancellation, and the previous year's only drama renewal, V, also failed to earn another season after a low-rated midseason run. Despite this and another noticeable ratings decline, ABC would manage to outrate NBC for third place by a larger margin than the previous year.

original_text: Teachers face several occupational hazards in their line of work, including occupational stress, which can negatively impact teachers' mental and physical health, productivity, and students' performance. Stress can be caused by organizational change, relationships with students, fellow teachers, and administrative personnel, working environment, expectations to substitute, long hours with a heavy workload, and inspections. Teachers are also at high risk for occupational burnout.

Teachers are also at high risk for occupational burnout.

original_text: In Ireland, private schools (Irish: scoil phriobhaideach) are unusual because a certain number of teacher's salaries are paid by the State. If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they have to pay for them themselves. The vast majority of schools are run by religious orders. The figures show that 86 of the students attending secondary school are in the voluntary secondary schools. The difference between the private and the voluntary schools is that the private schools are self-financing and have their own boards of management while the voluntary schools are mainly or wholly State-financed and have State-appointed boards of management. This page was last changed on 14 April 2013, at 04:56.

original_text: However, this definition is disputed by Thoreau's political philosophy pitching the conscience vs. the collective. The individual is the final judge of right and wrong. More than this, since only individuals act, only individuals can act unjustly. When the government knocks on the door, it is an individual in the form of a postman or tax collector whose hand hits the wood. Before Thoreau's imprisonment, when a confused taxman had wondered aloud about how to handle his refusal to pay, Thoreau had advised, "Resign." If a man chose to be an agent of injustice, then Thoreau insisted on confronting him with the fact that he was making a choice. But if government is "the voice of the people," as it is often called, shouldn't that voice be heeded? Thoreau admits that government may express the will of the majority but it may also express nothing more than the will of elite politicians. Even a good form of government is "liable to be abused and perverted before the people can act through it." Moreover, even if a government did express the voice of the people, this fact would not compel the obedience of individuals who disagree with what is being said. The majority may be powerful but it is not necessarily right. What, then, is the proper relationship between the individual and the government?

original_text: Internet2 is a not-for-profit United States computer networking consortium led by members from the research and education communities, industry, and government. The Internet2 community, in partnership with Qwest, built the first Internet2 Network, called Abilene, in 1998 and was a prime investor in the National LambdaRail (NLR) project. In 2006, Internet2 announced a partnership with Level 3 Communications to launch a brand new nationwide network, boosting its capacity from 10 Gbits to 100 Gbits. In October, 2007, Internet2 officially retired Abilene and now refers to its new, higher capacity network as the Internet2 Network.

original_text: Embedded in the thylakoid membranes are important protein complexes which carry out the light reactions of photosynthesis. Photosystem II and photosystem I contain light-harvesting complexes with chlorophyll and carotenoids that absorb light and transfer the energy to the reaction center. The photosystems are organized in the thylakoid membranes as a series of enzyme complexes in a linear arrangement. The reactions catalyzed by the complexes occur simultaneously, and each step leads to the next in the electron transport chain, allowing the transfer of electrons from water to NADP. The light reactions of photosynthesis occur in two steps: the light dependent reactions and the light independent reactions. The light dependent reactions use light energy to make the energy-storage molecule ATP and the reduced electron carrier NADPH. During the light dependent reactions, the absorption of light by chlorophyll in the antenna complexes of photosystem II and photosystem I is used to pump protons across the thylakoid membrane. The pumped protons are used to make ATP in the cytoplasm by chemiosmosis. The energy-storage molecule NADPH is made by the light-dependent reactions when electrons derived from water are transported through photosystem I and photosystem II. The light independent reactions, also called the Calvin cycle, use the energy-storage molecules to make organic molecules from carbon dioxide. A step in the light dependent reactions of photosynthesis is the transport of electrons from water to NADP. In the following figure, label the electron acceptor and the electron donor. A step in the light dependent reactions of photosynthesis is the transport of electrons from water to NADP. In the following figure, label the electron acceptor and the electron donor. Is this process exergonic or endergonic? Another step in the light dependent reactions of photosynthesis is the transport of electrons from water to NADP. In the following figure, label the electron acceptor and the electron donor. Is this process exergonic or endergonic? This quiz and worksheet combo will help you quickly assess your understanding of the light reactions of photosynthesis. The quiz questions will test your knowledge of the main players in the light reactions, and the main products of the reactions.

original_text: Kenya is active in several sports, among them cricket, rallying, football, rugby union and boxing. The country is known chiefly for its dominance in middle-distance and long-distance athletics, having consistently produced Olympic and Commonwealth Games champions in various distance events, especially in 800 m, 1,500 m, 3,000 m steeplechase, 5,000 m, 10,000 m and the marathon. Kenyan athletes (particularly Kalenjin) continue to dominate the world of distance running, although competition from Morocco and Ethiopia has reduced this supremacy. Kenya's best-known athletes included the four-time women's Boston Marathon winner and two-time world champion Catherine Ndereba, 800m world record holder David Rudisha, former Marathon world record-holder Paul Tergat, and John Ngugi.

original_text: After the 1940s, the Gothic style on campus began to give way to modern styles. In 1955, Eero Saarinen was contracted to develop a second master plan, which led to the construction of buildings both north and south of the Midway, including the Laird Bell Law Quadrangle (a complex designed by Saarinen); a series of arts buildings; a building designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe for the university's School of Social Service Administration;, a building which is to become the home of the Harris School of Public Policy Studies by Edward Durrell Stone, and the Regenstein Library, the largest building on campus, a brutalist structure designed by Walter Netsch of the Chicago firm Skidmore, Owings Merrill. Another master plan, designed in 1999 and updated in 2004, produced the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center (2003), the Max Palevsky Residential Commons (2001), South Campus Residence Hall and dining commons (2009), a new children's hospital, and other construction, expansions, and restorations. In 2011, the university completed the glass dome-shaped Joe and Rika Mansueto Library, which provides a grand reading room for the university library and prevents the need for an off-campus book depository.

original_text: Deforestation is the conversion of forested areas to non-forested areas. The main sources of deforestation in the Amazon are human settlement and development of the land. Prior to the early 1970s, the Amazon was almost completely untouched by humans. The increasing demand for food and resources caused the deforestation of the Amazon. In the 1970s and 1980s, the Brazilian government encouraged colonization of the Amazon by creating infrastructure, such as the Trans-Amazonian Highway. The human activity in the Amazon has continued to increase over the past 20 years. Currently, over 20 of the Amazon has been deforested, with the majority of deforestation occurring in Brazil. The main deforestation in Brazil is due to land clearing for cattle ranching and agriculture. Brazil is the world's leading exporter of beef and soybeans, which have been a main driving force for the deforestation of the Amazon. In the Amazon, deforestation is also causing a decrease in biodiversity. There is a high rate of deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon due to illegal gold mining, leading to habitat loss and endangerment of many species. The loss of biodiversity is a major concern for the Amazon, as biodiversity provides many services such as carbon storage, water filtration, and prevention of soil erosion. The decrease in biodiversity could have long-term effects on the Amazon.
text: The Amazon rainforest is one of the world's most important natural areas, but it is also one of its most threatened due to the increasing rate of deforestation.

original_text: Since 7500 yr ago, a situation with tides and currents, very similar to present has existed. Rates of sea-level rise had dropped so far, that natural sedimentation by the Rhine River had almost kept up with the sea-level rise. In the Roman period, the Rhine delta was the largest in Europe, and an important strategic military-political factor. It has long been known that the Roman port of Batavia was situated on the southern side of the mouth of the Oude Rijn. The port has been investigated by many archaeologists, and the remains of the port have been surveyed, but the actual location of the port was not known. For archaeologists the Roman port of Batavia has been an enigma. The port, and the river have long been submerged, and it has not been possible to locate the port. The location of the port of Batavia, has been determined by geological and geophysical surveys, which have shown the location of the river mouth, and the port itself. Using geological and geophysical surveys it was possible to determine the position of the mouth of the Oude Rijn, and the positions of the Roman port of Batavia. In the years 2002, 2004 and 2007 geological and geophysical surveys were carried out. The results of these surveys were the basis for the archaeological research. The geophysical and geological survey was carried out from the shore at the north side of the Oude Rijn, to the sea. The geological research, and geophysical survey were carried out in two phases. In the first phase, geological survey, and geophysical survey were carried out to determine the geological situation of the present day coast, and the presence of archaeological remains in the shore. The geophysical survey was carried out with a geophysical proton magnetometer, with a loop size of 32 x 25 cm. The survey was carried out at 10 m intervals. The geophysical results were interpreted by Dr. J.H.M. Jansen of Geoscan bv. The geophysical survey showed no archaeological remains in the shore. The geological survey was carried out with a Sonic penetrator. The penetrator was used to determine the depth of the palaeosol. The palaeosol is the original soil at the time the area was not submerged by the sea. The results of the geological survey were used to determine the position of the river mouth. The results of the geological survey showed that the palaeosol had disappeared over most of the shore. This indicates that the shore has been submerged by the sea. The only place where the palaeosol was still present was at the eastern end of the survey. The palaeosol was present at 2.5 m below present sea-level. This indicates that the river mouth was at the present position of the eastern tip of the land spit. In the second phase, the geological and geophysical surveys were carried out in the area of the river mouth. The geophysical survey was carried out with a proton magnetometer, with a loop size of 32 x 25 cm. The survey was carried out at 10 m intervals. The geophysical survey showed two linear anomalies in the south-west part of the survey. The anomalies were interpreted as remains of ships. The geological survey was carried out with a Sonic penetrator. The penetrator was used to determine the depth of the palaeosol. The results of the geological survey showed that the palaeosol was present at 2.5 m below present sea-level. This indicates that the river mouth was at the present position of the eastern tip of the land spit. The results of the geological survey also showed a significant amount of shells. These shells were of a type of shell that can only grow in saline water. The results of the geological survey showed that the river mouth was at the present position of the eastern tip of the land spit. The results of the geophysical survey showed that the river mouth was at the present position of the eastern tip of the land spit. The geophysical survey of the river mouth showed two linear anomalies in the south-west part of the survey. The anomalies were interpreted as remains of ships. The geological survey of the river mouth showed that the river mouth was at the present position of the eastern tip of the land spit. The results of the geophys
