original_text: The Tech Coast is a moniker that has gained use as a descriptor for the region's diversified technology and industrial base as well as its multitude of prestigious and world-renowned research institutions and universities. The region is defined by its technology clusters in aerospace, biotechnology, computers and peripherals, electronics, telecommunications, defense, nanotechnology, homeland security, medical devices, environmental technology, transportation and more. "Tech Coast" has also been used to describe the region by some of the nation's most influential corporate leaders and news media. The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) has established the Tech Coast to represent the region's innovation and technology industries. "There is no doubt that the San Diego region is a global leader in technology, innovation and research," said Mark Cafferty, President and CEO of the EDC. "This new brand will help to communicate that message around the world." The Tech Coast's vibrant entrepreneurial ecosystem has helped San Diego earn the reputation of being the nation's most innovative economy. The region is home to a growing number of tech startups and many of the nation's most innovative and entrepreneurial companies. In 2014, San Diego was the second-most venture capital funded city in the nation, according to the National Venture Capital Association (NVCA). The San Diego Region's robust innovation economy is part of what has attracted more than 350 high-profile corporate leaders to invest in the EDC's exclusive leadership group, the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) Board of Directors. "The most successful companies are those that adapt to change and embrace innovation," said Ted Roth, president of Shea Homes and vice chair of the EDC Board of Directors. "San Diego's economy is built on a foundation of innovation, which makes the Tech Coast name and logo a natural fit. The Tech Coast brand clearly communicates our region's innovation economy." San Diego has been a hub for technology and innovation for more than 50 years. "The technology sector is part of our region's DNA. The EDC's new Tech Coast brand and logo captures the spirit of innovation that has helped drive our region's economy for decades," said Bruce Kern, executive chairman of the EDC Board of Directors and chairman and CEO of Sudberry Properties. San Diego's technology industry is a strong and growing part of the region's economy. The industry added more than 8,500 jobs in 2013, according to the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation. "Our region is home to a dynamic technology industry," said Bill Walton, EDC Board member and a leader in San Diego's technology industry. "The Tech Coast brand and logo will help us communicate to the world the many ways that San Diego's innovation economy is influencing the global market." The EDC is committed to continuing to build the regional economy through job creation, entrepreneurship, global competitiveness and military advocacy. To learn more about the Tech Coast, visit .
text: The San Diego region has announced the launch of a new regional brand, the Tech Coast, which aims to showcase the region's innovation and technology-based economy.

original_text: Tesla worked every day from 9:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. or later, with dinner from exactly 8:10 p.m., at Delmonico's restaurant and later the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Tesla would telephone his dinner order to the headwaiter, who also could be the only one to serve him. "The meal was required to be ready at eight o'clock.... He dined alone, except on the rare occasions when he would give a dinner to a group to meet his social obligations. Tesla would then resume his work, often until 3:00 a.m.":283, 286

Tesla would telephone his dinner order to the headwaiter, who also could be the only one to serve him. "The meal was required to be ready at eight o'clock.... He dined alone, except on the rare occasions when he would give a dinner to a group to meet his social obligations. Tesla would then resume his work, often until 3:00 a.m.":283, 286

original_text: Due to its electronegativity, oxygen forms chemical bonds with almost all other elements to give corresponding oxides. The surface of most metals, such as aluminium and titanium, are oxidized in the presence of air and become coated with a thin film of oxide that passivates the metal and slows further corrosion. Many oxides of the transition metals are non-stoichiometric compounds, with slightly less metal than the chemical formula would show. For example, the mineral FeO (wustite) is written as Fe 1 - xO, where x is usually around 0.05.

For example, the mineral FeO (wustite) is written as Fe 1 - xO, where x is usually around 0.05.

original_text: Plastoglobuli (singular plastoglobulus, sometimes spelled plastoglobule (s, are spherical bubbles of lipids and proteins about 45-60 nanometers across. They are surrounded by a lipid monolayer. Plastoglobuli are found in all chloroplasts, but become more common when the chloroplast is under oxidative stress, or when it ages and transitions into a gerontoplast. Plastoglobuli also exhibit a greater size variation under these conditions. They are also common in etioplasts, but decrease in number as the etioplasts mature into chloroplasts.

original_text: The owner produces a list of requirements for a project, giving an overall view of the project's goals. Several DB contractors present different ideas about how to accomplish these goals. The DB owner selects the DB contractor whose price is based on how to best meet the owner's needs. The DB contractor, in cooperation with the owner, determines the project's scope and cost. This helps establish the project's budget and schedule. The DB owner and the DB contractor then finalize the project's scope, budget, and schedule. The DB contractor begins to identify qualified subcontractors to perform the work. The DB contractor and the DB owner review the plans and specifications for constructability and cost efficiency. The DB contractor presents the plans and specifications to the subcontractors. The subcontractors are asked to determine their costs. The DB contractor then prepares a final GMP for the project, which includes all the subcontractors' costs. The DB contractor and the DB owner negotiate a mutually agreed-upon contract. The DB contractor presents a GMP proposal for the project. The DB contractor prepares a schedule for the project. The DB contractor prepares a list of project risks and a plan to minimize their impacts. The DB contractor then begins construction. The DB contractor and the DB owner identify problems that may arise during construction. This helps to resolve them quickly. The DB contractor monitors the project schedule and budget. The DB contractor prepares a list of potential changes and their costs. The DB owner and the DB contractor then negotiate the changes and their costs. original_text: Exceptional examples of the bourgeois architecture of the later periods were not restored by the communist authorities after the war (like mentioned Kronenberg Palace and Insurance Company Rosja building) or they were rebuilt in socialist realism style (like Warsaw Philharmony edifice originally inspired by Palais Garnier in Paris). Despite that the Warsaw University of Technology building is the most interesting of the late 19th-century architecture. Some 19th-century buildings in the Praga district (the Vistula's right bank) have been restored although many have been poorly maintained. Warsaw's municipal government authorities have decided to rebuild the Saxon Palace and the Bruhl Palace, the most distinctive buildings in prewar Warsaw.

original_text: The Pilgrim Street building was refurbished between November 2006 and May 2008; during the refurbishment works, the cinema relocated to the Old Town Hall, Gateshead. In May 2008 the Tyneside Cinema reopened in the restored and refurbished original building. The site currently houses three cinemas, including the restored Classic - the United Kingdom's last surviving news cinema still in full-time operation - alongside two new screens, a roof extension containing the Tyneside Bar, and dedicated education and teaching suites.

original_text: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

original_text: Deforestation is the conversion of forested areas to non-forested areas. The main sources of deforestation in the Amazon are human settlement and development of the land. Prior to the early 1960s, access to the forest's interior was highly restricted, and the forest remained basically intact. Farms established during the 1960s were based on crop cultivation and the slash and burn method. However, the colonists were unable to manage their fields and the crops because of the loss of soil fertility and weed invasion. The soils in the Amazon are productive for just a short period of time, so farmers are constantly moving to new areas and clearing more land. These farming practices led to deforestation and caused extensive environmental damage. Deforestation is considerable, and areas cleared of forest are visible to the naked eye from outer space.

original_text: Closely related fields in theoretical computer science are analysis of algorithms and computability theory. A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational complexity theory is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem, whereas the latter asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem. More precisely, it tries to classify problems that can or cannot be solved with appropriately restricted resources. In turn, imposing restrictions on the available resources is what distinguishes computational complexity from computability theory: the latter theory asks what kind of problems can, in principle, be solved algorithmically.

original_text: Recently, chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified crops. Since, in most flowering plants, chloroplasts are not inherited from the male parent, transgenes in these plastids cannot be transmitted to future generations of plants, making chloroplasts an interesting option for the development of sterile, transgenic crops. For example, scientists from Monsanto and Syngenta have already developed plants with plastid-encoded resistance against some pathogens. However, so far, the genes responsible for the resistance have been inserted into the chloroplast genome by means of natural recombination. A recent article in Current Biology, by Katz et al., describes how scientists have successfully introduced transgenes into chloroplasts by means of genetic engineering. They succeeded in expressing a gene for a fluorescent protein in tobacco chloroplasts, making the plants glow green. The researchers found that this expression was stable, in contrast to the previously described genes for antimicrobial proteins, which were inherited only by a few percent of the offspring plants. I was interested in finding out more about this research, so I contacted the lead author of the article, Steve Katz, and asked him a few questions about the work. Dr. Katz kindly agreed to answer my questions and the result is a very interesting interview, giving a great insight into the history of the project and future prospects. Read it here.

original_text: By 1620 the Huguenots were on the defensive, and the government increasingly applied pressure. A series of three small civil wars known as the Huguenot rebellions broke out, mainly in southwestern France, between 1621 and 1629. revolted against royal authority. The uprising occurred a decade following the death of Henry IV, a Huguenot before converting to Catholicism, who had protected Protestants through the Edict of Nantes. His successor Louis XIII, under the regency of his Italian Catholic mother Marie de' Medici, became more intolerant of Protestantism. The Huguenots respond by establishing independent political and military structures, establishing diplomatic contacts with foreign powers, and openly revolting against central power. The rebellions were implacably suppressed by the French Crown.[citation needed]

original_text: In 1521 Luther dealt largely with prophecy, in which he broadened the foundations of the Reformation placing them on prophetic faith. His main interest was centered on the prophecy of the Little Horn in Daniel 8:9-12, 23-25. The antichrist of 2 Thessalonians 2 was identified as the power of the Papacy. So too was the Little Horn of Daniel 7, coming up among the divisions of Rome, explicitly applied.

So too was the Little Horn of Daniel 7, coming up among the divisions of Rome, explicitly applied.

original_text: Non-revolutionary civil disobedience is a simple disobedience of laws on the grounds that they are judged "wrong" by an individual conscience, or as part of an effort to render certain laws ineffective, to prevent their intended purpose, or to end their enforcement. It is a form of civil resistance. Civil disobedience differs from other forms of protest in that, to be civil disobedience, it must be done openly, with the protestors declaring their actions and accepting the punishment for them. The philosophy of non-violence and civil disobedience was first practiced by Henry David Thoreau in the essay Civil Disobedience, which was written as a reaction against slavery and the Mexican-American War. Unless indicated otherwise, the text in this article is either based on Wikipedia article "Civil disobedience" or another language Wikipedia page thereof used under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License; or on original research by Jahsonic and friends. See Art and Popular Culture's copyright notice. Retrieved from "

original_text: The mouth of the Rhine into Lake Constance forms an inland delta. The delta is delimited in the West by the Alter Rhein Old Rhine and in the East by the Neue Donau New Danube. These form the border of the 170 ha nature reserve, which is, however, not accessible to the public. Already in 1889 the first bird observation station in Europe was established here. In 1956 the area was declared a nature reserve. The area is famous among birdwatchers for its large numbers of birds, particularly in the migration seasons. 295 species have been observed here so far, of which about 80 are breeding birds. On the feeding grounds of the delta, even rare birds such as the white-tailed eagle, the black stork, the crane or the black kite can be seen. The area is especially popular with water birds. The delta is the most important resting place for migratory birds in Germany. The "Neue Donau" channel forms a natural border between the nature reserve and the residential area. The natural spectacle of the delta can be admired best from the two observation towers. The Rhine Valley from the observation tower on the Alter Rhein offers a unique perspective. The nature reserve is home to countless species of birds. They are a special attraction especially for bird watchers. Another nature reserve is located directly on the shores of Lake Constance: The "Naturschutzgebiet Scherzinger Ried" This is where the Rhine flows into Lake Constance and forms the largest inland delta in Europe. The area is a paradise for water birds.

original_text: Moderate and reformist Islamists who accept and work within the democratic process include parties like the Tunisian Ennahda Movement. Jamaat-e-Islami of Pakistan is basically a socio-political and democratic Vanguard party but has also gained political influence through military coup d'etat in past. The Islamist groups like Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hamas in Palestine participate in democratic and political process as well as armed attacks, seeking to abolish the state of Israel. Radical Islamist organizations like al-Qaeda and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad, and groups such as the Taliban, entirely reject democracy, often declaring as kuffar those Muslims who support it (see takfirism), as well as calling for violentoffensive jihad or urging and conducting attacks on a religious basis.

original_text: Louis XIV gained the throne in 1643 and acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert. At first he sent missionaries, backed by a fund to financially reward converts to Catholicism. Then he imposed penalties, closed Huguenot schools and excluded them from favored professions. Escalating, he instituted dragonnades, which included the occupation and looting of Huguenot homes by military troops, in an effort to forcibly convert them. In 1685, he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau, revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.[citation needed]

In 1685, he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau, revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.[citation needed]

original_text: Starting in the late 1950s, American computer scientist Paul Baran developed the concept Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant, efficient routing method for telecommunication messages as part of a research program at the RAND Corporation, funded by the US Department of Defense. This concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established principles of pre-allocation of network bandwidth, largely fortified by the development of telecommunications in the Bell System. The new concept found little resonance among network implementers until the independent work of Donald Davies at the National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom) (NPL) in the late 1960s. Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe in the decade following, including the incorporation of the concept in the early ARPANET in the United States.

original_text: While most Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs and require a valid prescription, some Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs without requiring a prescription. Many customers order drugs from such pharmacies to avoid the inconvenience of visiting a doctor or to obtain medications which their doctors were unwilling to prescribe. However, this practice has been criticized as potentially dangerous, especially by those who feel that only doctors can reliably assess contraindications, risk-to-benefit ratios, and suitability of a medication to a given patient. Some, such as the Electronic Frontier Foundation, have argued that the inability to get a prescription drug from an Internet pharmacy can cause delay in treatment for those without access to other sources. The Alliance for Safe Online Pharmacies also argues that the lack of physical examination may lead to improper prescriptions for medications that have side effects such as addiction. Some online pharmacies also offer services to customers over the internet. The scope of the services varies widely and includes prescription drug renewals, shipping of routine refills, specialty medicine and patient care management. Some online pharmacies also provide services like online doctor consultation. Some online pharmacies (e.g. 121doc.co.uk) are now offering services (like free delivery) to their customers and do not require a prescription for their products. The Medicines Act 1968 allows the sale of unlicensed medicines with the approval of a medical practitioner. This can be in the form of a prescription or a direction given by a doctor in a prescription-only medicine's patient leaflet. The sale of unlicensed medicines online is still illegal in the UK; however, there is no regulation for marketing and advertising of unlicensed medicines to the public. The industry standard for website certification is the Norton Secured Seal, which is only awarded to pharmacies that comply with the strictest safety standards and is the only safety seal backed by Norton's 50 million global customers. The term "online pharmacy" is a contentious issue as there are several companies that operate as online pharmacies in the U.S., however, many are not certified to sell pharmaceuticals. They are referred to as online pharmacies, but many are really online stores that sell a wide variety of products in addition to pharmaceuticals. The term "online pharmacy" is used to refer to both legitimate online pharmacies and illicit online pharmacies. In the UK, the sale of prescription medicines is allowed only with a prescription from a medical practitioner. The Medicines Act 1968 (UK) requires that prescription drugs be sold by a pharmacy only, and that prescription drugs be dispensed by a pharmacist. In the U.S., the federal government has enacted laws to address this issue. The Ryan Haight Online Pharmacy Consumer Protection Act of 2008, which came into law in March 2008, amends the Controlled Substances Act to address online pharmacies. It classifies offences as either prescription drug fraud or prescription drug trafficking. The Controlled Substances Act is the statute that outlaws drugs in the U.S. Some states have also enacted laws against pharmacies operating without a valid physical address within the state. The National Association of Boards of Pharmacy (NABP) operates the .Pharmacy Verified Websites Program, which accredits online pharmacies that meet stringent safety and other criteria. There are also some websites which provide ratings and reviews of online pharmacies. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved RxCut for the sale of prescription drugs by U.S.-based pharmacies. Although the majority of U.S. pharmacies are independently owned, many are operated through mail-order systems. For example, the United States Postal Service operates the largest civilian fleet of vehicles in the world, and is legally allowed to deliver prescription drugs to residents in many states. Costco, Sam's Club, and BJ's are some examples of stores which operate as membership clubs that require a paid membership to purchase prescriptions. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported that the levels of antibiotic resistance in Americans has not decreased over the last decade. text: The sale of prescription drugs over the internet has grown rapidly in recent years and now accounts for more than half of all prescription drugs sold in the US, according to the US Department of Justice.

original_text: Tymnet was an international data communications network headquartered in San Jose, CA that utilized virtual call packet switched technology and used X.25, SNASDLC, BSC and ASCII interfaces to connect host computers (servers) at thousands of large companies, educational institutions, and government agencies. Users typically connected via dial-up connections or dedicated async connections. The business consisted of a large public network that supported dial-up users and a private network business that allowed government agencies and large companies (mostly banks and airlines) to build their own dedicated networks. The private networks were often connected via gateways to the public network to reach locations not on the private network. Tymnet was also connected to dozens of other public networks in the U.S. and internationally via X.25X.75 gateways. (Interesting note: Tymnet was not named after Mr. Tyme. Another employee suggested the name.)

original_text: Tesla served as a vice president of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, the forerunner (along with the Institute of Radio Engineers) of the modern-day IEEE, from 1892 to 1894. He was also involved in establishing the new American Institute of Electrical Engineers (AIEE) as president of the first AIEE board of directors. Tesla is quoted by the New York Times in 1909 as saying, "My apparatus offers no chance whatever to the experimenter to discover some new principle." Others were even more adamant about the impossibility of extracting free energy from the vacuum. As I mentioned, there is a lot of controversy about free energy, so I have to be careful not to get too caught up in that. I must simply present the facts and let you draw your own conclusions. The most popular theoretical model for the electrical effects in the vacuum is known as quantum electrodynamics (QED). QED has been extremely successful in describing the behavior of atoms, molecules, and subatomic particles; however, it is only considered valid at the microscopic level. At the macroscopic level - that is, the level at which we can see things - QED fails miserably when trying to describe the behavior of electricity and magnetism. In 1971, David Bohm, a physicist from London's Birkbeck College, and Basil Hiley, then at Birkbeck and now professor of physics at the University of London, developed the theory of the implicate order. This new approach to physics was based on the phenomenon that subatomic particles are able to remain in contact with one another regardless of the distance separating them. Bohm and Hiley asserted that subatomic particles are able to remain in contact with one another because the separating space is not empty, as has been postulated by scientists since Newton. According to Bohm and Hiley, the universe is filled with a background energy - what Einstein called the ether - which contains an infinite quantity of energy. It is theorized that the vacuum energy is the subtle energy that is tapped by the quantum vacuum devices in order to produce free energy. The idea of the ether goes back to the ancient Greeks, who considered it to be the substance in which the heavenly bodies were suspended. Newton believed in the ether and thought it to be the medium for gravity. In 1905, Einstein showed that Newton's ideas of space and time were incorrect, and that space was curved by matter. Matter tells space how to curve, and space tells matter how to move. Space, then, was no longer regarded as being filled with an ether, but was rather a vacuum. This vacuum was deemed to be completely empty, but later physicists began to suspect that it was not completely empty after all. In the mid 1920s, the American astronomer Edwin Hubble discovered that the universe is expanding. He came to this conclusion after measuring the velocities of distant galaxies and finding that they were all moving away from us. This meant that the universe must have been smaller in the past than it is today. This evidence led Hubble to propose the Big Bang theory, which he presented at the 1929 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in the auditorium of the University of California at Berkeley. According to the Big Bang theory, the universe began in a state of extremely high density and temperature. At some point a cataclysmic event took place, and the universe began expanding. After the Big Bang, the universe remained in a very high temperature state for about 100,000 years. During this time the universe was filled with light in the form of gamma rays and was extremely opaque, like a misty fog. The high temperature and pressure prevented the formation of atoms, and electrons and nuclei of atoms were able to exist freely in a sea of radiation. At some point, however, the high temperature and pressure in the early universe caused it to expand and cool, and the electrons and nuclei were able to combine to form the first atoms. The universe had finally cooled enough to form atoms. The light of the Big Bang traveled freely through the universe for the next 380,000 years, and the universe was finally able to become transparent. The universe had expanded enough that it was no longer opaque. It was at this point that the light of the Big Bang stopped traveling freely through the universe and instead was absorbed by

original_text: In a report, published in early February 2007 by the Ear Institute at the University College London, and Widex, a Danish hearing aid manufacturer, Newcastle was named as the noisiest city in the whole of the UK, with an average level of 80.4 decibels. The report claimed that these noise levels would have a negative long-term impact on the health of the city's residents. The report was criticized, however, for attaching too much weight to readings at arbitrarily selected locations, which in Newcastle's case included a motorway underpass without pedestrian access.

original_text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the United Nations, set up at the request of member governments. It was first established in 1988 by two United Nations organizations, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), and later endorsed by the United Nations General Assembly through Resolution 4353. Membership of the IPCC is open to all member countries of the WMO and UNEP. The IPCC does not carry out its own research, nor does it do the work of any other organization. Thousands of scientists from all over the world contribute to the work of the IPCC on a voluntary basis. Review is an essential part of the IPCC process, to ensure an objective and complete assessment of current information. IPCC aims to reflect a range of views and expertise. The Secretariat coordinates all the IPCC work and liaises with Governments. It is supported by WMO and UNEP and hosted at the premises of WMO in Geneva, Switzerland. The IPCC Bureau Members, including the IPCC Chair, meet twice a year to decide IPCC policy and approve IPCC reports. The IPCC Panel is the decision making body of the IPCC and is responsible for the IPCC work programme. It also adopts the IPCC reports. It meets in plenary session at the main IPCC Conferences, where the IPCC Assessment Reports are approved. The IPCC Chair is elected by the Panel. The IPCC's activities are supported by a small Secretariat based in Geneva, Switzerland. The work of the IPCC is supported by governments and participating organizations through the provision of meeting facilities and financial support for the attendance of delegates and IPCC participants. The IPCC has established a Task Force on National Greenhouse Gas Inventories to develop and refine an internationally agreed methodology and software for the calculation and reporting of national greenhouse gas emissions and removals. The IPCC has also established a Task Force on Emission Scenarios to develop illustrative "storylines" of plausible future developments.

original_text: During his time at his lab, Tesla observed unusual signals from his receiver which he concluded may be communications from another planet. He mentioned them in a letter to reporter Julian Hawthorne at the Philadelphia North American on 8 December 1899 and in a December 1900 letter about possible discoveries in the new century to the Red Cross Society where he referred to his experiments in New York in the spring of 1899. In the letter Tesla explains that the sounds consist of disturbances which "would appear to my ear like faint, muddled whisperings." Tesla was a little unsure of himself as to whether he was actually receiving voice transmissions. He contacted some of his friends who understood the nature of sound and its properties, such as Robert Underwood Johnson, who was the editor of Century Magazine, and Sir Oliver Lodge. Both Johnson and Lodge confirmed that the sounds were real and not from Tesla's imagination. The next step for Tesla was to try to improve the transmission quality, and he continued to receive the signals through the summer of 1900. He also noted that the signals seemed to follow him, as he moved from Colorado Springs to Pike's Peak, to Telluride, to his lab in New York. He concluded that "the sounds I am listening to must be the genuine notes of the planetary symphony, perhaps, of some distant world."

original_text: Large-scale construction requires collaboration across multiple disciplines. An architect normally manages the job, and a construction manager, design engineer, construction engineer or project manager supervises it. For the successful execution of a project, effective planning is essential. Those involved with the design and execution of the infrastructure in question must consider zoning requirements, the environmental impact of the job, the successful scheduling, budgeting, construction-site safety, availability and transportation of building materials, logistics, inconvenience to the public caused by construction delays and bidding, etc. The largest construction projects are referred to as megaprojects.

original_text: Luther and his colleagues introduced the new order of worship during their visitation of the Electorate of Saxony, which began in 1527. They also assessed the standard of pastoral care and Christian education in the territory. The visitation was a "comprehensive evaluation of the spiritual and theological condition of the church, followed by the application of remedies to heal and strengthen its life and witness" (Gritsch 1986:333). The reformers' aim was to raise the level of Lutheran catechesis. Luther's Small Catechism was developed as a tool in this process. The great Reformer was not the first to recognise the importance of catechetical instruction. Theologians and leaders of the church have always recognised the necessity of instructing the young in the foundations of the faith. In fact, the practice of catechesis goes back to the very beginning of the church. Origen (died c.254) was the first to use the term catechetical. The word is derived from the Greek word katechein, which means "to teach orally" (Enns 2004:172). In the early church, the act of baptism was preceded by the catechumenate, a period of intensive instruction. This period could last up to three years. Catechetical instruction included the teaching of the fundamental doctrines of the faith. Somewhat later, the catechetical practice included a creedal statement to be recited by the catechumen, which was a preparatory step for baptism. In the ancient church the catechumenate was an orderly system of instruction, which lasted about three years. The baptismal candidates were called catechumens. The catechetical instruction of the church was not just for the young. It was common practice to instruct all people who wanted to become members of the church. The catechetical instruction included the teaching of the faith and instruction in the biblical narrative of redemption. During the medieval period, catechesis became the responsibility of the parish priest. He became the official catechist. During the late medieval period, the church was divided into two parts, the clergy and the laity. The clergy were more educated and were responsible for the teaching of the faith, while the laity were ignorant and uneducated. This division was detrimental to the church. The clergy, who were the teachers of the faith, lived a life far removed from the life of the people. The clergy were often more interested in political and economic matters than in the teaching of the faith. The clergy became more interested in the study of theology than in the teaching of the faith. Theological education became an end in itself. The teachings of the church were also less accessible to the people, because they were not translated into the language of the people. During the sixteenth century, the people were not allowed to read the Bible in their own language. The clergy regarded the Scriptures as the property of the church. They also discouraged the people from reading the Scriptures. The clergy regarded the Bible as a book to be studied in the Latin language. The Roman Catholic Church has a long tradition of catechesis. During the Middle Ages, catechesis was an important aspect of Catholic teaching. It was the principal vehicle for instructing children and adults in the fundamentals of the faith (Falco 2006:311). During the Middle Ages, catechesis was regarded as a part of the church's evangelical mission. The church began to teach the people to read and write. At first, the church taught the people to read and write so that they could read the Scriptures and the church's liturgy. However, the church used this opportunity to teach the people other subjects such as Latin. During the Middle Ages, the church's catechetical instruction was given in Latin, which most of the people did not understand. The catechetical instruction was given mainly to the children of the wealthy families. As the church developed, the catechetical instruction given to the people was given in a more systematic way. The church's catechetical instruction was given in the form of a lecture. The clergy would instruct the people by delivering sermons. In the medieval church, the clergy regarded the catechetical instruction as a spiritual exercise. During the Middle Ages, there were a number of handbooks that were used by the clergy to instruct the people. The clergy used

original_text: Tesla gained experience in telephony and electrical engineering before emigrating to the United States in 1884 to work for Thomas Edison in New York City. He soon struck out on his own with financial backers, setting up laboratories and companies to develop a range of electrical devices. His patented AC induction motor and transformer were licensed by George Westinghouse, who also hired Tesla for a short time as a consultant. His work in the formative years of electric power development was involved in a corporate alternating currentdirect current "War of Currents" as well as various patent battles.

original_text: The rainforest contains several species that can pose a hazard. Among the largest predatory creatures are the black caiman, jaguar, cougar, and anaconda. In the river, electric eels can produce an electric shock that can stun or kill, while piranha are known to bite and injure humans. Various species of poison dart frogs secrete lipophilic alkaloid toxins through their flesh. There are also numerous parasites and disease vectors. Vampire bats dwell in the rainforest and can spread the rabies virus. Malaria, yellow fever and Dengue fever can also be contracted in the Amazon region.

original_text: Plague was reportedly first introduced to Europe via Genoese traders at the port city of Kaffa in the Crimea in 1347. After a protracted siege, during which the Mongol army under Jani Beg was suffering from the disease, the army catapulted the infected corpses over the city walls of Kaffa to infect the inhabitants. The Genoese traders fled, taking the plague by ship into Sicily and the south of Europe, whence it spread north. Whether or not this hypothesis is accurate, it is clear that several existing conditions such as war, famine, and weather contributed to the severity of the Black Death.
text: Plague was reportedly first introduced to Europe via Genoese traders at the port city of Kaffa in the Crimea in 1347. After a protracted siege, during which the Mongol army under Jani Beg was suffering from the disease, the army catapulted the infected corpses over the city walls of Kaffa to infect the inhabitants. The Genoese traders fled, taking the plague by ship into Sicily and the south of Europe, whence it spread north. Whether or not this hypothesis is accurate, it is clear that several existing conditions such as war, famine, and weather contributed to the severity of the Black Death.

original_text: In 1466, perhaps 40,000 people died of the plague in Paris. During the 16th and 17th centuries, the plague was present in Paris around 30 per cent of the time. The Black Death ravaged Europe for three years before it continued on into Russia, where the disease was present somewhere in the country 25 times between 1350 to 1490. Plague epidemics ravaged London in 1563, 1593, 1603, 1625, 1636, and 1665, reducing its population by 10 to 30 during those years. Over 10 of Amsterdam's population died in 1623-25, and again in 1635-36, 1655, and 1664. Plague occurred in Venice 22 times between 1361 and 1528. The plague of 1576-77 killed 50,000 in Venice, almost a third of the population. Late outbreaks in central Europe included the Italian Plague of , which is associated with troop movements during the Thirty Years' War, and the Great Plague of Vienna in 1679. Over 60 of Norway's population died in 1348-50. The last plague outbreak ravaged Oslo in 1654.

original_text: Walt Disney and his brother Roy contacted Goldenson at the end of 1953 for ABC to agree to finance part of the Disneyland project in exchange for producing a television program for ABC. Although ABC was a fledgling network, it attracted Disney because it was not tied to a film studio that might interfere with his free rein in developing the content of the proposed television program. With ABC on board, Disney was then able to obtain a 500,000 loan from Bank of America to supplement his own 10,000 savings and the 400,000 he raised from other private investors. The Disneyland concept was a larger-than-life amusement park with attractions based on Disney animated films and television shows. To develop and build the park, Walt Disney appointed Walter E. Dymkus to be Disneyland's manager, and Harrison "Buzz" Price to determine a suitable location for the park. Walt Disney, with the aid of his brother Roy and his friend Herb Ryman, created a map of the park. Roy Disney then met with Stanford Research Institute to determine whether the proposed site in Anaheim, California was suitable for development. Based on SRI's positive evaluation, 160 acres (65 ha) of orange groves and walnut trees in Anaheim were purchased in 1954 for 800,000, and Disneyland construction began a year later. In July 1954, Walt Disney announced that Disneyland would be built in a 100-acre (40 ha) parcel of property bordered by South Harbor Boulevard, West Ball Road, Interstate 5, and South Disneyland Drive in Anaheim. Disney purchased the site for approximately 800,000, and sold 560,000 worth of stock in the Disneyland corporation to ABC (which was to co-produce the Disneyland television show) and other Hollywood investors. The site was situated in a suburban area 22 miles (35 km) southeast of Hollywood, in an area largely occupied by agricultural land and residential housing. A major issue was the availability of water, as the area was suffering from a drought. However, Disney was convinced that an underground aquifer would support the development. He also wanted to provide free parking to attract visitors, so Disney purchased a 100-acre (40 ha) parcel along the western edge of the site from farmer William B. Evans, Jr. for 100,000. This gave the park more than enough land for a large parking lot. In order to provide the necessary water supply, Disney acquired the rights to the first 1,200 acres (490 ha) of the Santa Ana River from the Orange County Water District for 50,000. Much of the Disneyland property was floodplain. To overcome this problem, the construction crews pumped tons of sandy fill into the site, while crews built retaining walls to contain the river, which now flows through a concrete channel. The first stage of construction was to clear the site of buildings, underbrush, and trees. When Disneyland opened in July 1955, the park had 20 attractions, no hotels, and only six dining establishments. Within the first three years, the park expanded to 40 attractions and eight restaurants. By 1959, the park hosted 7.7 million visitors, and Walt Disney Productions invested 20 million into the property. The park's expansion during the first three years was not without problems. The park initially opened with only five hours of electricity, which was scheduled to operate the attractions between 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. In the summer of 1955, the park had no nighttime activities, because the rides and attractions were not equipped for night use. That year, the park had a total of 12,000 light bulbs, most of which were in the park's lighting fixtures. Walt Disney personally hired experts to help the park with its lighting, including Roland F. "Doc" Sheridan and J. G. "Marty" Sklar. They worked with outside lighting companies to create better lighting for the park. In 1957, Walt Disney hired a lighting director, Joe Fowler, who brought in new lights to Disneyland. In 1959, Disneyland had 16,00
text: The Walt Disney Company was founded by Walt Disney and his brother Roy Disney in September 1953, following a meeting between Walt Disney's friend and business partner, Jack Goldenson, and ABC's chairman, George Westinghouse.

original_text: Oxygen is the most abundant chemical element by mass in the Earth's biosphere, air, sea and land. Oxygen is the third most abundant chemical element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium. At standard temperature and pressure, two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen, a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O2. Oxygen is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table, is a highly reactive nonmetal, and an oxidizing agent that readily forms oxides with most elements as well as with other compounds. By mass, oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium. At standard temperature and pressure, two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen, a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O2. Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 20.8 of the Earth's atmosphere. Additionally, as oxides the element makes up almost half of the Earth's crust. Dioxygen is the most common oxidizing agent in nature. Conversely, oxygen is also reduced, forming oxides and peroxides; notable examples include the superoxides, the peroxides, and ozone. Oxygen reacts spontaneously with some transition metals, such as iron, to give oxides and peroxides. Oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe by mass after hydrogen and helium and the most abundant element by mass in the Earth's crust. Oxygen is highly reactive, and in its pure form is a colorless, odorless gas. In the atmosphere, it is usually found in the form of a diatomic gas. Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 20.8 of the volume of air. In nature, elemental oxygen is produced from water by cyanobacteria, algae and plants during photosynthesis and is used in cellular respiration for all other living organisms. Oxygen is toxic to obligately anaerobic organisms, which were the dominant form of life on Earth until the Great Oxygenation Event. Oxygen is a very reactive element and must exist in the 2 state. It readily forms compounds with almost all other elements. Oxygen is the most electronegative element. It is one of the two elements with a diatomic state of matter at standard conditions for temperature and pressure, the other being bromine. Oxygen reacts spontaneously with some transition metals, such as iron, to give oxides and peroxides; the lightest transition metal nitride is uranium nitride. The extraction of a key intermediate product in the industrial synthesis of ethylene glycol from ethylene oxide represents a major commercial application of the direct oxidation of hydrocarbons by oxygen. Reactive oxygen species are intermediates or products of the normal metabolism of oxygen and have a short lifetime in the cell. However, during times of environmental stress, production of these compounds may exceed the cell's capacity to neutralize them, leading to oxidative stress. Reactive oxygen species can induce programmed cell death and stimulate cell proliferation. Oxygen, as a part of oxygen gas (O2), is produced from water by cyanobacteria, algae and plants during photosynthesis and is used in cellular respiration for all other living organisms. Green algae and cyanobacteria in marine environments provide about 70 of the free oxygen produced on earth and the rest of free oxygen is produced by terrestrial plants. Oxygen is produced industrially by fractional distillation of liquefied air, use of zeolites and electrolysis of water into which dissolved potassium hydroxide has been introduced to increase the conductivity. original_text: Firstly, certain costs are difficult to avoid and are shared by everyone, such as the costs of housing, pensions, education and health care. If the state does not provide these services, then other providers will charge for them and they will not disappear. Secondly, there is a choice of different kinds of tax. For example, if a poll tax is introduced, then this will not reduce income tax. If a flat rate tax is introduced, then this will not reduce corporation tax. Thirdly, taxes are complicated. The more complicated the tax system, the more difficult it will be to calculate how much it costs to collect. The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that a flat rate of income tax would cost 20 billion a year to introduce. However, the government's own research concludes that the cost of introducing a flat rate of income tax would be 30 billion a year. The TaxPayers' Alliance also argues that the cost of collecting the taxes on tobacco and alcohol is 500 million a year. However, the UK Government's own research estimates that the cost of collecting tobacco taxes is 300 million a year and the cost of collecting alcohol taxes is 600 million a year. Moreover, the TaxPayers' Alliance does not take into account all of the costs of collecting taxes. For example, it does not include the cost of prosecuting people who avoid paying tax or the cost of investigating and challenging tax avoidance schemes. For more details, see Chapter 6 of the Mirrlees Review of the UK Tax System. In the UK, the poorest 10 of households pay a higher proportion of their income in taxes than the richest 10 of households. In other words, the tax system in the UK is regressive. Of course, some taxes are more progressive than others. Income tax is progressive. Council tax is regressive. The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that in 200809, the poorest 10 of households paid a lower proportion of their income in taxes than the richest 10 of households. However, it does not include the cost of means-tested benefits in its calculation. It also does not include the costs of indirect taxes on goods and services that the poorest 10 of households are more likely to buy. When indirect taxes are included, then the richest 10 of households pay a higher proportion of their income in taxes than the poorest 10 of households. Moreover, the tax burden on poorer households will increase under the Government's spending cuts, as means-tested benefits are cut. The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that the UK government spends 18 million a year on health and safety regulation. However, it does not explain what it means by health and safety regulation or where the 18 million figure comes from. Moreover, the cost of health and safety regulation is not easy to estimate. It depends on how one defines health and safety regulation. The TaxPayers' Alliance also claims that the UK government spends 36 million a year on equality and diversity regulation. However, it does not explain what it means by equality and diversity regulation or where the 36 million figure comes from. Moreover, the cost of equality and diversity regulation is not easy to estimate. It depends on how one defines equality and diversity regulation. The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that the UK government spends 126 million a year on regulating the telecommunications sector. However, it does not explain what it means by regulating the telecommunications sector or where the 126 million figure comes from. Moreover, the cost of regulating the telecommunications sector is not easy to estimate. It depends on how one defines regulating the telecommunications sector. Moreover, the cost of regulating the telecommunications sector will depend on whether it is regulated by the government or by Ofcom. For example, Ofcom's operating costs in 200910 were 146 million. The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that the UK government spends 17 million a year on regulating the energy sector. However, it does not explain what it means by regulating the energy sector or where the 17 million figure comes from. Moreover, the cost of regulating the energy sector is not easy to estimate. It depends on how one defines regulating the energy sector. Moreover, the cost of regulating the energy sector will depend on whether it is regulated by the government
text: The TaxPayers' Alliance claims that a flat rate of income tax would cost 20 billion a year to introduce, but the UK Government's own research concludes that the cost of introducing a flat Rate of Income Tax would be 30bn a year.

original_text: Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at level two, the data link layer. Another major difference between X.25 and Frame Relay is that X.25 requires a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted. Frame Relay does not define any such handshakes. X.25 does not define any operations inside the packet network. It only operates at the user-network-interface (UNI). Thus, the network provider is free to use any procedure it wishes inside the network. X.25 does specify some limited re-transmission procedures at the UNI, and its link layer protocol (LAPB) provides conventional HDLC-type link management procedures. Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDN's layer two protocol, LAPD and LAPB. As such, its integrity operations pertain only between nodes on a link, not end-to-end. Any retransmissions must be carried out by higher layer protocols. The X.25 UNI protocol is part of the X.25 protocol suite, which consists of the lower three layers of the OSI Model. It was widely used at the UNI for packet switching networks during the 1980s and early 1990s, to provide a standardized interface into and out of packet networks. Some implementations used X.25 within the network as well, but its connection-oriented features made this setup cumbersome and inefficient. Frame relay operates principally at layer two of the OSI Model. However, its address field (the Data Link Connection ID, or DLCI) can be used at the OSI network layer, with a minimum set of procedures. Thus, it rids itself of many X.25 layer 3 encumbrances, but still has the DLCI as an ID beyond a node-to-node layer two link protocol. The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X.25. Because Frame relay is a data link layer protocol, like X.25 it does not define internal network routing operations. For X.25 its packet IDsthe virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers have to be correlated to network addresses. The same is true for Frame Relays DLCI. How this is done is up to the network provider. Frame Relay, by virtue of having no network layer procedures is connection-oriented at layer two, by using the HDLCLAPDLAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode (SABM). X.25 connections are typically established for each communication session, but it does have a feature allowing a limited amount of traffic to be passed across the UNI without the connection-oriented handshake. For a while, Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks. However, X.25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted by the Internet Protocol (IP) at the network layer, and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and or versions of Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) at layer two. A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS. original_text: Microorganisms or toxins that successfully enter an organism encounter the cells and mechanisms of the innate immune system. The innate response is usually triggered when microbes are identified by pattern recognition receptors, which recognize components that are conserved among broad groups of microorganisms, or when damaged, injured or stressed cells send out alarm signals, many of which (but not all) are recognized by the same receptors as those that recognize pathogens. Innate immune defenses are non-specific, meaning these systems respond to pathogens in a generic way. This system does not confer long-lasting immunity against a pathogen. The innate immune system is the dominant system of host defense in most organisms.

original_text: Of particular concern with Internet pharmacies is the ease with which people, youth in particular, can obtain controlled substances (e.g., Vicodin, generically known as hydrocodone) via the Internet without a prescription issued by a doctorpractitioner who has an established doctor-patient relationship. There are many instances where a practitioner issues a prescription, brokered by an Internet server, for a controlled substance to a "patient" she has never met.[citation needed] In the United States, in order for a prescription for a controlled substance to be valid, it must be issued for a legitimate medical purpose by a licensed practitioner acting in the course of legitimate doctor-patient relationship. The filling pharmacy has a corresponding responsibility to ensure that the prescription is valid. Often, individual state laws outline what defines a valid patient-doctor relationship.

original_text: The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine. The cycle is an arrangement of components as is typically used for simple power production, and utilizes the thermodynamic properties of water and steam to produce mechanical work from heat. The efficiency of the cycle is limited by the properties of the working fluid and the operating conditions of the components. The Rankine cycle follows the four processes and states of the thermodynamic cycle as described in thermodynamics. The four processes and states of the Rankine cycle are: 1-2 Isentropic expansion (isentropic means constant entropy) 3-4 Isentropic compression 2-3 Isobaric heat addition 4-1 Isobaric heat rejection In the Rankine cycle, the working fluid (water) is initially at a low pressure and temperature, and a liquid. During the cycle, the fluid undergoes phase change to steam (vapor) and then back to liquid water. The working fluid is pumped from a low pressure reservoir to a high pressure reservoir by an external force (e.g. a pump), and a heat source is used to heat the working fluid to an even higher temperature. The heated working fluid is expanded through a turbine to convert the thermal energy into mechanical work. A condenser cools the expanded working fluid to its original temperature and pressure, and the working fluid is pumped back into the high pressure reservoir. The heat source, the pump, the turbine, and the condenser are the components of the Rankine cycle. 4-1 Isobaric heat rejection (condenser) In the Rankine cycle, the working fluid is water. The water is pumped from a low pressure reservoir to a high pressure reservoir by an external force (e.g. a pump), and a heat source is used to heat the working fluid to an even higher temperature. The heated water is expanded through a turbine to convert the thermal energy into mechanical work. A condenser cools the expanded water to its original temperature and pressure, and the water is pumped back into the high pressure reservoir. The heat source, the pump, the turbine, and the condenser are the components of the Rankine cycle. The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine. The cycle is an arrangement of components as is typically used for simple power production, and utilizes the thermodynamic properties of water and steam to produce mechanical work from heat. The efficiency of the cycle is limited by the properties of the working fluid and the operating conditions of the components. The heat source temperature is a limiting factor to the thermal efficiency of the cycle, and the cycle is generally used to convert heat into mechanical work near to the heat source, with the lower temperature heat rejected into the ambient environment. 1-2 Isentropic expansion (isentropic means constant entropy) (turbine) 2-3 Isentropic compression (compressor) 3-4 Isobaric heat addition (boiler) 4-1 Isobaric heat rejection (condenser)

The RCA is a member of the National Council of Churches, the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, and the World Council of Churches. The Reformed Church in America has approximately 325,000 members and 1,030 congregations, with almost 100,000 members living in Canada. The Reformed Church in America has been in existence for over 370 years and is still actively engaged in proclaiming the good news of God's grace in Jesus Christ. text: The Reformed Church in America traces its origins to the Dutch Reformed Church, which was founded in 1628 in New Amsterdam (now New York City) by Dutch immigrants.

original_text: The city is the seat of a Roman Catholic archdiocese (left bank of the Vistula) and diocese (right bank), and possesses various universities, most notably the Polish Academy of Sciences (Polska Akademia Nauk), the Jagiellonian University, the Pedagogical University, and the Krakow Academy of Economics. There are also a number of colleges, museums, and galleries, including the National Museum, the Cathedral of St. Mary, and the Archaeological Museum, all of which have collections dating back to the Middle Ages. The site of Krakow was occupied by a Slavonic settlement in the 7th century, but a town was not established until about 1000. In the 11th century the area was ruled by the Piast dynasty, who established a bishopric in 1000. In 1241 the city was captured by the Mongols. Krakow was the capital of Poland from 1038 to 1569, when Warsaw was chosen as the new capital. The city was part of the Habsburg Empire from 1583 until 1684, when it was seized by the Swedes, but it was restored to Poland in 1697. After the final partition of Poland in 1795, Krakow was ceded to Austria and became the capital of Galicia. During World War II, Krakow was under German occupation and was known as the seat of the German Governor General Hans Frank (1939-45). The Nazis built a concentration camp at Auschwitz (Oswiecim), just west of Krakow, and a network of subcamps at surrounding factories, mines, and farms. The city was liberated by Soviet troops in January 1945. Krakow became part of the Polish People's Republic in 1947.
text: Krakow is the capital of Poland and one of the most important cities in central Europe, with a population of more than one million, and is the largest city in the Silesian region.

original_text: Whilst the permanent building at Holyrood was being constructed, the Parliament's temporary home was the General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh. Official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the Assembly Hall, which is part of the School of Divinity of the University of Edinburgh. This building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the Church's General Assembly. In May 2000, the Parliament was temporarily relocated to the former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow, and to the University of Aberdeen in May 2002.

original_text: Various gold-themed promotions and initiatives were held throughout the 2015 NFL season to tie into the "Golden Super Bowl"; gold-tinted logos were implemented across the NFL's properties and painted on fields, the numbering of the 50-yard line on fields was colored gold, and beginning on week 7, all sideline jackets and hats featured gold-trimmed logos. Gold footballs were given to each high school that has had a player or coach appear in the Super Bowl, and "homecoming" events were also held by Super Bowl-winning teams at games.

original_text: Kenya has proven deposits of oil in Turkana and the commercial viability was just discovered. Tullow Oil estimates Kenya's oil reserves to be around 10 billion barrels. Exploration is still ongoing to determine the extent of oil deposits in Turkana and the coastal region. According to Tullow Oil, Kenya's proven oil reserves are estimated to be around 10 billion barrels. Kenya's potential gas reserves are estimated at 500 billion cubic feet. The Government is also evaluating shale gas and coal bed methane potential. According to Ministry of Energy and Petroleum, Kenya's oil reserves stand at 1.2 billion barrels, of which 600 million barrels are recoverable. Tullow Oil is the leading oil exploration company in the country. In the past, Kenya had a thriving oil industry that produced 12,000 barrels per day, but this industry collapsed in the 1970s and 1980s due to mismanagement and the falling oil prices. In 2012, Kenya earned KES 2.8 billion from oil exploration. The Ministry of Energy and Petroleum is implementing the Kenya Petroleum Exploration and Production Bill 2014, which will guide the development of the upstream oil and gas sector. The National Oil Corporation of Kenya (NOCK) is the state-owned oil company in Kenya. NOCK's functions include importing, storing and distributing petroleum products in Kenya. The company also acts as an advisor to the Government on matters related to energy and petroleum. Other private players in the industry include Kenol Kobil, Total Kenya, Oil Libya and Shell Kenya. The oil and gas sector in Kenya is still in the exploration and development stage. There are no local suppliers of oilfield equipment. The country imports 100 per cent of its crude oil. Oil exploration firms are required to use local services and goods in their operations. This is in compliance with the Local Content Policy and the National Oil and Gas Policy. The Kenya Petroleum Refineries (KPRL) is the only refinery in Kenya. The refinery has a capacity of 35,000 barrels per day and produces petroleum products including gasoline, diesel, kerosene, aviation fuel and lubricants. The Ministry of Energy and Petroleum has set up a Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) working group to explore the feasibility of LPG development in the country. The group will study the establishment of LPG import facilities and distribution infrastructure in Kenya. In 2014, the Government of Kenya signed a preliminary deal to construct a KES 47 billion oil refinery in Lamu. The facility will have a capacity of 120,000 barrels per day. The construction is expected to start in 2016. Low price of oil in the global market.
text: Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta has announced that the country's oil and gas reserves will be developed in a manner that will create jobs and boost the economy.

original_text: A number of researchers (David Rodda, Jacob Vigdor, and Janna Matlack), argue that a shortage of affordable housing - at least in the US - is caused in part by restrictive zoning laws and regulations. While I think that the rhetoric of a "housing shortage" is a bit overblown (I've yet to see anyone who actually believes that prices would be lower without the regulation), I do think that zoning regulations are an important part of the puzzle. In my own work, I find that regional zoning regulations are an important part of understanding housing prices, especially at the higher end of the market. As I was reading about the work of Rodda, Vigdor, and Matlack, I was reminded of the work of US Treasury Secretary Andrew Mellon. A number of years ago I heard an economist discussing Mellon's work on the economics of zoning and the impact of zoning on the supply of housing. I can't find the original source, but I did find an article on the Mellon's ideas from 2007, written by Mark Thornton. Here is the relevant excerpt from Thornton's article: Andrew Mellon, the U.S. Treasury Secretary in the 1920s, wrote, "Within the past year I have come to the conclusion that zoning restrictions and building codes have been greatly responsible for the present high cost of housing....I have come to the conclusion that if it were possible to repeal all building laws and codes...we would have the low cost home and the end of the slums." Mellon's insights, though overlooked, are worth pursuing, because they expose a serious problem with government zoning policy. The problem is that zoning laws, which were intended to promote better living conditions for city dwellers, have led to the opposite. The problem is that these zoning laws were not just a way to "promote better living conditions," but were instead a way to exclude lower-class people from certain neighborhoods. Housing prices are not simply a function of supply and demand. There is also the element of zoning and neighborhood covenants. An example of this is the racial covenant that was used in the deed of a house that I bought in the 1990s. Posted by Phil Miller on June 04, 2012 at 08:35 AM in Economics, Housing Permalink Comments (0)

original_text: In the Presidential elections, President Kibaki under the Party of National Unity ran for re-election against the main opposition party, the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM). The elections were seen to have been flawed with international observers saying that they were below international standards. After a split which took a crucial 8 of the votes away from the ODM to the newly formed Orange Democratic Movement-Kenya (ODM-K) 's candidate, Kalonzo Musyoka, the race tightened between ODM candidate Raila Odinga and Kibaki. As the count came into the Electoral Commission of Kenya (ECK) headquarters, Odinga was shown to have a slight, and then substantial lead as the results from his strongholds came in early. As the ECK continued to count the votes, Kibaki closed the gap and then overtook his opponent by a substantial margin after votes from his stronghold arrived later. This led to protests and open discrediting of the ECK for complicity and to Odinga declaring himself the "people's president" and calling for a recount.
text: In the Presidential elections, President Kibaki under the Party of National Unity ran for re-election against the main opposition party, the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM). The elections were seen to have been flawed with international observers saying that they were below international standards. After a split which took a crucial 8 of the votes away from the ODM to the newly formed Orange Democratic Movement-Kenya (ODM-K) 's candidate, Kalonzo Musyoka, the race tightened between ODM candidate Raila Odinga and Kibaki. As the count came into the Electoral Commission of Kenya (ECK) headquarters, Odinga was shown to have a slight, and then substantial lead as the results from his strongholds came in early. As the ECK continued to count the votes, Kibaki closed the gap and then overtook his opponent by a substantial margin after votes from his stronghold arrived later. This led to protests and open discrediting of the ECK for complicity and to Odinga declaring himself the "people's president" and calling for a recount.

original_text: On December 28, 2015, ESPN Deportes announced that they had reached an agreement with CBS and the NFL to be the exclusive Spanish-language broadcaster of the game, marking the third dedicated Spanish-language broadcast of the Super Bowl. Unlike NBC and Fox, CBS does not have a Spanish-language outlet of its own that could broadcast the game (though per league policy, a separate Spanish play-by-play call was carried on CBS's second audio program channel for over-the-air viewers). The game was called by ESPN Deportes' Monday Night Football commentary crew of Alvaro Martin and Raul Allegre, and sideline reporter John Sutcliffe. ESPN Deportes broadcast pre-game and post-game coverage, while Martin, Allegre, and Sutcliffe contributed English-language reports for ESPN's SportsCenter and Mike Mike.

original_text: The agreements include fixed annual carriage fees of PS30m for the channels with both channel suppliers able to secure additional capped payments if their channels meet certain performance-related targets. Currently, the BBC's BBC One and BBC Two channels are available on a free-to-air basis. The deal also includes a commitment from the BBC to seek to secure a further long-term extension of its terrestrial channels' licences. BBC Director General Mark Thompson said: "This is a good deal for licence fee payers. "By bringing these negotiations to a successful conclusion we have secured the long-term future of our most popular TV channels, while also generating significant savings for licence fee payers. "As the licence fee review gets underway, we're determined to ensure that the BBC continues to offer the best possible value for money for our audiences. "We are committed to delivering further significant savings as part of the licence fee review, with plans to cut costs by PS400m over the next six years. "The extra savings we have agreed with the BBC as part of this deal will not be redirected to other areas of BBC activity. Instead, the licence fee settlement will require the BBC to deliver the further savings for licence fee payers announced in March.

"By bringing these negotiations to a successful conclusion we have secured the long-term future of our most popular TV channels, while also generating significant savings for licence fee payers.

original_text: French Huguenot explorer Jean Ribault charted the St. Johns River in 1562 calling it the River of May because he discovered it in May. Ribault erected a stone column near present-day Jacksonville claiming the newly discovered land for France. In 1564, Rene Goulaine de Laudonniere established the first European settlement, Fort Caroline, on the St. Johns near the main village of the Saturiwa. Philip II of Spain ordered Pedro Menendez de Aviles to protect the interest of Spain by attacking the French presence at Fort Caroline. On September 20, 1565, a Spanish force from the nearby Spanish settlement of St. Augustine attacked Fort Caroline, and killed nearly all the French soldiers defending it. The Spanish renamed the fort San Mateo, and following the ejection of the French, St. Augustine's position as the most important settlement in Florida was solidified. The location of Fort Caroline is subject to debate but a reconstruction of the fort was established on the St. Johns River in 1964.

original_text: As in the House of Commons, a number of qualifications apply to being an MSP. Such qualifications were introduced under the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Act 1981. They are summarised below. A person is disqualified from being an MSP if they: are a peer, that is to say a person who holds a title of honour that entitles them to sit in the House of Lords; hold an office or place of profit under the Crown (other than an office of the Queen's Body Guard for Scotland or Royal Company of Archers); hold an office under the Scottish Government or the Scottish Parliament; are the chief executive of a local authority or are employed by a local authority; are the chief constable of the Police Service of Scotland; or are the Lord Advocate, Solicitor General for Scotland, the Procurator Fiscal of the Court of the Lord Lyon, the Lord Advocate Depute, the Solicitor General, or the Advocate General for Scotland. Also, a person is disqualified from being an MSP if, within the last five years, they have been convicted of a corrupt or illegal practice at a parliamentary, local government or European Parliamentary election. A person is disqualified from being an MSP if they are the subject of a bankruptcy restrictions order or a debt relief restrictions order. In addition, a person is disqualified from being an MSP if, within the last five years, they have been convicted of an offence and have had passed on them a sentence of imprisonment or detention for a term of three months or more. Qualification (No. 2) Act 1921 The Qualification (No. 2) Act 1921 disqualifies from being an MSP any person who: holds certain offices under the Crown; is a minister of the Church of Scotland who receives a stipend; holds a commission in Her Majesty's Forces (other than in the reserve forces); or holds a commission in the reserve forces and is liable for service. The Act also requires MSPs to sign a declaration on taking office that they do not hold any of these offices. Disqualification (Scotland) Act 2000 The Disqualification (Scotland) Act 2000 disqualifies an MSP if, within the last five years, they have been convicted of a crime involving dishonesty or deception. The Act also requires MSPs to sign a declaration on taking office that they do not fall within this disqualification. British Nationality Act 1981 The British Nationality Act 1981 disqualifies a person from being an MSP if they are neither a Commonwealth citizen nor a citizen of the Republic of Ireland. The Electoral Commission has published a booklet providing further information on the disqualification provisions relating to the Scottish Parliament.
text: An MSP is a member of the Scottish Parliament and is elected by the people of Scotland at the Holyrood election on 5 May 2014... and then re-elected at the next general election on 8 May 2015.

original_text: The Very high-speed Backbone Network Service (vBNS) came on line in April 1995 as part of a National Science Foundation (NSF) sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between NSF-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States. The network was engineered and operated by MCI Telecommunications under a cooperative agreement with the NSF. By 1998, the vBNS had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with DS-3 (45 Mbits), OC-3c (155 Mbits), and OC-12c (622 Mbits) links on an all OC-12c backbone, a substantial engineering feat for that time. The vBNS installed one of the first ever production OC-48c (2.5 Gbits) IP links in February 1999 and went on to upgrade the entire backbone to OC-48c.
text: The Very high-speed Backbone Network Service (vBNS) came on line in April 1995 as part of a National Science Foundation (NSF) sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between NSF-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States.
