The vBNS installed one of the first ever production OC-48c (2.5 Gbits) IP links in February 1999 and went on to upgrade the entire backbone to OC-48c.

original_text: The historian Francis Aidan Gasquet wrote about the'Great Pestilence' in 1893 and suggested that "it would appear to be some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague." He was right, but the new evidence is much more detailed. Today, we have a far better understanding of the plague bacillus, which is so called because it has the shape of a rod or bacillus. The bubonic plague is a disease caused by bacteria called Yersinia pestis. It is transmitted by fleas that live on rats. The flea's bite transmits the bacteria to the bloodstream, and can be fatal within two or three days. It is not spread from person to person. A person with the bubonic plague will experience fever, vomiting, headaches and painfully swollen glands. Without treatment, death can come within three days. In the Middle Ages, the bubonic plague was fatal in 70-90 of cases. "In the first year there was a terrible mortality in England among the upper classes, and in the second year it was even worse. Many thousands of people died and many cities were almost destroyed" The Black Death was the most devastating epidemic in recorded history, killing between 30 and 60 of Europe's population. Today, we estimate that between 75 and 200 million people died. The Black Death arrived in Europe in October 1347, when twelve Genoese galleys docked in Sicily. They carried rats, and more worryingly, the bacteria that caused the bubonic plague. Genoese merchants were well known for their trading links with the Black Sea, and the Italian city of Genoa was an important trading port. The Black Death spread through Europe by sea and overland. It was impossible to contain and people had no idea what was causing it. "The pestilence was so powerful that it could not be checked by any means" As people fled the Black Death, many carried the bacteria with them. The plague became a stowaway on trading ships and in the baggage of fleeing travellers. The Black Death was a pandemic - a disease that has spread over a wide geographical area. The plague pandemic arrived in England via Bristol in June 1348 and swept rapidly across the country. The Black Death was so destructive because no-one knew what was causing it. This meant that there was no way to prevent it, and no cure. The symptoms of the plague were well known, but the cause was not. This meant that there was no way to prevent it spreading. The lack of any cure meant that the plague spread quickly. Within four years, it had killed between one third and half of Europe's population. The symptoms of the bubonic plague were well known, but the cause was not. People believed that the plague was sent as a punishment from God for the sins of mankind. They took to prayer, penance and processions. They made offerings to churches and saints, and went on pilgrimages. These actions did nothing to prevent the spread of the plague. The plague was highly contagious, and it was impossible to contain. Medieval medicine did not understand the true cause of the plague. They were unaware of the role of fleas in spreading the disease. Treatments included sweating, bleeding and purging. In some places, people turned to sorcery and magic to save themselves. In 1348, William of Ockham became a Franciscan friar. Born in Ockham, a village in Surrey, he had studied at Merton College, Oxford. William of Ockham was a philosopher and logician. He is famous for 'Ockham's Razor'. This is a principle in science that states that the simplest solution is often the right one. William of Ockham was so convinced that the plague was not a punishment from God that he wrote a book explaining why. He argued that plague was not a divine punishment for sin, but an act of nature. He wrote that the plague was caused by an 'infection of the air', which infected humans. William of Ockham believed that the 'infection of the air' was caused by an alignment of the planets, not by God's wrath. William of Ockham's ideas

original_text: QuickBooks sponsored a "Small Business Big Game" contest, in which Death Wish Coffee had a 30-second commercial aired free of charge courtesy of QuickBooks. Death Wish Coffee beat out nine other finalists to win the competition and the commercial aired during the third quarter of the game. "We are in total disbelief and still pinching ourselves," the company said in a statement. Death Wish Coffee was the victor of Intuit's (NASDAQ:INTU) Small Business Big Game competition. When you think of NY, you think of big things - like big business and the big apple - but the state's governor is showing off his small business pride. While this is the first time a Super Bowl commercial has been given away for free, the idea has been done before in other forms of media. And although the commercial for the coffee company is only 30 seconds, it cost Super Bowl advertisers an average of 4.8 million per 30-second spot. "With no advertising budget, we were forced to think outside of the box," Death Wish Coffee founder Mike Brown said in a statement. The small business also entered the marketing campaign by creating a new flavor of coffee called the "Super Bowl Blend."

original_text: A number of Huguenots served as mayors in Dublin, Cork, Youghal and Waterford in the 17th and 18th centuries. Numerous signs of Huguenot presence can still be seen with names still in use, and with areas of the main towns and cities named after the people who settled there. Examples include the Huguenot District and French Church Street in Cork City; and D'Olier Street in Dublin, named after a High Sheriff and one of the founders of the Bank of Ireland. A French church in Portarlington dates back to 1696, and was built to serve the significant new Huguenot community in the town. At the time, they constituted the majority of the townspeople.

A French church in Portarlington dates back to 1696, and was built to serve the significant new Huguenot community in the town. At the time, they constituted the majority of the townspeople.

original_text: Through combining the definition of electric current as the time rate of change of electric charge, a rule of vector multiplication called Lorentz's Law describes the force on a charge when in the presence of a magnetic field. In the unit system of CGS, in which electric charge is measured in units of coulombs and time is measured in units of seconds, the force on a charged particle is measured in units of dyne. In the unit system of MKS, in which electric charge is measured in units of coulombs and time is measured in units of seconds, the force on a charged particle is measured in units of newtons. In the unit system of Gaussian, in which electric charge is measured in units of statC and time is measured in units of seconds, the force on a charged particle is measured in units of dyne.
